PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the pastoral and rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering the man on the land in the organisation of his affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 14 citizens) and Kilgariff (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Protected Wildlife: Laboratory Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we believe that our protected wildlife are not suitable subjects for laboratory experimentation and that repetitive and needless experiments should be prohibited.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robertson (from three citizens) and Short (from 188 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Robertson (from 18 citizens) and Watson (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill.

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate and all Senators in the Parliament assembled we the undersigned do in humble duty pray that the parliament reject legislation to enact an Australian Bill of Rights which we believe is contrary to the well being and wishes of the Australian people and the Australian community.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 24 citizens) and Robertson (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 60 citizens) and Robertson (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous, divisive and unnecessary proposal, the provisions of which are dictatorial, harmful and against the true interest of the people of Australia.
Your petitioners pray: That the Senate reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article 11 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney- General. I note the statement by the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia issued today and I ask the Minister: How does the Government propose that the Parliament might determine disputed matters of fact presented by Mr Justice Murphy in his response to all matters allegedly involving him in volume 2 of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and the Don Thomas allegations?

—The situation is that the Government simply will not give any further consideration to that matter unless and until we hear further from the High Court of Australia after the High Court has been through such processes as it decides it wants to undertake to resolve this matter.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the Chief Justice has put out a statement saying that the justices do not intend to conduct any inquiry or make any finding as to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. I ask the Minister to reconsider his answer, in light of that and other comments made by the Chief Justice, and tell us on what basis this matter is simply to be left in abeyance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw Senator Chaney's attention to the last sentence of the Chief Justice's statement in which he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The other members of the Court agreed to postpone further discussion until Mr Justice Murphy has made such response as he wishes to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the the Minister for Community Services whether his attention has been drawn to an article in today's Mercury newspaper in which a management consultant for the Tasmanian Spastics Association is critical of a recent Federal Government grant for respite care in Hobart. Can the Minister indicate whether this new service will affect the existing respite care service run by the Tasmanian Spastics Association?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the claims of a management consultant who was very critical of the Federal Government funding of, in this case, a State government department to provide for the co-ordination of respite care services in Hobart. I point out that the management consultant was one Ms Carmel Holmes who, until the last election in Tasmania, was the Liberal member for Denison and who, some few weeks after she was a Liberal member, recently attempted to become an independent member of the Upper House and failed there, too. I am amazed that she should be so critical of a proposal to provide for co-ordination of respite care services in Hobart. One of the consistent pleas of parents who have attended forums and meetings with me and the State Minister for Community Welfare has been about the lack of information on such programs and the lack of co-ordination in the delivery of such services.

ANSWER.PARA: I was very happy that my Department had been able to provide a grant of $42,000 to the State Department of Community Welfare for a respite care service for intellectually and physically disabled people in their homes and in the homes of host families. Far from being wasteful expenditure of public money, the new service is designed to complement the existing in-home caring services which are offered by the Tasmanian Spastics Association. That Association has recently been granted $76,000-odd for its program of respite care for the children of southern Tasmania. The program to which we have recently given a grant is to complement and supplement that program-not to act in competition with it. I suggest that Ms Holmes direct her energy to giving credit where credit is due and not fall for the simple formula of merely criticising everything that is initiated by this Government-apparently even those things initiated by this Government to assist the Tasmanian Government. I do not know what Ms Holmes thinks she will achieve by this. She has not achieved much in the two recent elections, and I hope that this sort of behaviour will consign her to the political dustbin where she belongs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to comments by the Attorney-General on the national Today show this morning, when he said that the Government was put on notice by the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia only last Friday that there was some uncertainty about the position of Mr Justice Murphy. I ask: Was not the Government considering volume 2 of the Stewart report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions and the allegations by Don Thomas in the context of the judge's position on the High Court before the Chief Justice spoke to the Attorney-General last Friday and, if not, why not?

—Of course the Government was considering the recommendations of volume 2 of the Stewart report at that time. To answer the question, however, as to whether there was anything in that volume which may have had significance for Mr Justice Murphy's future would be to reveal the contents of that report. To answer the question either way would be to reveal the contents of the report. That is not something the Government is proposing to do, for good reasons articulated last week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Foreign Investment Review Board investigate directors of companies and possible corrupt practices in its review of foreign investment proposals? Can the Minister confirm that the FIRB has so investigated the Iwasaki tourist resort at Yeppoon on the central Queensland coast?

—I have noticed in the Age newspaper today and also in the Australian Financial Review, if not in other newspapers, that a son-in-law of the Queensland Premier, Mr Folker, was appointed as a director of the Iwasaki Sangyo company, which runs the Yeppoon tourist resort, on Christmas Day 1984. Mr Folker is reported as being the manager of a farm at Kingaroy, which is a long way from Yeppoon. For those two reasons I imagine that he would be uniquely well qualified to be a director of the Iwasaki tourist resort company. I am sure that his appointment would have had nothing to do with the fact that he is the son-in-law of the Queensland Premier. Likewise I am sure that the $55,000 paid by the same company as part of a land exchange deal to the Premier's son, John Bjelke-Petersen, had nothing to do with the fact that John Bjelke-Petersen is the son of the Premier. I notice that one or two other matters were put forward in the Age newspaper as well. If I can drop the irony now, given the prima facie case of some sleazy, under the table deals in regard to that company and the favoured treatment it has received on many occasions from the Queensland Government, it is a matter I will refer to the Treasury, but as far as I know there is nothing in the FIRB regulations that would allow the FIRB to do that.
—I raise a point of order. My point of order is that by the end of the answer the Minister was making a direct allegation of corruption against the Queensland Government and I ask him to withdraw it.

—I listened to the Minister and I thought the Minister was speaking generally about the Queensland Government, not about any particular individual. If I am wrong in that, and the Minister did relate his remarks to an individual Minister in the Queensland Government, I ask him to withdraw them.
—If anybody wants to construe my remarks that way, naturally I am happy to withdraw. I completed my answer and I am happy to let the public record speak for itself.

—Mr President, I wish to address you on the point of order. This is the second time in a short period that the Minister has used the same technique of naming individuals and then moving on to make a general allegation. In this case he mentioned several members of the family of the Premier of Queensland and then went on to make a general allegation of corruption. The Minister, with his smart-Alick manner and the attempts he makes to play to his gallery of supporters, is clearly showing contempt for the forms of this place by using that verbal technique to avoid being in breach of Standing Orders. The point I make is simply this: What Senator Walsh is doing is firstly naming individuals and then linking those individuals to conduct which he would not be able to directly accuse them of under the Standing Orders.
—Tell us how your brother-

—There is a typical example of that interjection. Senator Walsh referred to a brother of mine on a matter which has been aired in this place on many occasions, in the same way as there has been an inquiry into the matter which is consistently run at my colleague Senator Michael Baume, and where there has been a clearing. The issues he raised by way of interjection against my brother were dealt with by a royal commissioner, Mr Justice Smith, and there is a very clear statement as to my brother's innocence. This is a typical example of the sort of smear on which I have risen with respect to Premier Bjelke-Petersen. Mr President, I ask you to examine not just the immediate sentence in which the accusation of corruption is made but the totality of the answer, which clearly tries to tie that to the individual concerned.
—Boring.

—I note the interjection of `boring' on my left. The fact is that for a very long period this Minister has engaged in this and similar techniques. The Opposition believes that it is entitled to the protection of the Chair and the protection of the Standing Orders and that he should be called to order.

—Mr President, on the point of order: As this Senate would know I am not a self-appointed protector of Senator Walsh-nor would he wish that. While I have great respect for the point of order raised by Senator Chaney, I ask you to weigh what I am about to say before you make a ruling on this very important matter. If it is put to you that a Premier of a State, a Minister in a State government, a Prime Minister of this country, or a Minister in the Federal Government has a relative or friend involved in a business undertaking and that those Ministers or heads of state make a decision that leads to the benefit of those relatives or close friends, and that in those circumstances a responsible Minister in this Senate cannot condemn that practice, I would have thought that if you rule that way, Mr President, the processes of open democracy would have been eroded in this Parliament.

—Mr President, speaking to the point of order, I believe Senator Chipp has made a pertinent point about the first part of Senator Chaney's rather serious and sanctimonious point of order. I think the second point Senator Chaney seemed to be making was a point he made in this chamber on a previous occasion since he has been in Opposition, that is, that he is somehow offended by Senator Walsh or other people in this place blackguarding people collectively. I also used to complain about that when in Opposition over and over again, day after day, when Senator Sir John Carrick as Leader of the Government in those days used that tactic every day. As that practice was obviously approved of by Senator Chaney and his colleagues, and obviously no one was going to make any attempt to outlaw it, we decided the best approach was: `If you can't beat them, join them'. If Senator Chaney had been on his feet complaining of such practices in those days I might have had some reason to take him seriously. I certainly do not take him seriously on this occasion, nor do I think this chamber or you, Mr President, should do so.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not uphold Senator Chaney's point of order. Standing order 418 specifically states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House, or of any House of a State Parliament, or against any Statute, unless for the purpose of moving for its repeal, and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

The standing order does not relate to points that are made or matters that are raised against governments generally. I would think that to consider a government as a collective Ministry and to include that within standing order 418 is not the intention of the standing order. I do not think the standing order can be used in that way and I therefore do not uphold the point of order. However, I would appeal to Senator Walsh, as I have appealed before, to remember the refinements of debate in this place and to keep matters away from a near breach of the Standing Orders. I call Senator Walsh.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had finished my answer.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health a question concerning Medicare. I apologise that I have not given him proper notice, knowing that it is not a question related to his portfolio, but it is a serious question to which I would like a considered answer. It may be that he cannot give that answer today. Does the Minister agree that the health insurance system in Australia was or is one of the best in the world? Does the Minister agree that it is under peril because it is being abused unmercifully by a small number of unscrupulous doctors? Does the Minister further agree that he is disturbed, as I am, that when certain medical entrepreneurs get on television and claim that they are going to make $10m out of Medicare for the next year that puts Medicare in danger? Does the Government consider that the elimination of bulk billing, except for pensioners and persons who are in disadvantaged circumstances, would halt this abuse of Medicare virtually overnight?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do think we have a good health insurance system. That does not mean it cannot be improved. Certainly the health insurance scheme is under some stress if medical practitioners, or anyone else in fact, abuses the system. I also agree with Senator Chipp that a small number of medical entrepreneurs in this country seem to have been abusing Medicare, abusing the health insurance scheme. They have been abusing not only Medicare-the public health insurance scheme-but also the private health insurance scheme. They are not only entrepreneurial general practitioners but also entrepreneurs in radiology, pathology and other areas. As I say, they do not necessarily only abuse the public section of that health insurance system; but they can also abuse the private section, and they can abuse it in many ways without being detected because the records are not as good.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chipp made the assumption that by eliminating bulk billing we would solve all those problems. I remind honourable senators that back in 1968-69 a Liberal government realised that things were not well with the health insurance system and initiated an inquiry into that system. In those days we did not have bulk billing as it is known now and similar concerns were around then. Bulk billing has, in fact, got advantages in that it ensures that cost is not a barrier to some low income people in their seeking health care-

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `except for that'.

—I will come to that in a minute. It provides for administrative simplicity, it provides for prompt payment, it provides for very significant administrative changes for both doctors and the health insurance system, and it also has an effect, as it had in Canada, of restricting doctors' fees. It is all very well to say that we will just have bulk billing for low income people or particularly for pensioner beneficiaries and unemployment beneficiaries. We run into very real definitional problems there in that there are people who are not pensioners, or not beneficiaries or low income earners in the work force, but who may have a particular reason for having great difficulty paying their medical bills-for instance, they may have children with recurrent illnesses such as asthma, epilepsy or respiratory illnesses. There is also an assumption in what Senator Chipp said that by removing the capacity to bulk bill for these people somehow all our troubles will be over. They will not be over under those circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: Sure, bulk billing may be abused by a small number of doctors. I do not know whether I can cite the facts exactly, but for instance, in the first six months of 1985-86 compared with the same period in 1984-85 the number of direct bill services increased by about 18 per cent, the number of services per patient for those who were direct billed decreased from 2 per cent to 1.97 per cent while the number of services to patients who were actually billed increased. The number of services per provider increased slightly for those who were direct billed. There was no change for those who billed their patients. There were very marginal changes in the first six months of this year compared with the first six months of last year. The experience under the previous health insurance system was that bulk billed patients were not overserviced to any great degree more than those who were billed directly.

The situation is complicated. There will always be a group of doctors who will rip off the system. We cannot stop that just by getting rid of bulk billing. I point out also that entrepreneurial doctors of the type about whom Senator Chipp is talking are not necessarily all bad. We must ask ourselves why so many people go to such entrepreneurial services. They do because they are open, available and accessible, whereas the doctors whom they visited previously are not. If those entrepreneurial services have the effect that they have had in Sydney of ensuring that doctors' surgeries are open on Saturdays, Sundays and all sorts of times that people need them, in that small regard they may be better. I will get detailed figures from the Minister for Health to demonstrate to Senator Chipp that by wiping out bulk billing we do not just wipe out the abuse of the health insurance system. There are considerable benefits in bulk billing. Some of the best health services in the world are based completely on bulk billing. I suggest that the next time that Senator Chipp is in Western Europe he talks to some of the people of the social democracies there which have health insurance schemes that work very effectively and efficiently.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether he is aware of a proposal by the Brisbane Crematorium to recycle crematorium niches containing the ashes of Australian soldiers who died as a result of their war-caused injuries. Is it true that the Commonwealth accepted responsibility through the Office of Australian War Graves to maintain these memorials in perpetuity? Will the Minister inform the Senate of the steps he has taken to ensure that commemorations to Australia's former soldiers will be maintained and reassure next of kin that their relatives' ashes will not be disturbed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the problem to which Senator Reynolds refers. This matter was first raised in a grievance debate in the other place by the honourable member for Moreton on 1 May. He followed it up with a question without notice to my colleague Mr Holding, who represents me in the other place. As a result of that question I had some inquiries made in respect of the matter that has been raised by Senator Reynolds. I understand that there is a proposal to backdate tenure on the commemoration niches at this crematorium. In other words, unless a further fee is paid, niches will be recycled. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that only last month Messrs Peacock and Tim Fischer put out two Press releases which stirred up a hornet's nest in the veteran community. On a television show they stated that Australian war graves in Libya were under threat by Colonel Gaddafi's regime. They accused me of not being concerned. Of course, I expressed considerable concern about it but I pointed out that the story was a beat-up.

ANSWER.PARA: However, here we have a case where our war graves are threatened in Queensland and not a word has emerged from Mr Fischer in respect of these matters. It would appear that the greatest threat to Australian war graves does not come from overseas situations but here at home in Brisbane where the coalition parties' big business friends, including a former Treasurer of the Queensland National Party, were involved in an attempt to change the situation of war graves in that State. It is their complete subservience to the quick dollar mentality which prompts one to ask: `Where are Messrs Fischer and Peacock in defending Australian war graves in Brisbane against the big business bulldozers of the Queensland National Party?' I pay tribute and give credit to the independence and the moral fibre of the honourable member for Moreton, who is prepared to stand up against this bare-faced opportunism and this outrageous assault upon Australia's war dead by leading lights in the Queensland business community. I say quite categorically to the Senate that my Department will continue to maintain the veterans' niches and memorial plates in the relevant columbarium. I will be instructing my Department to cease negotiations with any crematorium which seeks to backdate tenure and, therefore, exact a further contribution from the Commonwealth Government. I also call on Mr Fischer, who showed such deep concern about a beat-up newspaper story concerning the bulldozing of war graves in Libya, to prevail upon his National Party colleagues in Queensland to ensure that this unthinkable desecration of war graves will not occur in our own country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it true, as implied by the Attorney-General on last night's Four Corners program, that the Government was proposing to initiate an inquiry into the allegations against Mr Justice Murphy? If so, what form was that inquiry to take and why was that inquiry not proceeded with in view of today's statement by the Chief Justice that the High Court of Australia is not conducting any inquiry into nor making any findings on the matters concerning Mr Justice Murphy?

—I think I have said as much as can usefully be said on this subject. The Government was considering certain contingency plans yesterday, depending on what the response of the High Court was yesterday in its meeting that we knew was taking place. In the light of the response the High Court gave, it has become unnecessary, at least for the moment, to proceed with any such contingency planning for the reasons I indicated in my answer to an earlier question.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen an article in the 25 April to 1 May edition of the National Times newspaper entitled `US gets tough with Australia over Nuclear Free Zone'? Does the Minister agree with the assertion contained in the article about the United States Administration's view that Australia's support for the South Pacific nuclear free zone proposal is for internal party consumption rather than a serious commitment to the concept? Does the Minister also agree that the United States Administration's view has come from contact with United States and Australian diplomats in Washington? If the Minister does not agree with these assertions, how does he explain the apparent misconception on the part of the diplomats referred to? Will he outline proposals which the Government has to clarify its position to other governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has seen the article in question. Neither the Minister for Foreign Affairs, nor anyone else in the Government for that matter, agrees with the assertion in the article that the Government's active role in the creation of the South Pacific nuclear free zone was largely, as the article states, `a response to internal party pressures on nuclear issues'. The SPNFZ Treaty is a regional response to long standing and deeply felt concerns about nuclear issues, especially nuclear testing in the region and the dumping of nuclear waste in the oceans of the region, and a desire to keep the region free of major power rivalries involving nuclear weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treaty contains substantive and important provisions on the acquisition, testing and stationing of nuclear explosive devices. Three draft protocols invite the nuclear weapons states to respect the main provisions of the Treaty in regard to their territories within the zone, not to use, or threaten to use, nuclear weapons against parties to the Treaty and not to test nuclear explosives anywhere within the zone. The Treaty has been widely welcomed by the international community as a significant contribution to arms control and disarmament.

The United States Administration has been extensively briefed including by Australian diplomats in Washington, on the substance and intent of the Treaty. Moreover, on 1 October last year senior Australian officials who took part in the negotiation of the treaty thoroughly briefed a wide range of United States agencies on the Treaty and the background to it. The records of the discussions do not in any way support the view expressed in that article that there is any misconception among United States officials as to the origins of the Treaty.

The Government has been informed that the Administration is studying seriously and with an open mind the Treaty and its draft protocols. This was confirmed to the Prime Minister by President Reagan during Mr Hawke's recent visit to Washington. The Government is aware that some agencies within the United States Administration are sceptical about the whole concept of nuclear free zones, but this attitude is a United States perspective and is in no way attributable to the manner in which Australian officials have presented the Treaty.

In addition to the extensive briefing already provided, including formal consultations in February of this year with a delegation of officials from South Pacific countries that drafted the Treaty, which delegation was led by a senior Australian diplomat, there has also been ministerial contact with senior figures in the United States Administration to emphasise, in particular, that the Treaty is fully consistent with Australia's obligations under ANZUS and fully respects the freedom of the seas under inter- national law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery on my left of former Senator Lajovic, a former senator from New South Wales. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend a warm welcome to him upon his return to Canberra.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refers to the ANZUS Treaty and port access. Is the Government aware of the so-called China formula which has allowed visits to Chinese ports by British warships? Could this formula form the basis of resolving the port access problem that exists between the governments of New Zealand and the United States of America?

—The term `China formula' apparently refers to arrangements reached between the Chinese and British governments for a visit to Chinese ports by British warships in the next few months. Chinese policy, like that of New Zealand, is not to permit nuclear weapons to be brought into its ports on visiting ships. Whether those arrangements might provide a precedent for resolving or helping to resolve the port access problem between New Zealand on the one hand and the United States and Britain on the other is not something on which the Australian Government would wish to express a view. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What are the likely economic consequences of the outbreak of coffee rust in Papua New Guinea and what help can Australia offer in fighting that outbreak?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The consequences of the outbreak of coffee rust in Papua New Guinea are very serious indeed. Coffee is Papua New Guinea's major agricultural export earner; 48 per cent of Papua New Guinea rural households produce some coffee, and approximately 75 per cent of the total crop is produced by smallholders. Export earnings from coffee are expected to reach $300m in 1986, of which some $90m can be expected to be received directly by smallholder growers. Perhaps I should say something about the phenomenon of coffee rust. `Coffee rust' is a term used to describe a family of fungus that renders the fruit of affected trees useless for commercial purposes. It spreads very quickly from plant to plant and from region to region. Once rust has taken hold on a plant or plant material it is almost impossible to eradicate short of destroying the material.

ANSWER.PARA: There was an outbreak of this fungus in Papua New Guinea in 1965 which affected a small area of non-commercial coffee. Trees and materials in the affected area were destroyed and the outbreak was eradicated. A new outbreak of rust has been reported in three provinces in Papua New Guinea. Papua New Guinea officials estimate that more than 3,000 hectares, or 12 per cent of smallholder crops, may be affected. Industry representatives estimate that 25 per cent of the 1986 crop may be at risk. The actual fungus probably will not be identified for some months. Clearly widespread preventative spraying would be necessary to prevent its spread. It is not possible on the basis of the present information to estimate fully the final consequences and implications of the outbreak, but the orders of magnitude follow from the figures I have given so far.

As to Australia's response, I indicate on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs that Australia has responded speedily and efficiently in locating and transporting chemicals and equipment required for the Papua New Guinea eradication and control effort that commenced at the weekend. The Natural Disasters Organisation and the Australian Defence Force are to be commended for their efforts. Further assistance of this nature may be necessary. We are also exploring other ways of assisting Papua New Guinea's response to the outbreak. Discussions will be held with our High Commissioner over the next few days. Among the further areas of assistance being explored are the provision of scientific and technical advisers to strengthen Papua New Guinea's own expert staff; advice and assistance on the logistics aspect of the current control spraying campaign; and technical and other support for the education campaign that will need now to be directed at producers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention did not really have to be drawn to the denial coming from across the aisle. I noticed it, and I thought that after 12 years in the Senate I was fairly cynical and hard-bitten, but I must say that I was astounded that the Stalinists across the aisle are attempting to rewrite such recent Australian political and economic history. I quote a few sentences from that book:

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a projected deficit. That is his deficit. You are deliberately misleading the House.
—Go back to writing prospectuses for Patrick Partners. It continues:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . on Monday, 28 February . . . Stone met Howard and gave him firm advice that the projected 1983-84 deficit was about $9,000m . . .

That is almost $10 billion, exactly as I had said. Senator Cook also asked me: How did the 1982 Budget blow out the prospective 1983-84 deficit? There are basically two answers. In 1982-83 on both the outlays and revenues sides there were massive miscalculations, to put a charitable interpretation on it, of the type which blew out the 1982-83 deficit from, in round figures, $1.7 billion to $4.5 billion, or in other words boosted real outlays by more than 8 per cent over those of the previous year or, if one takes account of the fact that there was an additional pay day and pension day in the previous year, boosted real outlays in his Budget over his second last Budget by more than 9 per cent. This is the man who now advocates austerity in government expenditure. Because of the factors I have mentioned there was a higher base for the deficit following the 1982-83 Budget outcome. The other major reason was that the full year cost of the expenditure and taxation changes which had been incorporated in the last Howard Budget, that is, the 1982 Budget, added almost $3 billion more to the deficit. That Budget was brought down by the man who was unquestionably the most irresponsible Treasurer the country has ever had.

Senator Cook also asked me whether there was any similarity between Mr Howard's record in his last year as Treasurer and his more recent record as Leader of the Opposition. There is, indeed, an alarming similarity in that he displays the same propensity for fiscal irresponsibility as Leader of the Opposition as he exhibited as Treasurer. I cite just two examples. They have also made-principally, in this case, Mr Howard-promises on the taxation revenue side of the Budget which would cost revenue up to $5 billion. The cumulative effect of the fulfilment of those promises, if any government were to introduce them, added to the present deficit would produce a deficit of about $12 billion in the next financial year which, as a proportion of gross domestic product, would be still somewhat lower, however, than the prospective deficit which this Government inherited from Mr Howard in the autumn of 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Baume says, bulk billing is not an essential part of Medicare. It just happens to be a very desirable part of Medicare and a desirable part of the health insurance system. ANSWER.PARA: Under the private health insurance system in this country patients make claims for repayment or payment to doctors. The items are coded and have numbers against them. —I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy and it concerns a proposal that spent fuel rods from the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor will be shipped to the United States of America in June. How many fuel rods will be in each shipment? How much plutonium is in each fuel rod? How many shipments will go this year? What is the total cost of each shipment? Has the option of storing spent fuel rods in Australia been considered and what would be the cost of this? Finally, what proposals are there about what to do with the highly enriched uranium that will emerge from reprocessed fuel rods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question not being appropriate to be put on notice, I will do my best to answer it. The Government is seeking to send back to the United States of America for reprocessing a total of about 450 fuel rods. So far as each shipment size is concerned, as the design and approval procedures for the container which will be used to transport the high flux atomic reactor spent fuel elements to the United States have not yet been completed, a definite capacity has not been decided, but will be in the range of 100 to 120 elements. The 450 spent fuel elements are estimated to contain about one-quarter of a kilogram of plutonium, with each fuel element containing slightly more than half a gram. It is unlikely that arrangements will be finalised in time for shipments of spent fuel to commence this year. It is expected to be early next year before the first shipment will take place. I am not able to release details of the cost of each shipment as this information is confidential to the commercial interests involved. The relevant contracts, in any event, are still being finalised and when this is done the overall cost certainly will be made public.

ANSWER.PARA: The option of continuing to store the spent fuel at Lucas Heights was carefully considered by the Government. As almost all available space for fuel storage at Lucas Heights is currently full, however, further fuel storage space would have had to be constructed or else the HIFAR shut down. Construction of interim additional storage was estimated to cost over $400,000 but was not considered to be a desirable option by the Government as this would only defer the decision on eventual long term disposal of spent fuel. I should say also that the disposal of spent fuel is consistent with the Government's nuclear non-proliferation objectives by reducing the inventory of highly enriched uranium stored at Lucas Heights. Final disposal in a deep repository in Australia would be prohibitively expensive, costing in the order of tens of millions of dollars, and would require the establishment of processing facilities, contrary to the Government's commitment against further stages of the nuclear fuel cycle in Australia.

No decisions have been made on the final use of the highly enriched uranium to be recovered from the spent fuel elements. However, under the Australia-United States safeguards arrangements this material will be available only for peaceful uses as designated by Australia. In particular this material could be used, of course, as further fuel for the HIFAR reactor.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I have had a number of representations from the Nganampa Health Commission out of Alice Springs concerning the problems of education for Aboriginal people in the communities of northern South Australia. What capacity does the Commonwealth Government have to address educational needs of this sort and what, if any, initiatives have been taken by the Government to tackle this and similar problems of education for isolated or disadvantaged students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent years the conventional form of assistance for education of young Aboriginal students living in remote areas has been by way of payment of the Aboriginal secondary grants scheme, an allowance which pays for travelling and school expenses, books and other incidental items. Although that has provided educational opportunities for some young people in isolated areas, it has by no means been successful for all or even a majority of young Aboriginal people living in isolated areas. Problems of homesickness, cultural shock, inappropriate school environments and so forth have meant that many young Aboriginal people have dropped out of their boarding schools and returned home to their communities at an age below school leaving age and have had no constructive activities available for them.

ANSWER.PARA: In recognition of this, last year the Federal Government announced a $1m pilot program for developing remote area educational programs suitable for adolescent Aboriginal students, and in particular for those who did not wish to go away to school or whose families did not wish them to go out of the community and who intended-as far as they could be sure at that age-to stay in their communities and, therefore, required a more vocationally oriented-community oriented type of education. The $1m is being spread amongst Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory to fund, I think it will be, half a dozen projects. One of the projects in the Northern Territory, for example, is a mobile educational unit which will take vocational education suitable for Aboriginal adolescents into some of the remote communities. There is also a program developed in South Australia for its remote areas. At the same time we are making increased efforts to train teachers, either Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal but preferably Aboriginal, in a way that will enable them to teach successfully in these very remote areas.

Senator Crowley will probably be aware that a South Australian college in her State is a leader in this respect. It has a very successful program whereby teachers from the remote area communities-that is, members of those communities-are trained to teach mainly on the job in their own communities. They are not required to leave their communities for extended periods. They are able to carry out most of their training in their communities with the support of staff from the South Australian college, which means that the problem of cultural gaps, cultural inappropriateness and so forth is overcome. In fact, in recognition of the South Australian college's development in this regard that project has now become one of our Government's key centres for teaching and research; that is, it receives additional funds to enable it to develop its work at a very high standard and in a way which, we hope, will enable it to be a model for teacher training for Aboriginal teachers for remote communities throughout those States which have such remote communities.

It will probably be a few months before we can start evaluating the pilot project, but all of the relevant States and the Northern Territory have co-operated with the guidelines developed by me in consultation with the National Aboriginal Education Committee. I hope, and expect, this new development will mean that Aboriginal students living in remote areas will not face nothing after primary education, which is the circumstances they were once in, and are still in in a number of places in Australia-that they will have the opportunity to undertake some useful community oriented and culturally appropriate education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senators Chipp and Sanders asked me about the quantity of depleted uranium resulting from enrichment of Australian uranium in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, on behalf of our uranium customer countries, that is now located in France. I undertook to give them an answer today and I now do so. Perhaps I should say at the outset that the definition of depleted uranium, which is widely misunderstood, not least by the Australian Democrats, is uranium in which the content of the fissile isotope uranium 235 is less than the 0.7 per cent normally found in natural uranium. While depleted uranium has some reactor uses as a blanket for neutron capture in fast breeder reactors, as was said yesterday, it is perhaps more familiarly known for its non-reactor uses, taking advantage of its great density-for example, yacht ballasts, counter weights in large aircraft control systems, and in shielding for radiological purposes. The situation as to quantum is this: The Australian Safeguards Office has advised me that there are 159,991 kilograms of this material presently stored in France. That amount largely reflects I guess, the volume of enrichment activity that is being carried out there. Only two countries have passed on Australian origin nuclear material to the USSR on the all-in all-out principle-Finland and Sweden. The 159,991 kilograms in France to which I have just referred is, I am advised, all Finnish material sent on there after it has been returned to Finland from the USSR. Tails derived from Australian origin nuclear material enriched in the USSR on behalf of Sweden are all, in fact, now in the United Kingdom. I have some further information about the procedures that are involved in tracking this material. I suggest it might suit the convenience of the Senate if I were to seek incorporation of those paragraphs in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.

—Very well. Under Australia's bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements the Australian Safeguards Office maintains inventories of Australian origin nuclear material as it moves through the nuclear fuel cycle. Procedures to enable this to be done are provided for in the administrative arrangements to the agreements which establish a system of records and reports by which the Australian Safeguards Office is kept informed of international transfers of Australian origin nuclear material. This is so whether the transfer is between two of Australia's bilateral partners or between one partner and the USSR, in whose territory the Government has agreed that AONM may be processed on an all-in, all-out basis.

ANSWER.PARA: The administrative arrangements also provide for periodic summary reports of inventories of AONM to be exchanged between ASO and its counterpart organisations. These reports provide the basis for periodic reconciliation of accounts kept by ASO with those kept by its counterparts, defining the amounts of nuclear material and nuclear items subject to Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements. The way in which the Australian Safeguards Office accounts for Australian uranium is clearly set out in its 1984-85 annual report which I recently tabled in Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I also have a reply to Senator Hill's question asked of me yesterday about United Kingdom and New Zealand intelligence. Again, I think it might suit the convenience of the Senate if I were to incorporate the reply in Hansard, and I seek leave accordingly.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.

—I remind you, Mr President, that I am normally requested by Senator Chaney to incorporate these matters-I have been on a number of occasions in the past. I mention that for the record, and I will now proceed to give the answer that I promised to Senator Hill. The absence of a New Zealand representative from meetings of the Joint Intelligence Committee in London relates to the difficulties that are associated with the attendance at those meetings of the United States of America representatives. As far as we are aware, this exclusion does not affect the provision to New Zealand of intelligence from United Kingdom sources.

ANSWER.PARA: The responsibility for passing United Kingdom defence intelligence to New Zealand lies with the United Kingdom authorities. To the extent that the Australian defence intelligence output contains United Kingdom based information, there is no restriction by the United Kingdom on its transmission to New Zealand. In general, the Government will continue to abide by the long established principle of not passing intelligence obtained from one country to any third country without the prior consent of the originator.

With regard to the provision of Australian sourced material to New Zealand, Australia will continue to provide New Zealand with access to material of Australian origin under stated release conditions that existed prior to New Zealand's present difficulties with the United Kingdom. The Prime Minister, in a statement to the House of Representatives on 27 February 1985 about the New Zealand-United States dispute, said:

. . . whatever the outcome Australia will maintain active intelligence co-operation with New Zealand based, I insist, on material of Australian origin and in that way reflect the very close bilateral relationship between the two countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Sheil asked me for some information regarding a purchase by the Chisholm Institute of Technology in Victoria of a shopping centre. I have available the information sought in Senator Sheil's question and I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.

—Funds are provided to the States for institutions such as the Chisholm Institute of Technology under the terms of the States grants legislation. This requires institutions to provide the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission with statements by qualified auditors certifying that Commonwealth grants have been expended in accordance with the provisions of the legislation. In addition, institutions are required to provide an annual statistical return to the CTEC which includes details on expenditure patterns across the range of activities undertaken by them. I am advised that the Chisholm Institute of Technology has complied with the requirements of the legislation. However, in addition to receiving direct financial support from the Commonwealth, many institutions have access to other sources of funding, such as interest earnings, bequests or through links with industry. The Government encourages institutions to pursue appropriate alternative sources of income.

ANSWER.PARA: As I indicated previously, I asked for the matter of the purchase of the Caulfield Plaza shopping centre by the Chisholm Institute of Technology to be investigated. The CTEC has sought advice from the appropriate body in Victoria-the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission. Advice given by VPSEC indicates that: Firstly, the funds used to purchase the site were provided entirely from accumulated monies generated by the Institute's extraneous activities. No government funds were involved. Secondly, no government funds have been used for servicing costs. These are met from rental and lease income from the tenants of the Plaza. Thirdly, staff involved in managing and operating the Plaza are paid from extraneous funds. Fourthly, no Commonwealth funds have been used to manage or to assist with staffing of the Plaza complex. Fifthly, plans for the transfer of the general management of the Plaza to external property managers are well advanced.

As I understand it, the Institute decided to purchase the shopping centre site in view of its proximity to the Caulfield campus. Over the longer term this purchase will provide the institution with the opportunity to expand on to the site and it will therefore ensure that the institution retains the capacity to expand in the future.

The Government encourages institutions to undertake activities which will enhance their flexibility in meeting the needs of their students. Activities such as that undertaken by the Chisholm Institute deserve the support of governments and I have no intention of reducing Commonwealth funding to the institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1986 continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sitting of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation not otherwise being amended. Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routine administration. None of the amendments made by the Bill has any significant financial impact. Many of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill, I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more noteworthy changes included in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952

The amendment will clarify the Commonwealth's ability to impose charges to recover costs incurred in providing maintenance and development grants for aerodromes owned by local authorities under the aerodrome local ownership program.
Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980

The Act implements the agreed measures for the conservation of Antarctic fauna and flora agreed amongst the states parties to the Antarctic Treaty. The Act enables permits to be granted, subject to certain conditions, for scientific activities to be carried out in areas designated as specially protected areas. As the Act now stands, a permit cannot be granted for the use of aircraft in specially protected areas.

This restriction on the use of aircraft places an unnecessary restraint on the research which can be undertaken. It has also created considerable logistical difficulties and hazards for scientists engaged in field studies in specially protected areas, particularly where the area is an island. These problems could be obviated by limited and carefully controlled use of helicopters. The purpose of the proposed amendments to the Act is to enable this to occur.

The landing or driving of aircraft in specially protected areas is consistent with the agreed measures for the conservation of Antarctic fauna and flora. It is intended that permits granted for the use of aircraft will be subject to whatever conditions are necessary for the responsible management of the specially protected areas in accordance with the spirit of the agreed measures. Wherever possible the conditions applied would be based on existing specially protected area management plans.
Archives Act 1983

The amendment ensures that one of the original intentions of the Archives Act is achieved. This intention, in line with a long-established convention prior to the proclamation of the Act, is to provide privileged access to Commonwealth records not otherwise available for public access, including records not in the open access period. Regulations made pursuant to this amendment will prescribe the classes of persons to whom such access, called `special access', may be granted. They will also prescribe the classes of records which, in accordance with arrangements approved by the Prime Minister may be made available. At present only the purposes for which Commonwealth records may be made available to a person under special access arrangements may be prescribed by regulation.
Audit Act 1901

The purpose of these amendments is to facilitate the legislative reforms necessary to effect the initiatives of the Government with respect to the auditing of statutory marketing authorities-SMAs. Under these reforms, statutory marketing authorities are being provided with the option, through their enabling legislation, of appointing a private sector auditor to undertake the audit of their accounts. However, where a company auditor is appointed, the Auditor-General is to retain a discretionary power to conduct any of his usual audit functions under the Act having regard to the need to avoid unnecessary duplication of audits.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amdendment Bill 1986 is to amend the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 to provide increased flexibility for the Corporation in the exercise of its commercial and financial responsibilities. This will involve the removal of many of the present requirements for ministerial approval of what might be called the day to day operations of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. The amendments provided for in this Bill complement the restructuring of the statutory arrangements for the meat and livestock industry which this Government commenced during 1984 and continued in 1985. Previous changes have streamlined the operation of the industry's statutory organisations and have resulted in more appropriate mechanisms for ensuring the accountability of the AMLC through corporate planning and an annual general meeting. In accordance with policy relating to primary industry statutory marketing authorities, as set out in the recent Government policy statement, the present amendments provide for more flexibility in the AMLC's operations and places reliance on the corporate plan and annual general meeting to ensure appropriate accountability to both Parliament and industry.

The amendments in this Bill are supported by the industry and follow on from the invitation of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to industry to identify areas where administrative procedures could be rationalised to benefit the industry. The current amendments should provide the AMLC with a more effective capacity to address the marketing challenges facing the industry now and in the future. The amendments will not impose any new cost burdens on the Commonwealth and some savings may result to the AMLC through streamlined administration and financial management procedures.

The Bill provides for the removal of the requirement for specific prior ministerial approval of purchase of property over $100,000 by the AMLC, purchase and sale for export of meat and livestock, the terms and conditions for employment of staff and of consultants and the operation by the AMLC of facilities and services in connection with the marketing or sale of meat and livestock. In order to increase the flexibility of the Corporation's financial operations it is proposed to remove the requirement for ministerial approval of borrowings by the Corporation with the exception that where the AMLC wishes to borrow in excess of $5m in any financial year the approval of the Treasurer will be required. The Corporation will be empowered to lend money in connection with the performance of its functions. In accordance with the commercial principles behind these changes the Bill will remove the option currently available to the Corporation of securing a Commonwealth guarantee for its borrowings. At the same time the Corporation will be empowered to exercise its own discretion in deciding on the bank or banks with which it will maintain accounts and in deciding the nature and form of the investments in which reserves and other monies not immediately required are held.

In accordance with the new statutory marketing authority guidelines, the Bill provides the Corporation with the option of using a commercial auditor in place of the Auditor-General. The appointment of a commercial auditor will require a resolution at an annual general meeting of the Corporation and can only proceed where the Auditor-General reports favourably to the Minister on the suitability of the proposed auditor. The appointment must also be agreed to by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. The Auditor-General shall retain full auditing responsibilities where no commercial auditor has been appointed. In addition the Auditor-General's power to independently audit the Corporation and report to the Minister is to continue. The Government has considered it appropriate to provide licenced exporters of meat and livestock with the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions by the AMLC to make orders to transfer, cancel or surrender export quota allocations made under section 16j of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act.

As honourable senators will have noted from the statutory marketing authority policy statement, it is the Government's intention that the Minister for Primary Industry have a general power of direction over the activities of all Commonwealth primary industry statutory marketing authorities. This power is seen as a reserve power to be used in exceptional circumstances and accordingly strict provisions regarding the publication of such directions are included in the Bill. Directions under this amendment must be given in writing and then only after consultations between the Minister and the Chairman of the AMLC. The directions must be notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and tabled in both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days of issue. The Corporation will be required to report all such directions in its annual report together with a statement of their effects on AMLC operations.

The opportunity is also being taken in the Bill to clarify the power of the Corporation to be involved in the provision of services or facilities in connection with the sale and marketing of Australian meat and livestock. In this regard the Corporation is developing facilities to take advantage of computer technology consistent with its function to promote the sale of Australian meat and livestock. The reforms incorporated in this Bill should enable the Corporation to further improve on the effectiveness of its role in the marketing of Australian meat and livestock. They will enhance the statutory structure provided for this most important industry by removing unnecessary impediments to its commercial effectiveness. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name relating to Superannuation (Salary) Regulations (Amendment), pursuant to the notice of intention I gave earlier today. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation (Salary) Regulations (Amendment) are regulations made by the Minister for Finance under the Superannuation Act 1976. They are complex machinery provisions designed to provide the rules whereby certain payments of shift allowance are, or are not, to be treated as salary for the purpose of computing entitlements to superannuation. Prior to the regulations it was thought that shift allowance had to be paid continuously for 12 months prior to retirement before it could be counted as salary. Thus, it was thought that a shift worker who worked a day time shift that does not attract any allowance would not be entitled to include many months of shift allowance payments as part of his or her salary for superannuation purposes on retirement. The harshness of this interpretation appears manifest and eventually the Administrative Appeals Tribunal held that shift allowance formed part of `salary' in the ordinary sense of the word and the regulations were not relevant to determining what constituted salary. The Federal Court of Australia rejected an appeal against this decision lodged by the Commissioner for Superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the new open-ended nature of the definition of salary it has been necessary to make regulations to regulate the treatment of shift allowance as salary for superannuation purposes. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Committee can have no quarrel with these new rules on the grounds of their policy, or their basic substance. However, within the complex structure of the regulations there is conferred upon `a person authorised by the Commissioner' a power to take a class of discretionary decisions which could adversely affect a person's entitlement to superannuation.

If a contributor became a shift worker during the 12 months period ending on his or her death or retirement, and shift allowance was paid regularly during this final period, entitlement to have those payments included as salary for superannuation purposes is dependent on the issue of a certificate by an authorised person. This authorised person must first be of the opinion that there is a likelihood that shift allowance would have been regularly paid during a full 12 months had the employee not died or retired. Unlike every other administrative decision that can be taken in connection with superannuation, this decision of an authorised officer is not subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Yet this decision is no less important than other reviewable superannuation decisions. It is taken by the very same officials who take other reviewable decisions.

An adverse or arbitrary decision can have serious financial effects on a contributor or his family. Clearly, because of the risk that unfair and harsh decisions can be made there ought to be a right to challenge an adverse decision of an authorised person. There ought to be a right of appeal to the AAT against the personal `opinion' of that official as to what is and what is not `likely' on all the facts of a particular case. Since June 1979 at the latest it has been known that this class of important discretionary decision is not subject to appeal to the AAT. It appears, and the Committee accepts, that there was nothing deliberate or calculated about the absence of review rights in this instance.

The problem was caused by a drafting oversight. In 1979 the AAT in McLinden's case held that this class of authorised persons' decisions was not reviewable because only decisions of the Commissioner and his or her delegates are reviewable. The Commissioner could not provide that his or her delegates, rather than authorised officers, should take these particular decisions because under section 25 of the Superannuation Act the Commissioner cannot delegate powers conferred under regulations. He or she can only delegate powers conferred under the Act. Thus, there was an oversight in the otherwise protective scheme of appeal rights. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal formally and publicly identified the flaw in June 1979.

In 1980 the Administrative Review Council recommended that it be remedied by expanding the definition in the Act of `reviewable decisions' to include decisions of authorised persons. In 1980 the then Minister for Finance accepted this recommendation. However, it was not implemented. In 1981 the Administrative Review Council again recommended expanding the definition. In its fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth reports to date the Administrative Review Council has repeated its recommendation. It was hoped it would be implemented in one of a number of major superannuation amendment Bills over the past seven years. However, these Bills all came to grief even before they were introduced into the Parliament for reasons completely unrelated to this question of providing proper appeal rights. Since 1979 there have been, as I understand it, 10 Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills which are, by definition, designed to cater for machinery amendments and oversights of this kind. Had there been within the Department of Finance any serious commitment to providing for review of administrative decisions, it is to be expected that in seven years officials would have commandeered some space in one of those statute law Bills to make the amendment.

If there had been within the Department any concern for possible injustice or harshness, this solution would have been used as soon as the first superannuation amendment Bill had failed to make progress. However, where officials' decisions are not legally subject to review of the kind available before the AAT, there is a tendency for them to become peremptory, and possibly capricious. The belief develops that the decisions need not be subject to review because, having been made by the class of officials concerned, they are invariably and intrinsically correct.

Part of this Committee's remit is to try to persuade Ministers and officials to accept independent appeals in order to underwrite the quality of important administrative decisions. The Committee has asked the present Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in view of the long delays which have characterised the history of this matter, to make an amendment to section 154 of the Superannuation Act and place that amendment in the statute law Bill currently before the Parliament. Since that Bill has already left the House of Representatives, the Minister has agreed to amend section 25 of the Act in a proposed superannuation amendment Bill to be introduced in the Budget sittings, and later to amend the regulations to bring the errant class of decisions under the umbrella of review. He has undertaken that, if that Bill fails to pass, he will seek an amendment to section 154 to be placed in the Budget statute law Bill. The Committee has accepted this undertaking and respectfully commends the Minister for his decisions to act to provide for adequate review rights in this matter. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the correspondence relating to this matter.
