I had commented that in my State of Western Australia some 1,698 projects had been undertaken, creating 9,197 jobs. A total of $100.3m has been spent on those projects. When the Western Australian figures are compared with the national figures, it can be seen that Western Australia has got its fair share of the total funds. The national figures involve expenditure in excess of $1 billion, over 100,000 jobs created, and over 18,200 projects completed or undertaken. The average term of employment for those participating in community employment program projects in Western Australia is 50 weeks. The figure proves that the CEP is meeting its target of reaching the long term unemployed. The figure of 50 weeks is lower than that of Tasmania or Queensland. The average figure in those States was 69 weeks and 54 weeks respectively. Perhaps the Western Australian figure could be interpreted as being a further indication of the dramatic improvement in the Western Australian economy since the election of the Burke Labor Government in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: Further proof of the value of the CEP and how its targets are being achieved is provided in figures on the participation rates of special groups. Female participation rate targets largely have been achieved. On projects other than jobs on local roads, women comprise 43 per cent of participants to date. That rate is now in the region of 50 per cent so far for 1985-86. On Jolor projects women's participation rates rose from 8 per cent in 1983-84 to 25 per cent so far in this financial year. Significant increases in the participation rates of other special groups-for example, migrants with English language difficulties, Aboriginals and the disabled-have been recorded and are greater than the representation of these groups in CEP registers.

The CEP has gone a long way towards achieving its objectives. It has been effective in creating over 100,000 jobs and has been efficient in doing so. Its cost effectiveness can be measured in a number of ways. The following are but some examples. Seventy-six per cent of all CEP funds, over $1 billion, is spent on labour. The cost to the Commonwealth of each individual job of six months duration is $9,892. Perhaps the best indicator of the CEP's efficiency is that its administrative costs amount to only 3 per cent of the CEP budget. The CEP was designed as a job creation program and as such has proved to be eminently successful. The community at large has also benefited from the program. The benefits have been considerable through projects involving community services and facilities, road upgrading, parks and gardens, sports, recreation and tourism facilities, environment enhancement and arts and heritage.

Previous speakers have identified some of the projects and their costs. I am tempted to repeat the details of projects that I am aware of in the area with which I am most familiar-Wanneroo in Western Australia where I live-but in the interests of time I will resist the temptation. The only comment I make is that the local council of the Shire of Wanneroo, now the City of Wanneroo, was slow to recognise the value of the CEP. Some would even say that the Council was reluctant to involve itself in any way with the CEP in the very beginning. The hesitancy shown by the Council was eventually overcome thanks to the very good work done by local State and Federal members of parliament.

The residents of the City of Wanneroo now enjoy a large number of recreation facilities that they would otherwise not have enjoyed had it not been for the CEP. The work at the Whitford Nodes, the nature trail surrounding Lake Joondalup and the major planting of Australian wild flowers in the median strip of Wanneroo Road are only a few examples of the many millions of dollars of expenditure within the city boundaries. I commend the City Council for its albeit late but very useful involvement in the CEP. I particularly mention for commendation the Mayor of Wanneroo, Councillor Nick Trandos, under whose stewardship the Council's participation in various projects ensured that money was spent in the most effective and economic way available.

I also mention a further project in which another City of Wanneroo councillor is involved. This project, the CINARMY farm project, is designed to involve mentally retarded people in a market garden. It is well on the way to being a most rewarding and valuable experience for a small minority of the population that is often the first to feel the knife edge of economic downturn. The farm project received a CEP grant of $120,000 and has been in operation for some 15 months. According to Councillor Sybil Roberts, it is well on the way to becoming an economically viable long term project providing meaningful employment and activity for a number of disadvantaged and often forgotten people.

As distinct from some Opposition speakers, I have sought to be positive in my contribution to this debate. It is a disappointment that some of the Opposition speakers, whilst saying they supported the Bill, sought, perhaps unconsciously, to discredit the CEP and certain projects that were conducted under it. I hope that this negativeness will not serve to undermine the continued effectiveness of the CEP. I hope that the trade unions as well as political parties such as the Liberal Party of Australia will continue to apply for CEP funding.

I close my speech by repeating and elaborating on a point made by my fellow Western Australian colleague in this place, Senator Peter Cook, earlier in the debate. Senator Cook made the point that criticisms of individual projects are really criticisms of the relevant State consultative committees that have the task of assessing project applications against agreed principles and priorities. Formal applications for projects are made in the first instance to the CEP secretariats where Commonwealth and State officers determine the viability of projects against established criteria set down in the program guidelines. Proposals which meet these criteria are then passed on to the State consultative committees which have the task of comparatively assessing project applications against agreed priorities.

These broad-based committees comprise representatives of Commonwealth and State or Territory governments, trade unions, local government and community group organisations. This representation on the committees ensures that projects recommended for funding reflect community and target group interests. The consultative committees make recommendations for formal joint approval by State or Territory Ministers and the Commonwealth Minister's delegates. In all cases only those projects which meet CEP guidelines are recommended for approval.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT UNDERWRITING AMENDMENT BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Amendment Bill 1986 and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 both concern the export of Australian apples and pears and they have the support of the Opposition. The Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Act was introduced by a Liberal-National Party Government in 1981 to guarantee growers a minimum return by the Commonwealth when the prices received fell below the average achieved in previous years. The Act was to apply to the production of apples and pears during the 1981 to 1985 export seasons. The legislation provided a very much more expedient scheme than the previous system of stabilisation it replaced in that it did not shield producers from the market realities. Instead, it gave the industry insurance against sharp downturns in price without obscuring longer term market trends. Payouts were made when the average export return was less than the underwritten price.

SPEECH.PARA: The Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Amendment Bill proposes that the underwriting scheme be extended for a further five years and makes several amendments. For example, the floor price is to be dropped from 95 per cent to 85 per cent of the average return, but on the average of the best three of the preceding four years rather than the average of the four preceding years. While a number of growers may be disappointed in the floor price reduction, the ability to take the average of the best three years rather than the average of all four years is much more just to all the producers. Payouts in a low price season will not be limited by a preceding bad year. The underwriting scheme is an attempt to level out the peaks and troughs within the industry and to ensure that, should there be an unexpected fall in the value of apples and pears sold overseas, producers will not immediately be forced out of business. In fact, there has been only one instance when the Government has had to provide assistance under this scheme. That was in 1981, when the Commonwealth paid $4.8m to the industry.

The other proposed amendments to the Act are that the scheme should now apply to forward sales, which are all sales made prior to shipment, and at risk sales, which relate to produce shipped before sale. It is argued that without such an inclusion the underwriting scheme given to the apple and pear industry is not meaningful. I believe that the incorporation of these clauses in the Bill is particularly significant. Of Australia's apple and pear sales, a sizable proportion fall into the category of forward and at risk sales. Indeed, the majority of Tasmanian apple sales are classified as at risk transactions. Therefore, it is most important to the industry that these amendments be accepted.

The export of apples and pears in the 1985-86 season is estimated to total $61m. While the apple and pear industry accounts for only about 2 per cent of Australia's gross rural product, given the present state of our economy the contribution of this industry cannot be overlooked. In the last season the export of fresh apples amounted to 30,000 tonnes-a rise of 2,000 tonnes on the previous season. The 1985 crop was the largest since 1979. However, competition in the world market has increased significantly, with Australia losing much of its comparative advantages. Countries such as New Zealand, South Africa and some South American nations have made the successful export of Australian produce all the more restricted. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has pointed out the uncertainty surrounding export levels.

Furthermore, conditions created by the existing economic climate in Australia mean that our apple and pear industries are fighting uphill battles. Along with our other export industries, these industries have to cope with an inflation rate which is well above that of other exporting countries, the continued loss of millions of dollars from the primary industry budget since 1983 and Australia's inflexible wages policy and excessive regulation, which because of transport and export licensing fees limit our markets. These have all been impediments to the industry.

The Government's inaction over a plant variety rights scheme also places Australian apple and pear producers at a great disadvantage in relation to their competitors. Again, I challenge the Government and ask it to take up the recommendations of the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania that Australia should proceed with a plant variety rights scheme. Unfortunately, the problems will not go away. In fact, they could even worsen for Australia in the world market.

The apple and pear industry was once the life blood of the Tasmanian economy. While Tasmania can no longer lay claim to being the primary apple producing State, it is still very much concerned with this industry, particularly in the south of the State. In the past the State has had to battle with special problems which have disadvantaged Tasmanian growers; for example, the problems of cold storage, containerised shipping and rigid shipping schedules that cannot always be met by producers who have to cope with seasonal variations. The recent strike affecting the Australian National Line prevented packaging for apple exports reaching the State and thus threw out export schedules. Given the uncertainty surrounding export levels and the trying conditions facing Australian apple and pear producers, the need for the proposed export underwriting Bill is quite clear.

The purpose of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill 1986 is to amend the relevant sections of the Act dating back to 1973. At present apple and pear exporters cannot operate without a licence. Licences are issued by the Minister for Primary Industry on the recommendation of the Corporation and are subject to eligibility criteria such as financial standing and marketing experience. The amendments put forward in the legislation before us today will remove the Minister from the day to day administration and make the Corporation solely responsible for the issue of licences. It also provides for periodic review of export performance of licence holders. As a way of improving declining market performance the Corporation will implement a policy to restrict the number of export licence holders. This is an effort to achieve greater co-ordination of export activity and it is to be in consultation with the industry. Unsuccessful licence applicants will have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Opposition agrees that the reduction in the number of export licences may act to improve the terms to growers.

It must be noted that the restriction of licences will not offer exporters exclusive access to markets. That is, the licence does not gain a value of its own purely because of this restriction. For example, a grower does not need a licence in order to export because that grower can take advantage of making his fruit available to overseas markets by having the fruit exported on his behalf by any exporter of his choice. However, the Corporation, by pursuing a policy of licence restriction, will be better able to guarantee a quality product on the overseas market. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has given an assurance that the implementation of the policy to rationalise the number of exporters will be gradual so as to avoid adjustment problems within the industry.

The Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill also requires the Corporation to undertake corporate planning. The Opposition supports this initiative as it also should improve the operation of the Corporation and its accountability to industry and government. The long term performance of the Corporation can only be assisted by these measures. I believe that the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Amendment Bill and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill will be of benefit to the apple and pear industry and they therefore have our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Amendment Bill and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill have the support of the Australian Democrats. I would like to make some brief comments with regard to the Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Amendment Bill. The situation in agro-politics today is that we will not hear very much about this Bill, because it improves the conditions with regard to apple and pear growers. Doubtless those people in the industry who do not wish to say anything in favour of a government when it improves conditions, but rather wish constantly to harp on conditions that are not good and where government has failed, will not raise the issues that here there has been extensive discussion with the industry, that the items here are very much the type of items for which the industry was looking, or that the final result in this Bill goes much beyond the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations and the previous situation with regard to the underwriting.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is to be commended for this initiative and for the way it has come up with a package that will be supportive of the industry. In particular I refer to the fact that the legislation provides for picking three out of the best four years. That seems to me to be very useful in terms of any industry because it gives a closer approximation to the type of support that is needed by leaving out the bad season or the downturn season so that the best three years are able to provide the level of support at 85 per cent in the subsequent years if necessary.

With regard to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill, the Democrats do not have any major concerns. However, we have one concern with regard to the powers that the Corporation will have. The Corporation will be solely responsible for the administration of policy, particularly with regard to determining the issue of licences. I have some concern with this, not because of anything that the Apple and Pear Corporation has done but because of what some other corporations have done. I refer particularly to the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, which has established monopoly operations with regard to foreign markets. It seems to me to be totally in opposition to the best interests of our primary industry that we should allow any corporation to move to the point where it may decide that it will issue only one licence to export to any particular country. While ultimately that might be seen to be beneficial, so that in an export market there is not competition of one Australian company against another whereby one company may seek to bid down the price of a product, I believe that in the long run such monopolistic operations will stymie the development of new markets and will prevent the expansion of the markets to which the monopoly is given.

I believe that there are very real cases in terms of the Dried Fruits Corporation where that is the case. I instance India, where there is the possibility of expansion of markets but where markets are not being expanded at the moment as a direct result of the monopolistic licensing policies of the Corporation. I believe that in general a reasonably competitive operation is desirable. The normal arguments that one would use against monopolies can be used against monopolies in these situations. They become lazy and basically have the opportunity of writing a cheque without doing very much work, because there is no competition in terms of the provision of products packaging or alternative sale arrangements. The status quo prevails, which ultimately is detrimental to the expansion of our markets in overseas countries. I hope that the Corporation, when it is given these powers to solely determine the issuing of licences, will not go to that extent. I am heartened in some way by the retention of the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. However, I am not at all sure that that appeal will be sufficient in terms of overturning any particular application.

I am concerned also about the way in which the Apple and Pear Corporation may use these powers, which are almost identical to the powers of the Dried Fruits Corporation. For example, I would be critical of the Dried Fruits Corporation with regard to the way it has imposed an impost by saying that one needs a licence before one can purchase the commodity and that unless one purchases the commodity one cannot have a licence. The Corporation has managed to sew up the whole thing and made it tighter than a drum, and I believe that the Government needs to look closely at what is happening in terms of that particular market. While the Democrats generally support giving the Corporation this flexibility with regard to the issuing of licences and the ability to operate in a way that will enhance the market, I simply raise a word of caution that there are some so-called enhancements of the market by the establishment of monopolies which I believe ultimately will be detrimental to the market.

However, by those comments I do not wish to take away from the support of the Democrats for the initiatives of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in this regard and for the constructive and purposeful work that he and his Department have put into the new underwriting scheme. We hope that this scheme, similar to the underwriting scheme which has gone before, will need to be used only very rarely. We hope that the industry will be buoyant in each of its subsequent five seasons for which this legislation will run. We hope that, when we come back to look at this legislation at the end of that time, unlike Senator Watson we will not have to refer to its having had to be used on at least one occasion. Let us hope that it does not have to be used on any occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Oil Comp- anies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill 1986, which provides oil companies with a very legitimate compensation for stock losses suffered by them as a result of government regulations and policies which were in place when oil prices fell so rapidly earlier this year. The Opposition is concerned, however, that the oil companies will not be fully compensated, and that the Government will continue to pass the cost of its policies of oil market regulation on to consumers and to the oil industry. In summary, the Opposition takes the view that government regulation has placed the oil industry in a cost-price squeeze and has forced oil refiners to suffer stock losses.

SPEECH.PARA: Under normal market conditions oil companies would have been able to limit stock losses by delaying their stock purchases and delaying price reductions on sales. However, the compulsory allocation system for the purchasing of oil and the price controls imposed by the Government under its policies prevent this normal commercial operation. These stock losses were incurred in January and February this year. The oil price fell dramatically in the middle of January, but no adjustment for oil prices was made by the Government until 1 March, by which time the oil companies had had to continue to uplift Australian crude oil at prices which were far in excess of the world price. Suddenly, on 1 March, the Government adjusted those prices to something equivalent to the world price.

The refiners have estimated their losses, as a result of these circumstances, at between $550m and $600m. It should be emphasised that this legislation will only partially reimburse refiners for their stock losses, because the compensation is for losses on stock purchased in February. It does not apply to January, when, the Government has argued, refiners took supplies at acceptable risk conditions. The reimbursement is also less the value of sales from those stocks between the 1 March import parity price adjustment and the subsequent Prices Surveillance Authority price determination on 14 March. So the question remains about the $300m which the Government accepts that the oil industry has lost during this period which is not covered by compensation. The Government has argued that the earlier losses may be made up if the price increases in the future. The Government also argues that companies will be able to effectively recoup nearly half of any remaining losses via company tax deductions. But given no price recoupment in the foreseeable future, the companies will incur losses of about $150m. This is little comfort for the oil industry, which will be forced to wait for compensation which may never occur, and, if it does, will occur only after a substantial period in which substantial damage will have been done to company results, shareholder returns and share prices.

This is a good example of the extent to which the Government apparently has not thought, or does not want to think, about the commercial reality of its decisions or of its policies. A disturbing feature of the Government's attitude generally to this industry-and this is another example of it-is to be seen in a speech given by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) during a debate in another place on this same legislation. On 30 April he said:
Oil companies without any shadow of doubt are the ugliest and most avaricious of any sector of industry within Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I suppose that will only be bettered by Senator Sanders when he speaks in this debate. The honourable member for Dunkley is in good company when joined by Senator Sanders of the Australian Democrats. The honourable member for Dunkley, Mr Chynoweth, continues by saying that the answer to curbing this is to be found in the Australian Labor Party Platform, from which he then quotes. He says that the Platform states that the ALP will establish a public corporation-we have an ALP government so we can assume that this is the Government's policy as well, otherwise it will be in trouble. The ALP platform states:

SPEECH.PARA: Establish a public corporation, responsible to the Commonwealth Government, to participate in the development of Australia's oil and gas resources, such that the corporation-
(a) will have strategic as well as commercial objectives;
(b) may, with the approval of the Government, engage in any of the activities of an integrated oil company;
(c) may operate independently or in joint venture with private or other enterprise;

(d) will act commercially when participating with private companies, but may explore and locate reserves without seeking to develop them immediately, in the national strategic interest, when acting solely;
(e) will be funded as appropriate by Commonwealth grants and loans and by public borrowings, provided that its commercial operations incorporation provides a satisfactory return to its investors.
The honourable member for Dunkley goes on to say:

This is a part of the Australian Labor Party policy that I feel we should implement immediately. Why should these companies dictate to this Government the orders of some faceless overseas board? I believe that the Government has been blackmailed into giving the oil cartel a $125m handout.
That is provided for in this legislation.
We must make certain that it never happens again.

So there we have the true attitude, I think, of the Labor Party. There is part of the ALP platform and there is the call by a prominent member of the Labor Party in this Parliament for the implementation of that totally socialist approach to this industry. This legislation, which may be seen to be in light of a sop to the industry, is, as I have said, brought about by the total lack of commercial reality of this Government. If it can, by its policies, reduce the oil industry to a state of impotence and perhaps bankruptcy, that will more easily pave the way for its socialist objectives.

Of course, the Opposition does not share this view. This legislation would never have been needed at all if the Government had taken the advice that the Opposition has been giving it for the last 12 months-namely, to proceed to de- regulate the oil market, which it was considering 12 months ago. Despite clear indications that world oil prices were going to fall quite dramatically and may stay at low levels for some time, the Government has consistently refused to make the necessary policy adjustments to permit a more flexible response to the oil crisis. The Government has had plenty of time to adjust that policy. However, it has been unwilling to do so. While it has made some changes to the IPP formula to reflect the growth of the non-OPEC spot market, the Government has refused to fully deregulate pricing and the allocation system.

As I have said, if deregulation had been put in place a year ago when the Government was considering it, and the Opposition encouraged it, that would have enabled the oil industry to adjust much more flexibly and efficiently to the recent downward price movements and the market changes which have occurred since January this year. Unfortunately, the Hawke Government seems to be unable or unwilling to pursue deregulation initiatives in the oil market, despite its claim to be keen on deregulation and the reduction of controls on business. This is another good example of how the performance of the Hawke Government falls sadly short of its rhetoric.

I believe that in this case the Government has been heavily influenced by the union movement and some sections of the oil industry which have been opposed to deregulation. Mr Harris of Ampol Ltd, a notable critic of deregulation-although I have reason to believe from what he has told me privately that he does believe in a free market-was quoted in another place by the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) as having stated at a recent petroleum exploration conference in Adelaide that he was critical of the Opposition's attitude. Mrs Kelly has seized on this as proof that the coalition's policy of deregulating the oil market is opposed by everybody in the industry-oil refiners, oil producers, the trade union movement and the community generally. I think Mr Harris would be rather surprised by assertions that his comments at that conference purported to represent all of the oil industry and the trade union movement, let alone the community at large.

In fact, there is very considerable support in the industry for deregulation of the oil market. In a submission by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association to the Federal Government on 7 June last year-the industry had been invited by the Government to submit a discussion paper on deregulation-APEA said:

The Association has supported the introduction of a free market by the 1 June 1986 for some producers, but where this applies APEA urges the Government to provide time for commercial arrangements to be made to cope with the new system.

That is very similar, I might say, to what the Opposition has been saying. APEA, incidentally, represents 107 companies exploring for and producing oil and gas in Australia. In addition, 149 companies are associate members of APEA. Companies which provide services to those oil explorers and producers are associate members of APEA. So it really speaks on behalf of over 200 small to medium oil companies. That statement indicates at least some support for deregulation of the oil market.

In its submission to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry on petroleum products in September 1985 Esso Australia Ltd supported a truly free market for indigenous crude oil. Other oil companies not represented by APEA have also given their support to deregulation policies in this area. In a speech to the annual conference of the Institute of Directors in Australia in Adelaide on 7 March this year, the Chairman of Shell Australia Ltd, Mr Kevan Gosper, said:

I believe that the most effective framework within which to prepare for the uncertainties of the 1990s is a free market for oil in Australia. The Government considered this last year and decided to postpone any real moves in that direction. I urge most strongly a recon- sideration of that decision.

BP Australia Ltd in a position paper released in February this year also indicated support for a free market in Australian crude oil. I have had expressions of support for deregulation of that market from a number of other people in the oil refining industry who have been in touch with me. I do not propose to mention them or quote from letters they have written to me. However, I can assure the Senate that there is very widespread support in the oil industry, particularly in the refining side of it and, as I said, in the production and exploration side, for the views of the Opposition. Therefore, it is totally misleading to seize, as the honourable member for Canberra did in another place, on some fairly unrepresentative view of one figure in the industry-namely, Mr Harris of Ampol-in remarks he made in Adelaide as an indication that the Opposition is completely out of tune with industry thinking. That is not the case. Indeed, the evidence suggests that the remarks attributed to Mr Harris-from what I have since discovered, they may have been taken somewhat out of context-certainly can be of no support whatever for the claims made by the honourable member for Canberra.

Support for the views of the Opposition comes from not only the oil industry but also other industry representatives who have indicated that they support them as a means of ensuring lower fuel prices, which are so vital to the health of our economy. In a statement on 6 February this year the President of the Confederation of Australian Industry said:

Australia's competitors are taking full advantage of lower oil prices to decrease their energy costs. Our unfavourable balance of payments situation demands that we must also take all possible steps to improve Australia's international competitiveness. The prompt flow-on of lower world oil prices to Australian industry would be an obvious and rational move in that direction.

The Australian Automobile Association, which represents four million motorists throughout Australia, has also argued that the Government's oil policies are untenable and should be changed. As far as I can see, the only body that is registering strong opposition to deregulation is the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That opposition seems to be based on the fact that it thinks a few jobs of oil workers may be lost and that some Australian coastal shipping jobs may also be at risk. There is the real power behind the throne, as ever with this Government-namely, the views, the pressure and the influence of the ACTU. That seems to be the reason why a year ago, when this Government published a discussion paper and indicated a move in the direction of deregulation, it backed off. That was because of the influence of that body.

Last year the Opposition was very critical of the non-decision, as I have described it, of the Government on deregulation in the oil industry and a lack of nerve by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans. I said at that time:

Despite the free market rhetoric espoused by the Hawke Government, Senator Evans showed little resolve to pursue deregulation in the face of opposition by big brother-the ACTU. Indeed, Senator Evans was unable to offer more than a whimper in defence of his position.
The Coalition does not believe that deregulation of the oil market should be dumped in the too hard basket to suit Government and union convenience.
The Coalition is not prepared to leave the future of the oil industry unclear and is committed to introducing a free oil market when in Government.

The Government has refused outright to bear the burden of current regulation and to provide full compensation. Instead, it has forced consumers to pay for its policies by increasing petrol tax by over 200 per cent. The Prices Surveillance Authority, at the Government's behest, has also introduced a wholesale surcharge of nearly half a cent a litre to provide some compensation for these stock losses. So the consumer is bearing a further burden on top of the 200 per cent increase in the excise on petrol.

Given the revenue greed of this Government and its attempts to renege on the commitment to reduce the new tax on petrol, there must be doubts whether that surcharge will ever be lifted. The implications of this revenue shift are considerable. The fall in the price of petrol at the pump has not borne heavily on the Commonwealth Government. Most of the price benefit to consumers is a cost to oil-producing companies. The potential volatility of tax revenues is somewhat reduced. There is no case for reducing the proposed personal income tax relief or increasing other taxes on the grounds of revenue lost. This view has been expressed by the Business Council of Australia in its February 1986 bulletin, with which the Opposition certainly agrees. Consumers have suffered enough from the high taxes of this Government. They are entitled to some relief. This high-spending Government must be forced to accept fiscal limits and make expenditure cuts so that it can afford to reduce petrol taxes and compensate the oil industry and consumers. To do this, the Government must get its own Budget and its own house in order. In a recent speech in Adelaide, Mr Gosper, to whom I have already referred, said:

. . . the industry's concern for its future, the problem of stock losses for the refiners, and indeed the political and economic dilemmas that faced the Government would have been diminished considerably if a free market existed for crude oil and for petroleum products.
Again, he has reiterated a view he expressed last year. He goes on:

Petrol would be up to 30 per cent cheaper under a Labor government.
This man, who was shadow Minister for Minerals and Energy but who was destined to be the world's greatest Treasurer, was still convinced of this in 1980 when he told the National Press Club:

A Labor Government will freeze the price of Australian oil. We'll say `Thus far and no further' on the collection of this tax without mandate, this $3 billion which the Government will raise . . . and that way Australians have the benefit of having an oil field in their own country.

That is why I described this Bill as a surprising Bill. It is surprising because it has not taken the Government and the world's greatest Treasurer long to break those promises and this Bill is tangible evidence of their failure.

In case the people of Australia have forgotten, this Government has been quite happy to stand beside the petrol pump with its hands out, regardless of criticisms by its members when the pricing scheme was introduced. The Government's hypocrisy was revealed when it was put to the test when international oil prices fell. The rationale behind the oil parity pricing scheme was that the price would move up and down with world prices so as to achieve parity between foreign and indigenous oil and thus encourage oil exploration. This Government was perfectly happy to reap the benefits to fund its deficit when prices were high but it held on like a greedy schoolboy when prices fell. Its desperation to keep the oil money flowing is demonstrated by the way in which, by a sleight of hand, prices were reduced, only to be raised again by another levy. This is only putting off the evil day. The deficit can be reduced only by governmental self-control. Government spending cannot go on willy-nilly. The crunch has come. The Government has taken the coward's way out.

However, taxpayers and consumers are not deceived. If the Government grasped the nettle and allowed the industry to adjust flexibly to movements in prices, we would not be faced in the future with more situations similar to that which we are facing today. Today we are dealing with a Bill to partially compensate oil companies for losses occasioned by government action. When government is involved in a market-place all sorts of distortions can occur. I draw the Senate's attention to the ridiculous situation we now have: International oil prices have fallen, but the Government took overlong to react; our petrol prices have fallen, but only by half the amount they should have, yet at the same time we are sending liquefied petroleum gas to Japan at $US186 per tonne under contract while the Tasmanian Gas Company is having to pay $A269.50 a tonne. The Australian price went up approximately $8 a tonne on 1 April, a particularly apt day when one considers that it was not only April Fool's Day but also the day on which the price of oil fell by $6.10 a barrel.

Tasmanian consumers of LPG have to ask why they must be expected to pay increasing amounts for their own Australian LP gas at the same time that, as taxpayers, they are being required to fork out under this Bill. It is not the wealthy or big companies which are suffering losses here. The reticulated town supply in Launceston uses LPG and pipes it to pensioners, and to restaurants and other small businesses. It vitally affects our economy. It is not atypical.
I again quote the Treasurer, who stated:
If the Government is to carry the burden of a rational energy pricing policy, then the public also should reap some of the benefits of their sacrifice.

It is interesting that the Treasurer should recognise the sacrifice of the public. His Government seems to recognise problems in a meaningful way only when they are suffered by big business or big unions. This Bill is clear and irrefutable proof that this Government has no understanding of the needs and problems of small business in Australia. If there were any understanding of the problems of small business, we would not be faced with this brazen attempt to buy friendship in the big oil companies while the taxpayer foots the bill.

The Bill before the Senate provides for a sum of nearly $125m of taxpayers' funds to be paid by way of compensation to six oil companies for losses sustained as a result of government action. Does the Government not realise that for every action of government the whole nation is affected? In this case the decision to reduce the price of domestic crude oil supplies, firstly by $16.62 a barrel on 1 March and then by $6.10 a barrel on 1 April, had immediate and dramatic effects. It appears that the oil companies have suffered loss through no fault of their own, but there is no doubt that they alone will not be carrying the cost. The Australian taxpayer is being asked to foot the bill to the direct extent of nearly $125m. But that is not where it ends. The companies are passing on their costs to their customers. Here again the taxpayer pays, this time in his role as consumer. He consumes the fertiliser, the heating oil, the chemicals and the plastics, and these costs are not being reduced along with the reduction in the domestic crude oil supplies. Out of his mouth he condemns himself. The Minister reveals his reliance on a public service brief. TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder they are having trouble with their businesses if they are doing things like that. I have no doubt at all that they are in difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1978 the Federal Government set up an inter-departmental committee to examine the burden of paper work imposed on small business by governments. The Australian Bureau of Statistics undertook a survey of small business enterprises to establish the perceived cost to small firms of completing government forms. During 1978 this amounted to $215.3m, an average cost of $604 for each small enterprise. Losses occasioned by the rough and tumble of free enterprise are one thing; losses directly attributable to government action are quite another. The Minister for Resources and Energy does not understand the commercial realities of his portfolio unless those realities come in the form of big companies. His Government's action has caused stock losses not only to the big oil companies but also to the small businesses-to the petrol retailers. These are the family businesses of Australia, the forgotten men and women who battle and risk their all for reward. These are the little businesses that the Government can find no justification for helping. I remind Senator Evans that only a year ago he went on the record as follows:

Sooner or later the dollar is going to float back to more realistic levels . . . When that happens, obviously consumers will get the benefit of that in terms of reduced prices at the pump and the Government will lose the additional revenue . . . It is as hard and fast-
referring to his guarantee-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Until Senator Newman spoke I thought the only real opposition to the Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill 1986 was from the Australian Democrats, who have expressed the view that the legislation is, in their words, shonky, scandalous, a windfall and a give-away of an indefensible kind. Senator Newman departed a little bit from her party brief and gave us some further variations on that theme-although no doubt she will vote to support the legislation-suggesting, as she did, that it was a brazen effort by us to buy the friendship of the oil companies. That theme very much echoed what Senator Sanders had to contribute.
—She is only worried that you are only worried about the oil companies. That is what is worrying her.

—I am indebted to Senator Durack for that clarification, though I am sure Senator Newman will not be. I am sure she thought that what she was saying was clear enough. However, I thank Senator Durack; that is appreciated. Let me say at the outset that the Bill is nothing like what has been described by both Senator Sanders and Senator Newman and, if it were, that media storm which looked as if it were going to erupt at one point, not to mention the storm within my own Party, would still be very much with us rather than having dissipated as instantly as it arose once people in the media and in my Party-and, indeed, everywhere else except within the ranks of the Democrats, and also apparently including Senator Newman-appreciated what this legislation is all about. It is not in the nature of a give-away, and the last people who will be heard to be making that suggestion, even privately, are the oil companies, for reasons that I will explain. It is not in the nature of a give-away of any kind; it is in the nature of a prudent arrangement by the Commonwealth to stop what would otherwise have been a much greater drain on Commonwealth and taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put the facts of this matter on the record once again. The compensation payment that we are talking about, the reimbursement in issue here, is to compensate the industry for the small part of its now accumulated stock losses, following the world oil price collapse, that occurred when, at the Government's request, they went on lifting something like 13 million barrels of Australian crude oil during the month of February at a price of $16 a barrel higher than they would have been able to get that crude for on the world market. As a result, they faced a total additional cost of something like $210m. The payment of $125m is in the nature of a partial rebate of the $350m worth of crude oil excise revenue the Commonwealth collected from that continued program of liftings during the month of February-$350m which the Commonwealth would not have been able to collect had the oil companies ceased that program of liftings during the month of February. They undoubtedly would have ceased that program of liftings, had not the arrangement been entered into to compensate them at least for that particular component, the $125m of direct payment, with the remainder of the $210m being picked up by their opportunity to recoup in the market-place in the period before the Prices Surveillance Authority wholesale price determination took effect. That was a very good deal from the Commonwealth's point of view-$350m worth of revenue which it would not otherwise have received, less $125m payable to the companies under the legislation now before us; a net gain to the Commonwealth and the country of $225m.

They are the arithmetical realities of this arrangement. It is not good enough for Senator Sanders to dismiss that airily by saying we would have been able to recoup that $350m later on anyway. Of course that claim is premised on the assumption-which I assure him is false-that the allocation system would have been maintained intact had it fallen apart during the month of February in the way he is suggesting. I will come to the question of what the future of the allocation system would have been, but on the assumption that the companies just ceased lifting for February but then picked up their liftings again in April, May and June-which is a wildly implausible assumption; let us assume it anyway-I can tell Senator Sanders that his claim that over the remainder of the year they would have picked up the necessary further liftings from the Australian producers, which would have produced over time that revenue result for the Government, is false.

The short point here is that some of them were overlifted already in the month of January in such a way that they had no obligation to pick up this extra amount over the course of the year. When I talked previously about their obligation to pick up during the month of February I was talking in terms of commitments they had made concerning pick-ups during February. Some of those commitments were in excess of what they were technically obliged to do under the allocation system. That is the first point. They were not necessarily obliged at all to pick up over the course of the year that particular amount in question.

The second point I make is that in a falling price market, even had they picked it up, they would have been doing so at a price and accordingly at a revenue return to the Government very much less than the price we are talking about as having been applicable during the month of February. The import parity price now is very much less than it was in the month of February and it has continued to decline through the course of the year. That all sounds very technical but it is necessary to be technical from time to time-even though it is beyond the range and skill of the Democrats to focus on these matters-in order to point up the hollowness of some of the assertions continually made.

So that is the starting point, and I suppose from many points of view that is where the argument could simply be left; case rests. But let me go on with the other legs of the argument just so people appreciate the full enormity and irresponsibility of the crude, vulgar, populist claims that are being made by the Democrats on this occasion-that this is some sort of windfall payout to the oil companies or, as Senator Newman would say, an attempt to buy some friendship with them. The next leg of the argument is simply this: If we had not reached the agreement we did in the month of February to ensure a continued program of liftings during the month of February to produce the revenue result I have talked about, that would have meant not only the permanent disappearance of that particular chunk of revenue-net revenue when we take out this payment-but also, I can assure the Senate, the collapse of the allocation system, creating a situation whereby without any opportunity to prepare for it, phase it in and accommodate it, we would have gone straight into a free market environment-one in which there would have been much more imported crude and much more imported product.

The Opposition-this was the nub of Senator Durack's contribution to the debate-said what a terrific thing the free market was and that if we had had one all along we would not have had this allocation system and price constraints that were operating back in the month of February. Therefore, refiners would not have been caught in a stock loss situation and this legislation would not have been necessary. That may all be true, but the arguments in favour of a free market system have to be established on a cost-benefit evaluation rather than simply asserted. The reality is that, although there is a case to be made, there are arguments in favour of a free market and those arguments are very much present in the Government's mind. We considered them in 1985, and we will consider them again next year with a view to possibly introducing a free market in 1988.

Any immediate plunge into a free market system, in particular a complete free market system with no regard to the particular problems of the on-shore producers in Australia, would reduce them to the status of producers of the marginal barrel, absolutely at the mercy of the refining companies, even more so than the retailers for whose position Senator Newman's heart was bleeding earlier. Even in an environment where there are things to be said for a free market in principle, if not a complete free market, there is nothing much to be said for an immediate plunge into a free market situation in the environment in which we would have found ourselves had this occurred with the collapse of the allocation system back in February. There would have been a massive loss of government revenue, there would have been a massive further deterioration in our balance of payments on the assumption that a free market environment applying then would have sucked in-maybe not necessarily in the longer term but in the environment prevailing earlier this year-some of that massive amount of cheap crude oil and cheap product which is sloshing around the world at the moment. The incentive for people to buy that rather than domestic Australian crude would have been very great indeed, with obvious implications not only for our domestic producers but also for the balance of payments situation.

There would have been enormous difficulties with the Australian refining industry, not least two refiners in particular whose position is well known to be marginal economically at best-and all this was spelled out in the 1985 review I prepared when this matter was in issue. I am referring in particular to Ampol in Brisbane and the Mobil refinery in Adelaide, which between them involve something over 700 jobs. Those refiners would have been in an impossible position in the event of a sudden move to a free market situation, given the enormous temptation there would have been, and in fact still is in the circumstances prevailing in the world oil market, to import massive amounts not just of overseas rather than domestic crude oil but rather of refined product from overseas sources.

We would have had a problem immediately with the on-shore producers. They have a problem at the moment in terms of their exploration and development, but many are surviving-those of them with a production arm-on the basis of the existing allocation system in a non-free market environment. Some 8,000 people are employed in on-shore oil development and production, and a great many of those jobs would have been at risk, too, had we plunged into a system of a collapse of the allocation scheme with all that that involves. This is why Ted Harris made some comments in Adelaide at the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference, in the course of a speech which comprehensively demolished the pretensions to economic respectability of the Opposition in its pronouncements in this area. He said on behalf of Ampol, and I believe he was also speaking for a great many people in the industry:

I have read with interest the recent avalanche of press statements coming from the Opposition spokesman, Senator Durack, calling for a `free market' and the lowest possible petrol prices. What I want to say to him is this, that if cheap petrol is the predominant objective then we can fix that very quickly. We will simply have a milk run of tankers bring product into Australia from huge surpluses available from the Middle East and elsewhere and to hell with exploration and production and efficient refinery capacity, and employment and capital investment. Need I really say any more?
That is the nub of this argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will send you a copy of a letter he has written to me, which may give you a different view.

—I thank Senator Durack for that suggestion. I am always grateful to receive correspondence from him, whether he has written it himself or is simply passing it on. All I know is that, on the subject of Senator Durack's views on free markets, what Mr Harris was prepared to say publicly in the very public forum of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference in Adelaide a few weeks ago was that those suggestions-if not necessarily beyond proper analysis in implementation over time, in the context of the claim for immediate flow-on and immediate benefits from a free market, the claim that is made that immediate cheaper prices will result for the consumer-mean that there is a substantial downside to be taken into account, as I have spelt out and as he has even more adequately than I. That has to be taken into account by anyone who claims that, had we not entered into the arrangement embodied in this legislation, somehow all would have been right with the world. It would not have been right with the world. We would have had an instant collapse of the allocation system, instant pressures on the on-shore producers, instant massive pressures on the refining industry, instant pressures on the balance of payments, further pressures on government revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: While on the subject of government revenue, I interpolate that Senator Durack's suggestion that there has been no sacrifice at all from the Government's point of view in this whole course of events, as it has unwound over the last few months with the collapse in oil prices, is simply not the case. There has been a massive renunciation of revenue return from the Commonwealth compared with what would have been the case had we not forgone that revenue. I refer to the $150m in the remaining part of 1985-86 and the $420m in the full year next year, as a result of our decision in March not to recoup fully the amount of revenue forgone as a result of the decline in local prices and the massive reduction in excise revenue. The Government has already made that obvious sacrifice in terms of its revenue. There is a great deal more pain than that involved for the Government in terms of its revenue calculations for this coming year because production is so low at the moment. This was simply the revenue effect of changing the differential tax recoupment I was discussing a moment ago.

There is a further point that needs to be made, coming back to the line of argument about why this Bill is justified. It will be recalled that the first point was that it was not a give-away of $125m; it was a net gain of $225m for the Commonwealth. The second point I have been making is that many other downside effects flowing from the collapse of the allocation system undoubtedly would have occurred.

The third point I make is that there was no real alternative at the time for reimbursing the refiners for the stock loss incurred for February other than going down the route of direct payment. There was a technically available alternative which some of them still want us to allow them to pursue, and that is going to the Prices Surveillance Authority and getting authorisation for maintaining wholesale prices at a higher level than they otherwise would be to give them an opportunity for recoupment in the market-place. That may have been technically available, but to allow that avenue of recoupment or reimbursement to apply would have meant that consumers would not have received anything like the substantial benefits they have already-the nearly 6c they got in March, which is what we are talking about here. Not only would that have generated some anxiety for consumers, but more importantly from an economic and good government management of the country point of view, it would have meant that we did not get any benefit at all in inflation and CPI terms from the world decline in oil prices. As it is, the most recent CPI figures have not shown up any benefit from the decline in oil prices simply because they occurred too late in the March quarter for that to be so. But a benefit there will be from the March adjustment alone, something of the order of a 0.5 of a CPI percentage point in the first instance and something over 1 per cent in due course. It was important and necessary, for the health of the Australian economy and the maintenance of our competitive position as compared with other countries, to go down this route.

The final point I make to the Democrats is that, if this Bill were by some mischance to be defeated and this measure involving $125m were to be disallowed, the Government would be in honour and duty bound to allow the refiners, under those circumstances, to go back to the Prices Surveillance Authority and seek through that mechanism recovery of the full amount of $125m that is involved in the present legislation. That would involve an immediate increase in the wholesale price of petrol of something like 5.3c per litre for at least a month which would completely undermine the inflationary gains we have been making in recent times. That is the whole picture in terms of the rationale for this legislation.

Let me make one final point, again about the claim that the refiners are somehow the grateful beneficiaries of a handout in this respect. I have indicated that from the Government's point of view it certainly does not amount to a handout because we were the net beneficiaries in revenue terms. It should also be absolutely clear from an industry point of view that the refiners-my sympathies are not confined to the refiners; other people in the oil industry have been suffering very seriously as a result of the downturn in oil prices-have accumulated uncompensated stock losses after tax of something over $300m. Even after this $125m is paid to the industry as a whole and even after one takes into account the opportunities for recoupment the refiners have had through the existing delays in the implementation of new wholesale prices and through the modest allowance that has been made in the most recent PSA decision to enable some recovery for stock losses, the refiners are still lamenting to the tune of some $300m as the situation stands at the moment. Anyone who, under those circumstances, whether it is the Democrats or Senator Newman, says that somehow the Government is buying friendship, irresponsibly making giveaways in a way that does not have regard to any considerations of equity and justice, needs to bear that point in mind. That compares with the total profitability for the whole industry of the order of magnitude of $300m or $400m last year, last year being the year when profits were, for the first time in two or three years, for most companies in the black at all. A period of substantial losses.

Senator Sanders will know that neither of us is prone to weeping tears of blood for the oil companies. They are big enough and strong enough to look after themselves. Many of the representations I receive from them I treat appropriately. But there is a reality about the economic plight they have been facing as a result of the drop in oil prices, and where their losses, as was the case in February, are the product of Government policy and a specific Government request in order to maintain the integrity of that policy, I believe that we have no alternative but to act accordingly. I have made it clear in public statements on behalf of the Government that if and when prices come back up it is perfectly appropriate that action be taken to recover anything that could properly be argued as a windfall gain. For the record I repeat what I said in my Press statement of 16 April:

Should crude oil prices move in the opposite direction as dramatically in the future, appropriate measures will be taken to ensure that the refiners do not accrue stock gains of a windfall nature (i.e. over and above what is necessary to enable them to recover residual losses they have accrued during the present period of price collapse) and that the Government is recompensed for its present financial support, to the extent practicable.

That is the position. I believe that it is an evenhanded and balanced position. I understand what Senator Newman was saying about the position of the small retailers. I can repeat only the points that I made to her in the answer I gave to her question to me in the Senate the other day. The position of the small retailers is very different, from all sorts of points of view, from that of the refiners. I do not want to go through those issues again. The basic point is that maybe the small retailers are not properly informed. Maybe they are unaware of the time that elapses between the announcement of a change in import parity pricing and the Prices Surveillance Authority's change in the wholesale price determinations. But the opportunity is there for them to inform themselves. The system has been around now for some considerable time. There is a gap. There is a delay. The stock period for the service stations is short enough to enable them to adjust their inventories accordingly. They are under no constraints so far as the PSA in concerned, although I acknowledge that there are competitive constraints on their ability to recoup in the market-place. Generally speaking, they are not bound by the regulatory apparatus that is the case with the refiners. It has to be said for the benefit of people who are always preaching the virtues of free enterprise that such losses as small retailers have incurred, and they have been minor, have been what can be regarded only as ordinary commercial risk, associated in some instances with an insufficient appreciation of the room for manoeuvre available to them.

I do not know, at the end of the day, whether Senator Newman had any particular consistency about her speech. On the one hand she was berating me for spending too much of the taxpayers' money on the refiners. In her next breath she was berating me for not spending a bit more on behalf of the Government to pay to the retailers to put them in the same position as the refiners.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't listen.

—I listened very carefully. I simply say that at the end of the day this measure is thoroughly justified for all the reasons I have outlined. I am grateful to the Senate for its general support of the measure, however churlish that support may have been, and to those who have indicated their willingness to vote for the measure. I wish the Bill an appropriately speedy and robust passage.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
