PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wool industry and the Opposition have no general disagreement with the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1986. It will bring the wool industry into line with revamped arrangements which are now operating in 12 other rural industries, the most notable being the recently established Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation. The Bill will significantly reorganise the management of funds available for research and development in the Australian wool industry. At present the finance in this industry is controlled by the Wool Research Trust Fund, which is the largest in Australia with a budget in 1985-86 of $25m and with a reserve of $44m. Part of the Fund's annual budget is allocated to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics for research. But under this legislation a new body is to be established, the Australian Wool Research and Development Council, which will control the finances.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Government there are four ways in which it is anticipated that this body can act to improve the present system. Firstly, it will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of wool research and development. Secondly, it will identify more precisely areas of wool research and development specific to the needs of the industry. Thirdly, it will improve account- ability for expenditure. Fourthly, it will encourage more effective use of resources and skill in research and development.

This legislation will result in the loss to the CSIRO and to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of their automatic right to wool research and development funds. For example, they will now be obliged to compete for funds on a project by project basis and will not receive an automatic lump sum allocation. In 1984-85 the CSIRO spent $5m on wool production research. It must be recognised that over the years this organisation has had a tremendous impact on the wool industry. In addition, the Australian wool textile industry has worked closely with the CSIRO in developing new products and techniques. Currently, over 20 projects are being jointly researched; most of these are not of a short term nature. Whether the loss of the previous automatic grant will adversely affect the CSIRO's wool research remains to be seen. However, I suggest that in the long run the increased competition will improve the efficiency of bodies involved in research and encourage them to strive for maximum achievement while at the same time minimising costs.

Research and development is essential to maintain and increase Australia's market position. In the past the Australian Wool Corporation has had a successful research and development policy which has resulted in ongoing success for the Australian wool industry. It has been very beneficial financially. The industry has always been prominent in Australia's development as a nation. Wool is predicted to continue to be our most stable rural commodity and the future outlook, according to some, is fairly optimistic. However, I must admit that I do not always share that high degree of optimism. Despite significant increases in consumption in the major markets of the world-Europe, Japan and the United States of America-and the rising price for a whole range of wool types, unfortunately Australia has unavoidable increases in farm costs which will offset the high returns of these so-called prosperous times, and as a result some sectors of the industry are seeking an increase in the floor price scheme. I think this is somewhat unfortunate.

As I indicated, there are some worrying signals which need to be heeded now. Firstly, the price of wool has not fully reflected the devaluation effects of the Australian dollar. Secondly, the Australian Wool Corporation's stockpile is still in excess of one million bales. Thirdly, although there has been a significant premium in the price of woollen products over their synthetic competitors, the fall in oil prices will tend to widen this difference, requiring additional advertising support to maintain sales at current prices or additional results of research flowing through to the industry. Fourthly, I submit that wool has never been cheaper in real terms, but that this does not really imply that prices cannot fall further. Fifthly, wool's share of the fibre market is not increasing and stands at only about 5 per cent of the total market. The problems with regard to price will inevitably be associated with an appreciation of the Australian currency, if that happens. There is also a disturbing trend that more and more farmers are moving from other industries which are currently depressed into producing wool, which could result in an oversupply situation.

Finally, I draw attention to the situation in the People's Republic of China, which has become a great market for Australian wool and is already an important buyer. Many people see the development of closer relations with China as a major plus for the wool industry, particularly in the light of the considerably increased demands, not only for wool but also for our rams and top breeding stock. In the short term this growing trade is a tremendous achievement, but I would like to sound a very loud and clear warning about the future prospects because I do not think that in the long term they are all that rosy.

I believe that China has the capacity to topple Australia from its pre-eminent position if its record over the past few years is anything to go by. Let me give some examples. In the area of cotton, in 1982-83 China produced 13.6 million bales. In 1984 this had risen dramatically to 25.3 million bales. Over the same period production in the United States of America dropped from 15.6 million bales in 1982 to 13.3 million in 1984. Similarly, in 1982 China's cotton yield was 500 pounds per acre, increasing to 600 pounds per acre in 1984. Across the sea, America's yield dropped significantly below that of China and in my view the same sort of situation could happen with wool if China applies itself to the wool industry as it did to the cotton industry.

At the moment China produces slightly less than two-thirds of its total requirements of wool. Although China has the third largest sheep population in the world, behind Russia and Australia, it has been unable to satisfy demand, with the result that imports have increased fivefold in the past five years. In money terms that has meant an import cost in excess of $500m. Of course, this has led to problems of foreign exchange and China's take of wool has not been even because of that problem. China's goal is to become self-sufficient in wool as soon as possible. I do not believe that this should be too difficult for it. China's yield per sheep is less than half that achieved in Australia. By improving this yield it is not too difficult to presume that it will not be too long before China is satisfying its increasing demands from its own resources.

Increasingly we are finding delegations of Chinese people coming to Australia, looking at our studs and taking notes which will be taken back home and applied in a practical manner. Australia is helping considerably in China's quest for self-sufficiency through improved quality and increased production. Providing China with high quality genetic material and superior breeding stock would increase the yield. Increasing the yield would also provide China with more basic materials for its anticipated increase in the production of wool textiles and apparel exports. In fact, China increased its exports of wool and allied textiles by some 17 per cent in 1984 and this is expected to increase even further over the next decade. China's lower costs of production in some areas could put pressure on international markets and depress orders for wool from Australia's traditional wool buyers.

In spite of the increases in sales of wool to China, our share of the Chinese market has fallen. Australia and New Zealand each export about 40 million kilos of wool to China. The most dramatic increase in sales comes from South America, whose share of the Chinese market has risen from 14 million kilos in 1982 to 40 million kilos in 1984. I therefore believe that we must be careful not to fall into the trap of expecting China to become the saviour of our most important rural industry. Our most pressing task today is to convince the Chinese that it would be cheaper, more efficient and more cost-effective on its part to continue importing high quality wool from Australia, rather than spending generations trying to come up with a product of equivalent quality.

Tasmania is the centre of the superfine wool industry of Australia. In February this year at the annual wool sales a world record price for superfine wool was established by the Japanese from Fujii-Keori Ltd, which has held the world record price for some years. That firm considers the Tasmanian superfine wool to be the best in the world. This wool derives from pure bred saxon merino sheep, a breed that has remained virtually unchanged for close to 200 years; but that does not therefore mean that there has not been years of research and selective breeding to make that breed what it is today. Two hundred years of research and development cannot be transported to another country, nor do I believe that it should be transported.

We should be doing all in our power to maintain supremacy in our superfine wool area and to develop new techniques and types of wool to keep ahead of changing demands. Our future will be determined, no doubt, by our investment in research and development and by our enterprises and achievements in the marketing area. This Bill aims to give greater emphasis to research and is geared towards a more efficient and effective program of development in the wool industry. It will improve the ability of the Australian Wool Corporation to approve and monitor all research projects according to the agreed corporate and operating plans.

One point that must be raised concerns the question of financial costs imposed by the Bill. While the proposed legislation is likely to be advantageous to the management of research and development funds, the policy of the Wool Corporation to date has proved successful. The Government must give assurances that the changes will not impose higher administrative costs or reduce the number of hours spent on research. It is important also that growers maintain a say in research matters. Despite some reservations I may have, I believe that the wool industry will benefit by the changes initiated in this Bill. Well managed research and development is fundamental to the industry's growth and future prosperity. It is vital that we develop and exploit new opportunities for wool and improve economic efficiency at all times in production and processing in order to ensure that Australia remains at the forefront in the production of wool for world markets. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Wool Industry Amendment Bill is to make changes to the organisation and administration of wool industry research and development funding. The responsibility for wool research and development will now fall to a new Wool Research and Development Council. The Council will have nine members and will be responsible to the Australian Wool Corporation. The coalition supports this move, which has been made with the support of the industry and will make the industry more accountable. The new Council Chairman will be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) from a panel supplied by the AWC, so the industry itself will have a say in its own affairs. Four of the Council will be nominated by the AWC and four will be nominated by an industry selection committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry remains one of Australia's greatest industries. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated the gross value of wool exports for 1985-86 to be in the order of $2.8 billion. This represents 26 per cent of total rural exports and 8 per cent of Australia's total exports. Wool production this year will again be the second largest contributor to our country's export earnings. Fine wool production in Australia is not among the best in the world-it is the best in the world. Australia produces fine wool better than any other country. Our merino flocks are the envy of wool growers everywhere. I add that New South Wales now holds the fine wool record price for the world which was taken away from Tasmania some time ago by Mr Gill from Walcha. It is of very great concern to me, and I know to the wool growers throughout Australia, that we are allowing our best blood lines to be exported to a number of countries. This is something that this Government should be addressing itself to at the moment. The argument has continued for a long time amongst governments and within the industry itself. Certainly, the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, David Asimus, has put his and the Corporation's position on this very strongly to the Government. At the National Agricultural Outlook Conference in Canberra earlier this year, David Asimus said that the Corporation had recommended the reintroduction of a merino export embargo. Senator Watson has already remarked on exporting our expertise in merinos to the rest of the world. Mr Asimus said:

While there is no strong evidence either way, the Corporation considers the further liberalisation of export restrictions would not be in the best interests of the Australian wool industry, and the embargo should be reintroduced.

He went on to say that Australia's reputation for top quality wool was not solely based on genetic material, but also reflected the husbandry, marketing and management skills that had evolved in the country's competitive, commercial en- vironment. He argued against the making of those skills freely available to the rest of the world. I totally agree with the sentiments he expressed.

If we start exporting our merino rams or semen we are giving our competitors the best opportunity they will get to take over our markets. Last year Australia trebled its exports of wool to China. It is being particularly aggressive in developing a new market there, as Senator Watson has already said. Of course, Europe is our largest market for merino wool and it is this market that we should be trying to protect and not throwing away to our potential competitors. Spain could emerge as the biggest threat to that market. Spain has the potential to substantially increase and improve its merino flocks. Having just entered the European Economic Community, Spain will be in exactly the right position to lock Australian wool out of the EEC market.

I am concerned that merino breeders, such as Don Vanrenen, who only recently was elected President of the World Federation of Merino Breeders, does not share my view. I believe that short term gains from lucrative overseas sales should not colour the argument. Obviously the world will pay top prices for our rams and semen, but the short term advantages will soon be forgotten if countries such as Spain decide to alter their programs from mainly meat production to wool production, and if they get the genetic material with which to do it, of course they will try. It is folly to believe that Spain, or any other country, will buy our best merino rams simply to increase their present activities of producing lean meat or for purely domestic requirements. A similar argument is raging at the moment in the angora goat industry. Again, short term considerations must be weighed against the long term benefits for the Australian angora industry.

The Federal Government is about to finalise, if it has not already done so, its Merino Export Review Committee report. I hope that common sense will prevail and that the members of that Committee will take a long term view. The changes being made to the wool industry under this legislation to improve organisational structure for research will really be wasted if, at the other end of the scale, we are selling off our expertise and our genetic material. Research has played a significant role in the development of our wool industry. There have been a number of research projects undertaken by such organisations as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, with its defleecing program. There has been considerable work in the development of improved hand pieces, automated mechanical shearing, research into better methods of handling and storage, and bale design. It is important that the research continues to be relevant to the industry. This legislation, with the establishment of a new Wool Research and Development Council, will ensure that the research remains relevant to the industry and addresses problems to which the growers and the industry itself need answers.

The five-year plan, which is also envisaged in this legislation making the Council accountable to the Parliament through the AWC, is important. The Opposition agrees with the Government's desire to obtain the greatest value for the dollars spent. The five-year strategic research and development plan is a move in the right direction. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support for the Wool Industry Amendment Bill. I will make only one comment on matters raised by Senator Watson and Senator Brownhill and that is to clarify the position which may have been somewhat confused concerning the export of merino rams and other genetic material from Australia. I think it is worth while putting on record that, as Senator Brownhill says, there is a considerable difference of opinion amongst the wool growing fraternity on this matter. It is not just a simple matter as Senator Watson and Senator Brownhill tended to put it, and all we have to do is to put a ban on the export of such material and everything will be okay.
—What about the warnings about the consequences of doing that?
—I point out to Senator Watson that the Merino Export Review Committee, which has some expertise in this area, has been looking at the problem, as he knows.
—Self-interest.

—What does the honourable senator mean by self-interest? That body was established to look at this matter. It has looked at the effects on the wool industry of the present arrangements for the export of rams and other genetic material. It prepared a draft report which was released on 1 May. The findings of that report, as both honourable senators well know, is that the export of merino rams and genetic material does not pose a threat to the Australian wool industry. It recommended a gradual easing of the restrictions in view of the significant opposition-which opposition we have heard here today-the limited number of merino rams available through the auction system and to allow adequate time for adjustment. It was required to produce a draft report which was to be released for public comment, which is what is happening now.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope, and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) hopes, that everyone will read the report and consider it critically and not just make blind assertions that such exports are bad. Once there has been sufficient public comment the Committee will prepare its final report and that final report will be submitted to the Minister and the Government, and at that time the decision will be made. There is plenty of time for the Opposition to put its views and to put some evidence to back those views. With respect, and I know it is difficult in a debate such as this, we have heard the views but not much evidence to back them. The Committee has looked at the evidence. The Minister has it in mind that any changes that will be made will be put into place for the 1986-87 ram auction sales which commence, I think, in July of this year.

So I think the Minister has taken a responsible approach to this matter. He has set up that review and there is plenty of time for public comment. All those in the industry will be able to put their case for and against it. The Minister will, by that stage, be saturated with advice from all sources, and I hope will not be too saturated to make a proper decision. I am sure he will not be. I thank honourable senators for their support and I will not delay the Senate any further on this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks are directed to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 and will refer largely to the question of the maturation of Australian spirits. There are some differences of opinion among manufacturers of these products in Australia, but the manufacturers of better grade products are combined in their condemnation of the decision of the Government with respect to the two-year maturation requirement. Some weeks ago I asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) certain questions regarding this decision. The Minister failed to answer the questions and promised to supply me with a comprehensive reply from his Department. Unfortunately, I am still awaiting that reply. I would have appreciated it if the reply had been produced prior to this debate.
—When was this?
—It was a few weeks ago.
—At the Estimates?
—No, in the House. The Senate may recall that I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Minister aware that maturation is an essential, integral step in the production of brandy, whisky and rum without which the oxidation and chemical change does not occur to produce the taste, aroma and characteristics attributed to these spirits? In whose interests has this decision to abolish compulsory maturation been made? . . . What steps will be taken by the Government to prevent the market being flooded with cheap rotgut local or imported spirits?
In the short reply Senator Button was able to give, he said:
I believe that there are very few countries where maturation under regulation is required as it has been required in Australia in the past.

I am afraid that the Minister is mistaken because every country which distills quality brandy, whisky or rum insists on maturation of those products, even though in those countries they might use unmatured spirit to manufacture spirits such as vodka and gin. As far as brandy is concerned, in the United States of America for example, and in the European Economic Community, a minimum two-year maturation period is required. In South Africa I believe the period is a minimum of one year, and in countries in which brandy is blended, such as Singapore and Malaysia, they require the use of products which have had two years maturation. With respect to rum-I do not know a lot about rum myself-

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on!

—My colleague from Queensland knows all about this. It is true that neither the United Kingdom nor the United States has any requirement for the maturation of rum, but then rum is not distilled in the United Kingdom or in the United States. All rum in those countries is imported. As far as whisky is concerned, the United Kingdom and the United States of America, of course, are distillers of whisky and both countries place great emphasis on maintaining the quality of whisky, both from a marketing point of view as well as from the point of view of the health of the consumers. Therefore, both countries insist on a minimum of two years maturation with respect to their whiskies.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that the great rum producing countries, including Puerto Rico and Mexico, which import more than 80 per cent of the rum into Australia, insist on maturation of that particular product. As a matter of fact, in their advertising in the United States, these firms make much of the virtues of maturation with respect to the quality of their product. The Minister might be able to tell me in whose interest this change has been made and on whose advice it was carried out. I understand from what I have been told that Sir Jack Egerton is a director of a rum distillery, and it would be interesting to know what role Sir Jack played in the formu- lation of this Government decision. I say this quite seriously. What arguments did Sir Jack employ to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) which were so persuasive that our wine growing, sugar growing and brandy and rum distilling industries should be put at risk?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Beenleigh?

—I think Beenleigh Rum Pty Ltd is out of business. I ask the Minister: What arguments did Sir Jack use to get three such important people to visit Brisbane in a VIP jet specifically to discuss the matter with him?
—Oh!

—That happened. Sir Jack could not have argued on the basis of quality, quality control, health or authenticity of the product. I suspect the only real arguments used were about how to keep the distilleries from going broke. The arguments used by Sir Jack could not have been devoted to the long term interests of the Queensland sugar industry, Australian grape growers, or the reputation of the Australian brandy, whisky or rum industries. Historically, I think we are all aware of Australian servicemen being blinded and otherwise poisoned by bad spirits in the First World War, in the Second World War and at other times in countries in which quality control of spirits did not exist. I mention servicemen because they were in such numbers in those countries and they were under such administrative control that the effect of bad spirits on their health was well recorded. Undoubtedly merchant seamen and other Australian travellers have suffered the same fate. Certainly it was the experiences of British sailors in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in relation to bad spirits that led to the regulations requiring maturation being first promulgated in the United Kingdom. We ought to have regard to the historical question of effects on health before we remove quality control on spirits.

SPEECH.PARA: It certainly seems strange to me that the Government is spending $100m on discouraging people from taking drugs but then turning around and deregulating the quality of one of the most used of all drugs in Australia. There are other factors, however, that are of greater importance to Australia and its whisky, brandy and rum industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the view of the whisky and brandy producers on this? I thought they were in favour of this.

—The message I have from the quality brandy producers in South Australia and from the quality rum producers in Queensland is that they disagree with what the Minister has said. Anyway, there are other factors that are of greater importance to Australia and its whisky, brandy and rum industries. One of those is the primary producers who provide the feedstock for the distilling industries. I want to deal with those factors under three headings-quality and price, importance to primary industry, and international standing and importations. I believe whisky should be matured because the great whisky producers of the world insist on their product being matured. Australian whisky is a very palatable product but it could not be said to have the same relative quality or prestige, at least when measured by the share of the whisky market that is enjoyed by our brandy and rum products. I have not seen Corio whisky for years or the other whisky that was famous in Australia some time ago. People lean towards drinking brandy and rum in preference to Australian whisky.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fair to say that brandy and rum producers have striven for and gained home recognition and some international standing. In the years ahead brandy and rum will join our wines in being internationally recognised. I hope that we will see the day when they will attract international awards. That will happen if we mature them properly. Maturation of rum is essential for refining. Moreover, the community expects rum to be matured because historically it always has been matured. The label `rum' should be reserved for maturated spirit which has been distilled from sugar cane or molasses. Sugar cane and molasses have some interesting properties. They can be distilled and the unmatured spirit can be used to make vodka, gin, or even to drive a motor car, but unless the spirit is matured it should not be called rum. Such unmatured spirit, or ethanol as it really is, could properly be called cane spirit, as it is in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jungle juice.

—Exactly, but it should not be thought of or sold as rum. Similarly, brandy must be matured. All the excellent Australian brandies are matured beyond the compulsory two years. They have steadily improved in quality and certainly are better than all imported brandies other than cognac and armagnac. Some are better than the younger imported cognacs. I recommend that Senator Grimes buy a bottle of St Agnes seven star brandy. He will find that what I just said is true.
—I cannot afford it.

—The Minister did quite a bit to the brandy industry a few years ago, I recall. The Government has claimed that the deregulation of maturation will make cheaper products available to the consumer. Let us examine that claim. I cannot give figures for Australian whisky, but from the inquiries that I have made the figures which I will give the Senate for rum and brandy will be substantially the same as for Australian whisky. For rum, the Bundaberg Distilling Company Pty Ltd claims that the cost of maturation is 15c per 750 millilitre bottle. That amount is not insignificant but is minuscule when compared with the excise which, last September, was $6 for a 750 millilitre bottle. It is a fair bit. That amount has increased each quarter, as it has for so many other products. The Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association has estimated that the cost per 750 millilitre bottle of maturing brandy is of the order of 35c, about twice the cost of maturing rum, but again is insignificant compared with the excise on that bottle.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government is concerned about the cost of the product it should stop its quarterly excise increase, which would relieve consumers very quickly and would also be very helpful to the industry. Maturation has an important part to play in the viability of cane and grape growing. At a time when the Government has been forced to provide grape growers with a subsidy to pull their vines and the Government is also involved in financial support to reduce sugar cultivation, it should not be contemplating legislation to further disadvantage growers by reducing the quality of the end product. Because of the maturation of both molasses spirit and grape spirit the brandy and rum distillers are able to buy grapes and cane at times of oversupply. This enables growers to be cushioned in good growing years. At the moment up to four years supply of distilled product is maturing. If the distillers were to decide to stop maturing the spirit-which the better manufacturers will not do; nevertheless the Government proposal would permit it-they would not need to take any grapes or sugar for four years. This cannot be in anyone's interest.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you know the Angoves family and their reputation for quality brandy. They regard this matter as being very critical. I am sure that all honourable senators from South Australia in particular would sympathise with their desire to maintain the high standard that has been achieved in the past. If the Bill is passed, an extension of time should be given to grape growers, many of whom will have made their decision to continue cultivating grapes on the basis of providing them to the brandy-making business. If the Government permits cheap and nasty rum, brandy and whisky substitutes to come into this country and, at the same time, imposes an increasing excise on the home-grown high quality matured products, the amount of grapes and cane needed for the home industries will be further reduced. The Government will therefore have lost tax revenue as cane and grape growers go broke and in the meantime it will have to increase vine pull schemes and cane substitution schemes.

Our balance of payments will be further affected adversely. Recently, Australian wine sales in Japan were affected by the reported use of softeners in Austrian wine. Senator Elstob very properly raised that question only yesterday. The Japanese had difficulty in discriminating between Austrian and Australian wines. Reversing this market disadvantage required both energy and money. I am not quite sure whether I would agree with the way in which Senator Elstob would like to identify Australian wine by putting a kangaroo on the label. That could be a good idea but other ways must be considered. I commend Senator Elstob for his interest in the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Senator Elstob about the coconut wines during the war.
—They also caused some visual problems for people during that period of our history.
—Have you ever drunk Emu brand port-style sherry? That was great stuff.

—No, I have not. Manufacturers of Australian quality wines are experiencing difficulties in getting their wines accepted in international markets, particularly in England and Europe, because of the marketing of low quality Australian-made wines before and just after the Second World War. The brand name `Emu' would have appeared on some of those wines. That matter was also mentioned in answer to Senator Elstob's question yesterday. We know of the recent wine scandal which will adversely affect the Italian wine industry. We should not contemplate doing anything that would put back our wine and spirits businesses, which have great potential for export markets.

SPEECH.PARA: For decades the French have enforced appellation control as a means of protecting the name of good products, not only at home but also abroad. Australia should not contribute to the downgrading of honest names such as Australian brandy, whisky and rum. I fully support the Opposition proposal that the maturation of whisky, brandy and rum be retained. I understand that later in the debate my colleague Senator Messner will move an amendment along those lines. I hope that honourable senators will see its importance in preserving the quality of our spirits that has been built up over many years. If the amendment is agreed to not only will it help the quality of our Australian rum, brandy and whisky; it will also be a tremendous help to the primary producers who produce the grapes and other commodities necessary for the production of these high quality goods.
