SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are discussing cognately the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. These Bills cover a relatively wide area of amendments-some insignificant changes and some important changes. However, for the sake of the debate tonight, I wish to limit my comments to clause 27 of the latter Bill, which seeks the repeal of two sections of the Spirits Act 1906. The essential problem that we are talking about is the maturation period for brandy, whisky and rum. I suppose that, at the outset of the debate, I should declare my interests. I do not drink any of those.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I would like to take the Senate back to the origin of this discussion. In September 1977 the Industries Assistance Commission was asked by the Government to consider the question of assistance to the protection of goods falling within Customs tariff items 22.08 and 22.09, which cover potable spirits and allied products and industrial alcohols. In July 1979 the IAC released a report which did not make any recommendations on the subject of maturation but said only this:

. . . suggests that the existing legislation should be amended to ensure that the standard of maturation achieved during the statutory period is uniform and, as far as possible, is non-discriminatory between imported and domestic goods and between domestic spirits of all types.

Since there was no action on the part of the Government at that time, this suggestion presumably was not acceptable, although later, the Government, following up these suggestions, sought to establish an inter-departmental committee. It also requested that the Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council review the existing standards for wine, spirits and liqueurs. This operation started in 1979. The Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council considered the matter of rum maturation and recommended that it be retained. However, following that recommendation there was more extensive political lobbying. Essentially, that situation carried through to 1983 when the Public Health Advisory Committee reported on the revised model food standards regulation for spirits and liqueurs in paragraph 6.4.3 of its report. That paragraph states:
PHAC noted the detailed background provided by the Food Standards Committee on the question of whether the current mandatory requirement that rum be matured for 2 years, should be deleted.

PHAC accepted the view of the Food Standards Committee that a change in the current requirements that rum be matured for 2 years in wood was not warranted and noted that this requirement had been included in the revised Standard for Spirits and Liqueurs.

PHAC also agreed with the Food Standards Committee that the question of whether rum should, or should not be matured was not a health issue. PHAC directed the Food Standards Committee to devote its time and attention to health related issues in the future.

That is a bit of a backhander. In other words, there was a clear indication at that point that progress with regard to the distillation and maturation of those spirits had reached such a standard that the Public Health Advisory Committee did not feel it was any longer a health consideration.

That brings us to the ninety-ninth session of the National Health and Medical Research Council in June 1985. When meeting on the model food standards regulation it put out several proposals. Proposal 3 (b) states:
Brandy shall-
(i) have been matured in wooden containers for not less than 2 years.
Proposal 5 (e) states:
Whisky shall be matured in wooden containers for not less than 2 years.
Proposal 6 (b) states:
Rum shall be matured in wooden containers for not less than 2 years.

So we have a fairly consistent pattern. Those bodies that looked at the model food standards regulation agreed that the requirement of maturation in wood for two years be retained. Of course, the model food standards, have progressed since June 1985 to the point where, for example, the South Australian Government has accepted them, other State governments have them under consideration and I believe that a number of State governments are due to accept them. I think it is fairly important to this debate that we note that the intent behind the model food standards is to get agreement between the Commonwealth and the States on a regulatory and uniform system with regard to a whole range of food matters. One problem that has bedevilled our Federation has been this difficulty of getting the general agreement of all those various governments on really essential items. This item, for example, has received constant attention at constitutional conventions and it has been agreed.

The food standards which I have just read out include in the definition of brandy, whisky and rum the essential ingredient, as part of the definition, that they be matured for two years. This problem is a multi-faceted one. One area is precisely that-the notion of the definition of those spirits. I remind honourable senators that when settlers first came to Western Australia, they looked at the black birds floating on the water and decided that they were not swans, because swans, by definition, were white. Later, it was accepted that we could have black swans. So there is an ingredient in this debate of the question about whether or not the maturation in wood for two years is an essential part of the definition of rum, whisky or brandy. If we look at the international situation, we see that an almost universal position is taken. Indeed, those various spirits are generally defined as requiring a two-year maturation period. Obviously there is an arbitrariness in the definition so it is possible to have a spirit named whisky, brandy or rum which has not matured for two years.

The situation that applies currently in Australia, and has applied up to this date, is that any product which is sold as whisky, brandy or rum must have had two years maturation. There are a considerable number of imported rums in Australia, although the major one comes from Puerto Rico and is marketed under the brand name of Bacardi. It is a white mixer rum that has been extremely successful on the Australian market. It is imported non-matured and is matured in Australia. The operation is covered by customs and hence we are able to know very clearly that all rums on the market have had the two-year maturation period.

At one stage the major distiller of rum in Australia-the Bundaberg rum company-put out a white rum which was singularly unsuccessful in the market. I am not quite sure why that was because I do not drink the stuff. When one looks at the marketing strategies of the Bundaberg distillery one could not but be amazed at how it managed to allow Bacardi to get into our market and to take the major proportion of our white rum market. It is a pity that, having the most efficient sugar cane producers in the world, and hence the cheapest sugar cane, we allowed somebody from halfway around the world whose liquor is based on sugar cane to export to Australia. I find this inconceivable. The reason probably stems much more from the marketing strategies of that company than the product itself.

I turn to where the industry stands currently. Senator Grimes, by way of interjection when Senator Jessop was speaking before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, said that he thought that the Wine and Brandy Producers Association was in favour of the Government's legislation. This is somewhat of a difficulty because the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association is opposed to the legislation but the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers Association of Australia is in favour of the legislation, so I suppose Senator Grimes may get one out of two, at least.

In my State there are two rum distillers-Bundaberg and Beenleigh. Bundaberg wishes to retain the two-year maturation period and Beenleigh wishes it to go. In other words, Beenleigh is in favour of the Government's proposal. It should be clearly said that both sides have relatively clear vested interests. In recent years Bundaberg has invested very heavily in new vats and hence is very interested in retaining the maturation requirement because of the investment it has made. At the time that this legislation was being discussed Beenleigh was broke and had no money to put into buying vats and hence it has a very clear vested interest in having the maturation level removed. I am not at all sure that we should make a decision on that matter.

I would also like to point out that this piece of legislation will not come into force until 1 April 1990 under section 26. The Government has been cognisant of the fact that, particularly because of the downturn in the brandy industry-presumably Senator Messner, who will follow me, has some interest in this matter-companies are currently holding stocks equivalent to four years sales by volume. That is extraordinary. The normal period is about two years but there has been a significant downturn in sales and companies have stock maturing for four years. If one adds four years that brings it to 1990 so obviously the Government has been cognisant of the situation in the industry and has sought to make sure that there can be a phasing-in operation. I certainly commend to governments that when they draw up legislation they take those matters into account. The more alarmist notions in some of the things that Senator Jessop said cannot necessarily be substantiated, particularly the types of problems that may occur with grape intake. If one saw the commercial brandy operations playing themselves out, the natural course of events would be that the companies involved would offload their brandy year by year over the next four years. They would not necessarily seek to take in any grapes until the third year if they wished to get entirely out of the market. That economic problem has to be faced with regard to not only brandy in South Australia but also rum in Queensland.

Another matter which I must address with regard to this piece of legislation is the market-place and how it may react. I emphasised to the people who made representations to me on this matter that the Australian Democrats are a free enterprise party. We believe that the market-place and the way it operates should not be excessively cluttered up by regulations unless there are good reasons. There were a number of good reasons in this area, one of which is consumer protection. In other words, the consumer knows what he is buying. I refer again to Senator Jessop's colourful phrase that people were buying jungle juice or some other type of cane spirits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose colourful phrase was that?

—I did mention it but Senator Jessop entered it into the record. The consumer, provided he knew what he was buying, would be in a position to make a distinction between non-matured brandy, wine or rum and matured brandy, wine or rum. That again raises the first question I asked as to whether we should allow somebody to market a product called unmatured rum or whether we should keep the word `rum' purely for the product which is matured and come up with a different name for the other. I am more familiar with rum. It would be possible for the Bacardi firm to market a product called Bacardi. It would not have the word `rum' on the label and I am quite sure that it would maintain its share of the market. When one has worked through the myriad of arguments one sees that people on either side seem to be pushing a case which is exaggerated. One finds it difficult, as my party in its deliberations ultimately found, to see what types of distinctions one ought to rely on with regard to clause 27 in particular. Our final position in favour of not voting for clause 27 was determined by the model food standards debate.
—Sold out Queensland again.
—The honourable senator should listen instead of having a good wine, brandy or rum. I said that the Australian Democrats will vote against clause 27.
—Don't be modest.
—It must have been a good dinner.
—You haven't been drinking too much and you ought to be commended.

—I acknowledge the interjection. It is the first one I have had from Senator Boswell for quite some time. Our position was determined by the extraordinary situation that the Government will find itself in with regard to the model food standards. The South Australian Government has already accepted the model food standards and other States are rapidly proceeding to do so. We cannot get uniformity of standards unless the Commonwealth co-operates. The Commonwealth, which has absolute power with regard to imports, is an essential ingredient in the whole exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems at this stage to be no good reason to pursue this matter but good reason to leave it alone. Pursuing this line would create further confusion and concern within the State governments that are moving towards and have agreed to adopt these standards. I raise this political problem with which obviously the Federal Government would be confronted: South Australia, with its brandy industry, and Queensland, with its rum industry, I am quite sure would find it very difficult politically, even with the best will in the world, to co-operate and change those model food standards in the light of the industries in those States. Being even-handed, I have selected a Labor government and a National Party government. That would be the case for obvious political reasons that all members of this chamber well know about. I do not think those State governments could co-operate with the Federal Government in this matter, hence we would find ourselves back where we were before we had general acceptance by the States of the propositions put to them by the Commonwealth in regard to those model food standards. From the analysis and research we have been able to do I do not think it is a matter of great moment. I must admit that that analysis really turns on trying to counter-guess what might be some commercial decisions made by companies, and if those companies made particular commercial decisions there could be a very significant economic impact, particularly on grape growers. As I say, that would really be to try to counter-guess the commercial decisions made by those companies, and it is somewhat difficult to know precisely what they would do because most of those companies have products well established in the market which require maturation.

As I put it to the people who are making representations to me, presumably these products have a niche in the market not simply on the basis of advertising but on the basis of taste, consumer support and consumer preference. Hence the companies would not make any wholesale commercial decision to get out of that product of maturation and go into some other product; they would remain with the matured product and probably attempt more vigorously to sell that product. In terms of the general way the market operates, with a bit of vigorous selling, that product ought to be able to retain its market share. So I do not really foresee a wholesale desertion from those various product areas, simply because that does not seem to me to be the way the companies operate, or the way a company would operate with regard to a well-known brand in the retail market.

Our decision has been influenced heavily by the confusion that would arise as a result of abandoning those standards-for no good reason, as we see it. We believe that the commercial disadvantage certain companies see if this measure is defeated also will not flow on. I believe those companies that have good brand names can simply drop the words `rum', `brandy' and `whisky' from their labels and not be in contra- vention of any State labelling laws and hence be able to sell their product under their copyright brand name, such as Bacardi in relation to rum.

I feel that, on balance, the maturation levels ought to be maintained for those products called whisky, brandy and rum and that that be in a settled context, in that we maintain conformity with those countries around the world that see themselves as having a stake in any one of those particular products. I refer to the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, which has provided Australia with a great deal of its rum. That country maintains maturation levels and Scotland, with its whisky, maintains maturation levels. So those countries that have a product they wish to promote and sell around the world have maintained those maturation levels. It seems to me that that is where we ought to stay, and that the new range of products now available, which can be produced chemically without maturation and without the injurious effects that such a process previously had, can also be promoted and obtain a market share in a free market being sold as some other type of drink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President--
—Is this a meeting of the brandy club?

—Yes, this is the first meeting of the brandy committee on this very important matter. I would like first of all to address myself to some of the other aspects of this legislation. I refer initially to the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, which covers a number of matters affecting bounties in respect of computers, high alloy steel products, ships, agricultural tractors and equipment, commercial motor vehicles, metal working machines and robots, and grain harvesters and equipment. I indicate that the Opposition has no difficulty with the amendments being proposed in the legislation, and we do not intend to oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is just one matter, though, that I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate and which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) might be able to explain in the course of winding up the second reading debate. I refer to the subsidy for grain harvesters and equipment. The intention of the legislation is to amend the principal Act to close a loophole relating to the sale price used for inflating bounty claims. As I understand it, if an item-say a grain harvester-is sold by a manufacturer to a dealer in such a way that it later sits unsold on the floor of the dealer's showroom but becomes depreciated in terms of its value in the marketplace, and there is subsequently a need to discount the price of that grain harvester in order to effect a sale and the dealer decides to take that up with the manufacturer and obtain a rebate or a discount from him on the original price of the goods, then the bounty that was paid earlier to the manufacturer of the grain harvester would be adjusted by claiming back from the manufacturer that part of the discount or rebate that has been granted to the dealer. That is certainly a reasonable proposition, but it seems to me that seeking to amend the legislation in this way, bearing in mind that a considerable time could elapse after the vehicle is first sold to the dealer and then sold to the customer, might mean that the bounty could be quite easily avoided in some other way by dealers getting into cahoots with the manufacturers and receiving discounts in another form. One does not have to be too clever to work out how that might be done. I am concerned that, if the Government's intention is to close this loophole, this may not be an effective means of doing it. I would like to hear the Minister's comments in that respect.

I turn to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. That involves two matters, one of which concerns inwards duty free concessions. I can see that Senator Puplick can hardly hold himself back as he wants to speak on this matter. As honourable senators will recall, the Opposition opposed the original legislation in respect of duty free shopping. This amendment will exclude from excise duty locally produced excisable items that are sold in inward duty free shops. In view of the fact that this arrangement is in place, we have no objection to it as Australian domestic producers would be penalised if this amendment were not to be enacted.

The other matter in this Bill which deserves some comment relates to the excise concessions in respect of vice-regal purchases of excisable items such as tobacco, alcohol and so on for private use. The Opposition feels that this is a reasonable proposition because, as the original proposals were enacted many years ago in circumstances where vice-regal persons came from Britain rather than having been born in Australia, these kinds of concessions were necessary to attract people to Australia to perform those duties. I stress that apparently these concessions will be removed not from excisable items purchased for official purposes but only from excisable items purchased for the private consumption of those persons. Consequently the Opposition does not oppose that measure.

The other Bill with which the House is dealing is the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, which touches on several matters, mainly of a technical nature, to which we have no objection. There are amendments to the Coal Excise Act and to the Customs Act affecting protected cultural objects, and other amendments relating to ships' stores, the power to detain and search suspected persons and so on. However, the most important aspect of this legislation is the amendments in clauses 25 to 27, which seek to remove the maturation requirements in respect of spirits-whisky, rum and brandy-produced within Australia. This topic was well covered by Senator Macklin in his contribution to this debate. Indeed, I was pleased that he came to a similar conclusion to that of the Opposition in seeking to remove from the Bill the clauses which seek to omit that important maturation provision.

I wish to make two or three points in connection with the brandy industry in particular in South Australia as that is a most important part of the wine and grape industry in my State. It should be recognised that the brandy industry does not exist by itself but relies on the grape and wine industry. It is significant that for many years the wine and grape industry was able to take care of itself. It would look after surpluses of grapes produced in bumper years by distilling that material into spirit, which later could be used in the manufacture of brandy and fortifying spirit for ports and so on.

The brandy industry in a sense is a safety valve for excess production in the wine and grape industry. As such it cannot be severed from the wine and grape industry. If in some years there is a tendency for the brandy industry not to be accorded the same high regard in the market that it is accorded in other years, its capacity to take care of the surplus production in the grape industry is diminished. Consequently there will be economic effects which will tend to put more pressure on governments to take care of the problems of the wine and grape industry in certain areas. That is a fundamental point that must be recognised. The brandy industry is a means by which the industry as a whole can look after itself rather than rely on Government support. This is recognised by the granting of a concessional rate of excise for Australian-made brandy. We in South Australia fully support that measure which was reinstated by the Fraser Government in, I think, 1982.

If brandy production is to become a recognised and powerful industry with a capacity to sell it products in the market-place, and thereby help out the wine and grape industry, it must be highly regarded and must have a future and the potential to grow. The industry has divergent views as to how that can be achieved. Those who are engaged in the production of quality brandy are concerned about the removal of the maturation requirement of two years. On the other hand, others tend to produce what might be called the lesser quality brandies and are interested in developing alternative markets and products. Many people are seeking to break into new product developments by virtue of the abolition of the two-year maturation requirement.

The Minister adverted to this topic in his second reading speech. He said clearly that the Government was contemplating that brandy manufacturers would be able to use this new provision which would emerge as a result of the passage of this legislation to produce new products which could be marketed all over Australia but which would take advantage of the brandy excise laws and would not be required to be matured in wood for two years. It is his view, and it is probably the view of some parts of the brandy production industry, that that is one way of expanding the market for brandy-like substitutes.

However, I must at this point draw the Senate's attention to the comments of the National Health and Medical Research Council, which has considered the definition of brandy over a long period. I have the report of a meeting of a working party of the Council, established to review the standards for wine, spirits and liqueurs, which met back in 1980. It determined:

. . . that the nature of brandy required that it be matured in wood for at least 2 years. The product not matured for the required period in wood could not be designated as `brandy' because it would not possess the taste, aroma and characteristics . . .

The working party went on to say that, whilst the Industries Assistance Commission might have a sound point of view on the subject of deregulation and considered that the maturation provision could be deleted for certain spirits, `the Working Party agreed that brandy was not one of these spirits'. The point is clearly made that the National Health and Medical Research Council felt that brandy is only brandy when subject to the maturation requirement of two years. By the way, the working party at that stage decided that the requirement for two years maturation should be retained by the Government.

What are the effects of allowing a situation to develop in which the product is not brandy in the real sense of the word? From all the divergent comments I have heard, I have formed the view that the majority of the industry is in favour of the retention of the maturation requirement because the Government's move is seen as premature. There is no attempt to protect the quality market by ensuring that labelling requirements are put into place, whether they are conducted by the States or otherwise. Nor are there requirements that proper testing and certification procedures be adopted by importers of brandy from overseas.

It is quite clear that that set of considerations is well in the forefront of the minds of distillers in South Australia. The Adelaide News of 2 May indicates that there is concern in the industry that brandy brewed in illegal stills could be sold in South Australia and could pose enormous health threats to South Australians. These views are not necessarily supported by the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association. However, I notice that Mr Nettlebeck, who is the Executive Director of that association, is quoted in the Adelaide News as saying that jobs might be threatened as a result of brandy makers adjusting stocks for the changeover regarding the maturation period. Certainly less brandy would be put into wood and stored for later use. I believe that to be a very important consideration in terms of South Australia. Certainly the Riverland areas of South Australia are subject to very violent fluctuations in market conditions. It does not seem to be reasonable that, at a time like this when protection from imports is not being given to the brandy industry, we should be seeking to reduce the industry's capacity in this way. This move is premature without proper safeguards as to labelling being put in place to protect the industry.

During the Committee stage of the debate the Opposition will be moving to defeat clauses 25, 26 and 27, or Part VI of the Bill, which amends the Spirits Act by removing the maturation requirement for brandy. I have set forth our reasons for so doing and believe that they are soundly based. They have the support of the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association which represents the majority of producers in this country. I believe that my colleagues will support this stand. I am looking to some of the Queensland Liberal Party and National Party senators to discuss other aspects of the maturation problem as it affects, in particular, the rum industry in the sugar cane growing areas of Queensland. I am sure that Senator MacGibbon will be speaking forcefully on that matter. I conclude by reiterating the point that the Opposition will be opposing the removal of the maturation requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1986. The purposes of this Bill have been dealt with already by a number of honourable senators. I do not intend to debate the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, particularly as it affects brandy, whisky and rum, as I think those aspects have been adequately covered by Senator Jessop and Senator Messner, supported on this occasion by Senator Macklin on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I presume that the force of their collective argument gives a new interpretation to the phrase `in vino veritas'. I confine my remarks to the clauses of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill which go to the question of inward duty free shopping. Doubtless the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will be reasonably unsurprised to hear that this is a matter to which I wish to direct my attention, in exactly the same way as undoubtedly my friends from the Department will regard my views on inward duty free shopping as the continuation of a long and boring saga with which we have all been intimately concerned for some considerable time.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, clause 6 of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill makes certain changes which are consequential upon the insertion in other Acts of the permission to establish inward duty free shopping at Australian international airports. The clause inserts a new item, No. 21, into the Schedule of tariffs as a consequence of the introduction of inward duty free shops at international airports in Australia, legislation for which was approved late last year. The proposed item will remove the excise duty on excisable airport shop goods, particularly alcoholic liquor and tobacco products purchased at these shops, provided that the quantities of such goods, in combination with customable airport shop goods, do not exceed one litre of alcoholic liquor or 250 grams of tobacco products.

The first inward duty free shopping facility was opened recently, on 1 May. On that date the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) issued a Press release to indicate that he had been involved in the opening of the first inward duty free facility at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I do not want to traverse in detail the nature of the contracts let for the extension of inward duty free shopping to existing concessionaires at Australian airports other than to say that I regard it as an absolute disgrace for the Government to have taken this step without calling competitive tenders for the provision of this service. After all, if people who had known that inward duty free shopping would be introduced as of 1 May 1986 had been in possession of that evidence when in May 1984 they were required to submit their tenders for five-year contracts for the operation of duty free facilities at airports such as Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, they would have drawn their tenders quite differently.

Existing concessionaires have been given an additional benefit, essentially at the expense of their competitors in a very cut-throat market which their competitors were not in a position to bid for when those concessions were introduced. I note the arrival in the chamber of my friend Senator Button, a person intimately familiar with the operation of the inward duty free shopping industry. Undoubtedly he understands the fundamental unfairness of this situation. That is undoubtedly one of the reasons he fought so hard against the introduction of inward duty free shopping when he was presenting his Cabinet submissions. Unfortunately, as with the fringe benefits tax on cars, he was monumentally rolled by those who have more Cabinet authority than he.

Nevertheless, the Minister for Aviation, in his Press release of 1 May, applauded the introduction of the inward duty free arrangement, which is now being assisted by the provisions to which I have already adverted in clause 6 of this legislation. He made some quite extraordinary claims about the benefits flowing to airlines and passengers from the introduction of inward duty free shopping. In the course of my speech I propose to indicate once again why I believe that the airlines and certainly the shopping and travelling public do not gain the benefits alleged by the Government. The Minister in his Press release alleged that airlines will save about $1m a year in fuel costs. Aeroplanes are supposed to weigh less because people will not bring duty free liquor, tobacco or perfume-the three items which are to be sold at inward duty free facilities-on to aeroplanes with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did they arrive at that figure?

—Senator MacGibbon is right in asking how they arrived at this figure. If one goes to the report of the Industries Assistance Commission entitled `Passenger Concessions' dated 6 November 1985, one sees that at page 85 under the heading `Fuel and other Savings by Airlines' it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Retailers' Association said that, if 80 passengers on a 747 deferred purchases of their liquor and tobacco entitlements, the total weight reduction would be 144 kg or 0.05 per cent of the weight of the aircraft (around 275 tonnes). Qantas has estimated that for 1985-86 potential fuel savings would be in the order of $450,000.
The Commission goes on to state:
A number of participants denied that such fuel savings were significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that 144 kilograms?

—It was 144 kilograms, or 0.05 per cent of the weight of the aircraft. In order to get to that, one has to assume, firstly, that people will not seek to purchase tobacco or perfume at overseas destinations when they know that a number of tobacco and perfume products are simply not available in Australia. For instance, one of the most popular female cosmetics brands, Clarins, is not permitted under the terms of its franchise agreements to be sold duty-free in Australia. So anybody who wishes to purchase that particular brand of cosmetic duty-free must buy it overseas; it is unavailable in Australia at duty-free prices. People know things like that when they are shopping around for fairly expensive products. One has to believe, having seen the sorts of cigars, for instance, which are available duty-free in Australia-a totally limited and insufficient range-that people will not buy tobacco products overseas when they know that at duty-free stores at Australian airports the same range of goods is not available.

SPEECH.PARA: A significant item is alcohol. One has to believe that people will not buy alcoholic beverages overseas and consume them on the aeroplane-they are still entitled to buy them duty-free in Singapore and bring them on to the aeroplane-and then buy a replacement bottle when they get to the inward duty-free store in Sydney. But people will do that. After all, it is basically a long flight to Australian ports from anywhere other than Port Moresby or Auckland.

This matter was specifically referred to in a case in 1983 in the Federal Court of Australia entitled John Raymond Steiner and Lynne Janine Steiner v Magic Carpet Tours Pty Limited in which the judge, His Honour Mr Justice Wilcox, remarked on the extent to which there was a problem of people buying alcohol to consume during a flight and them repurchasing when they get off the aeroplane. So that matter has in fact been tested. I therefore repeat the point that I made when we were debating the introduction of inward duty-free shopping in Australia-that this is of no substantial benefit to the airline industry but certainly will have the effect of increasing Qantas's ability to sell liquor on board the aeroplane. What it will do is to carry extra liquor, sell it to the passengers on the aeroplane and tell them: `If you buy your liquor from the airline now and let us give it to you now, you will not have to get jammed up in the inward duty-free store when everybody else gets off the jumbo aircraft and tries to buy inward duty-free purchases between the point of disembarkation and the Customs barrier'. The inward duty-free store has to be located between those two points according to the terms of the legislation passed by the Parliament last year.

The next point I raise is that I am not yet persuaded that this is not simply a method by which the Government intends to reduce the overall level of concessions available to Australian travellers. An article in the Canberra Times of 29 April under the heading `Duty-free cuts expected' made it quite clear, as indeed has Senator Walsh on a number of previous occasions, that this Government intends to wind back on the level of concessions available to passengers from inward duty-free shopping.

I make the next point about the relative price charged at airports compared with the price charged by duty-free shops not located at airports. An article by Seth Gregory in the Sydney Morning Herald some time ago stated:

Say you are planning a trip to Hong Kong and you're in the market for a new camera. Your best first step is to price the camera in Australia before you leave. You can do this by visiting retail outlets, but it is much wiser to price it in city duty-free shops. (Forget the airport establishments; ours are just as expensive as those overseas).

It is simply true, as Choice magazine and others have pointed out, that the prices of goods at duty-free shops at airports, particularly the shop at Kingsford-Smith Airport, which is run by a foreign company, not an Australian company, are considerably higher--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are an absolute rip-off.

—As Senator MacGibbon said, it is an absolute rip-off in terms of the relative price of goods available. The Sydney Morning Herald on 29 April 1986, under a heading `Duty-free: where not to go broke saving money', an article by Gareth Powell, indicated that the off-airport duty-free shops in Australia are indeed the cheapest in the world. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: In duty-free, as in so many other things, Australia is once again the lucky country. Very probably the best duty-free bargains in the world are to be found in Australia. And some of the best duty-free bargains in Australia are to be found in Sydney.

Most of the credit for this splendid state of affairs lies with Sterling Nicholas Duty-Free which in 1969 took out a summons against the Federal Government. It saw no legal reason why it should not sell duty-free goods away from the airport. By April 1971 it was still seeking clarification from the NSW Supreme Court of the Airport (Business Concessions) Act.

It was not until 1972 when Senator Chipp, the then Minister for Customs-he was then the honourable member for Higinbotham-took the first steps to make off-airport duty-free legally available in Australia. It is the price at the off-airport duty-free shops which is outstandingly the benefit available to Australian duty-free travellers. The IAC, in the report to which I have already referred, at paragraph 7.4.3 indicated that there was an alternative approach if we were to go down the track of inward duty-free shopping. It states:

Some participants have put forward a scheme which they suggest would overcome some of these problems. This would allow intending travellers to purchase goods at Australian duty free shops before departure. The goods would then be held in bond until their return to Australia. Packages would be collected from a booth within the Customs area at the airport. It is claimed that this method would not provide the same security problems as a supermarket style duty free store-

I interpolate here to say that the IAC indicated in its report the paramount concerns expressed by the Australian Customs Service and all the witnesses who appeared before the IAC about the Customs and policing matters related to inward duty-free shopping. The report continued:

It is claimed that this method would not provide the same security problems as a supermarket style duty free store, and that, as passengers would not be delayed very long, it would overcome some of the passenger processing problems.
If the export objective of duty free shopping is abandoned in favour of maximising passengers' utilisation of import concessions, there would be little to criticise in such a proposal.
Let us bear in mind that at the end of a very exhaustive inquiry the IAC recommended:
The Commission therefore considers that passenger import concessions should not apply to goods purchased in Australia by arriving persons before they pass through the Customs barrier.

A number of duty-free operators in Sydney have approached the Australian Customs Service to seek permission to sell goods to passengers prior to their departure, to be collected by those passengers on their return. A letter addressed to one of the people making representations, Mr B. L. Cody, the senior assistant secretary of Inland Services, made the point that sub-section 96 (B) (3) of the Customs Act and sub-section 61 (E) (2) of the Excise Act prevent this from being done.

If this Government is serious about inwards duty free shopping, there is no reason that it could not make the necessary amendments to the Customs Act and the Excise Act to allow a person departing Australia to make a purchase at a competitive price at an off-airport duty free store and on return to Australia collect his or her goods from a booth located between the point of disembarkation and the Customs barrier, in order to have it properly verified that the goods had been through the process of inwards duty free and had not been entered for home consumption. I put it to honourable senators that the Government is not prepared to go down that track for no reason other than some very much unexplained deals which have been made involving the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and the airlines, in particular Qantas.

It is about time that people started to realise that the primary beneficiaries of this whole inwards duty free proposal are foreign companies which were granted concessions for a five-year period, without mention of their access to inwards duty free shopping, in the face of competition from Australian companies who would have put in different tenders if they had known that inwards duty free shopping was going to be introduced. If the Australian companies had not believed that the clear recommendation of the IAC against inwards duty free shopping would weigh heavily with the Government, we would be looking at an entirely different situation. I put it to honourable senators that this legislation to give effect to the operation of inwards duty free shopping in relation to the decision already made by this Parliament on this matter, with the support of the Australian Democrats-except Senator Haines, who voted with the Opposition against this legislation-has led to a situation where not only has the IAC expressed concerns about loss of revenue, loss of security and the general undesirability of inwards duty free shopping, but also Australian travellers are being ripped off by Government dictate on the question of inwards duty free shopping.

Although it is not possible to go back at this stage to undo that damage to the rights of the travelling public in Australia, which I hope the next Liberal-National Party Government will be able to rectify, nevertheless it is worth making the point, which I shall continue to do whenever such Bills are before the Senate, that this Government is involved in a massive financial rip-off of the Australian travelling public by this inwards duty free proposal which it has put into place, I suggest, not only in defiance of the IAC and contrary to the views clearly expressed by Senator Button and the more rational members of the Cabinet, but by an entirely reprehensible deal done between the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Qantas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. I wish to confine my remarks to the clauses 25, 26 and 27 of Part VI of the latter Bill. I will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Messner to delete those clauses from the Bill because they are clearly against the interests of the Australian industry and the country as a whole. That Part of the Bill provides that the compulsory maturation requirements, that spirits be held for several years in bond before sale to the public, be deleted. The proposal is that this be phased out between now and 1 April 1990. Having read the debate in the House of Representatives and the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), one can say that the Government has argued its case very poorly and completely unconvincingly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's reason for the termination of this maturation turns on two points. Firstly, the Government walks away and says that there is State and Territory legislation covering the maturation of spirits. That happens to be true, but it is also absolutely irrelevant. While legislation exists at the moment in all States of Australia requiring spirits to have some maturation, once the Commonwealth abandons that requirement, one State will move to delete it from its statute book. It will do that because all States license the sale of spirituous and fermented liquors and derive income from the licenses they grant to the selling points for spirits. The money that the States get is proportional to the volume of sales made.

Since section 92 of the Constitution provides that the trade between the States shall be free and unfettered, one State will move to delete maturation requirements before the others so that it can sell liquor, probably imported liquor, which will move interstate from that one point of sale. There will be a short term profit for the Treasury of that State as a consequence of this Bill. Very rapidly all the other States will move down the same path and we will have a situation nationwide where there is no requirement to mature spirits. It would be a situation very similar to the licensing of pornographic television films; a path which the Australian Labor Party took us down, with the support of a few other people around here, some years ago. It was done for the Australian Capital Territory, but as soon as it was allowed into the Australian Capital Territory pornographic films spread throughout the whole of Australia without any method of control. The Government's first argument is the fact that the States and Territories have legislation on the books. Clearly this legislation is ephemeral and will not stand up to the test of time.

The second argument that the Government puts forward is that it is a resort to market forces. I applaud Senator Walsh and the other members of the Australian Labor Party who have discovered some of the facts of commercial life. Regrettably, the commercial market-place is now far more sophisticated than the Government's concept of it. What the Government is proposing here, when it glibly talks about resorting to market forces to sort out the spirits market, is really a return to unbridled eighteenth century capitalism. The Government has a responsibility, while moving to lift the oppressive load of regulation on the community, to maintain the interests and standards of the community. The Government cannot run away from its responsibilities with respect to spirits. The Government has a responsibility to maintain standards. It has a health responsibility. Cheap liquor is by definition bad liquor. In the past couple of months we have seen the business in the Austrian wine market. It is very easy in a fermentation process to end up with methyl alcohol instead of ethyl alcohol. Ethyl alcohol in large enough quantities will kill, but methyl alcohol in very small quantities will send a man blind-and kill him. There is a very real public health factor involved in maintaining the standards of spirits.

The Government's second responsibility is with respect to employment. The spirit industry directly employs quite a few people in Australia, but it indirectly employs quite a lot more. The third responsibility of the Government lies in the balance of payments. By killing off the spirit industry in Australia we will open up the spirit market in this country to imports and that will contribute significantly to our balance of payments problem. More than that, it will deny us any opportunity of export earnings in the future because some sections of the Australian spirit industry produce a very high quality product which can expect to have significant overseas sales in the years to come.

This Bill will undoubtedly open up the floodgates for spirits coming in from overseas. In the worst possible case we will get massive importation of what might be termed bar mix spirits. If one does not worry about quality, it is very easy just to mix alcohol with a cordial-something to give it a bit of colour-and a few of the aromatic fractions to simulate the spirit involved. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that happens all the time when one goes into a bar and asks for a whisky and soda, a brandy and dry ginger ale, or a gin and tonic. There is a row of taps and from these taps comes the soda water and cordial. They pour a measure of spirits into the glass, then go to the tonic tap or the dry ginger ale tap and some tasteless fluid gets squirted into the glass. What one gets is a cordial mixed with carbonated water to give the mix for those spirits. The same process, reduced to its simplest form, can be done for spirits. The Australian market would be opened up to spirits produced in that synthetic way and we would also be opened up to a massive flood of imports from countries that have surpluses. The first countries to think about are the countries in the European Common Market, with their well known wine lake. They have more wine than they can ever sell. If the Australian market were opened up, as this Bill seeks to do, the Europeans would distil a lot of that wine and without maturing it flood the Australian brandy market. The same sort of thing would happen with respect to South American producers. Brazil in particular has a huge alcohol industry based on cane sugar. It is dumping, at present, a huge amount of alcohol onto the United States domestic market, mainly for the gasocol program for their motor spirit. Certainly some of that would be available to be distilled across or mixed up and sent out to Australia as rum. Of course, we have the notorious Thai merchants mixing any sort of spirits or alcoholic beverage in back yards and producing it at a very low cost.

As previous speakers have said, all countries that are in the business of seriously producing spirits require maturation of those spirits. There is a period of three years for the maturation of scotch whisky in Scotland, and in a general sense-not exclusively-the requirement is for two years for other spirits. Australia has built up an industry producing spirits. The standard achieved, particularly with Bundaberg rum, which is the biggest selling spirit in Australia-it is bigger than any brand of scotch and certainly a lot bigger than any brandy-is producing a quality product. We can look forward to a considerable export market in the fullness of time for that high quality product. I believe that some of the brandies we produce in time will be sought after on world markets.

We have made an investment in capital and in skill here. The Bundaberg distillery and the brandy producers have been at this for generations and they have put a lot of time into learning the skills and procedures necessary to produce these products. They have also invested a lot of time and capital in developing markets. We cannot get on the intensely competitive international market overnight and sell a product, whether it is a rum or a brandy. Having made this investment in time, it is silly to throw it away by bringing in a Bill such as this. I am amazed at the way we go into new industries in this country, invest hundreds of millions of dollars-or even a billion dollars in some of the defence offset programs. We train people, invest all this money in the capital facility, and then walk away from it.

In my own State there is a company called North Queensland Engineers and Agents. We gave it a contract to build 14 patrol boats. It became the best ship-builder in Australia, building a very complex ship to the contract price and to the contract time. The skilled work force was in excess of 650 people. The contract came to an end and the whole yard collapsed. The work force probably fell to 200. I do not know what the company is now doing-probably doing odd job work. Here was an excellent industrial facility we had built up, and through lack of foresight and lack of planning by the Government there was no continuity of work for it. I fear that much the same situation is going to happen with respect to the spirit industry if this Bill passes.

I do not know why the Government went down this path in the face of all the advice against it that it received from the industry. All I can assume is that the Government was lobbied so intensively by importers that it felt that the best thing to do was to kill off the Australian industry. One of the principal lobbyists, I am informed, is the Bacardi company. Although Senator Macklin said that that company is importing from Puerto Rico, my advice is that it is producing the rum that it imports to Australia from Mexico. It may be transferred through Puerto Rico from a sales point of view, but the same company, Bacardi, has huge factories in South America producing synthetic products and things like that. It will certainly be one of the beneficiaries of the abolition of this market.

One of the other arguments that are advanced against the maturation program is that, because the product is held for two years and because millions of dollars are involved in the warehousing and the vats, there is very considerable on-cost to the spirits that are matured and somehow or other we are being kind to the consumer and saving him money by getting rid of this maturation program. The exact cost of maturation is difficult to establish, but it is recognised within the industry to be no more than 30c a bottle. When one thinks that most of the products sell for at least $12 a bottle-maybe $15 a bottle-the amount of 30c a bottle is really minuscule, it is not a high on-cost. For those who doubt that figure, the simple test is to look at the retail price of matured spirits of Australian origin against the comparable price of the white spirits such as gin and vodka. The price differential does not operate against rum or brandy. In fact, it is the other way round. Australian rum is cheaper than Australian gin or vodka. The real reason for that is that retail prices are controlled by the volume sales and the volume sales for rum are higher than for Australian gin or vodka.

While the individual cost per bottle is quite moderate, we have to remember that the companies producing brandy, rum and whisky in Australia have made very big investments with respect to buying oak for the vats and being able to store tens of thousands of gallons of the product for the two-year period and building the warehouses for them. Those facilities, if there is no maturation period, are lost. They are not commercially usable for any other products because they are on vineyards or in rum distilleries. The companies made that investment not of their own volition entirely but because the law requires them to do that.

While I am talking about spirits I want to go back to a point I referred to some years ago in the Senate. The Government has a responsibility with respect to alcohol and public health. I am not a prohibitionist in any way at all; I enjoy alcohol in its various forms, but I recognise that alcohol is a major public drug problem. The consumption of alcohol, particularly alcoholic spirits, by young people-by people who are starting to drink-worries me. I believe that the Government has a responsibility in this area. When my Party was in power I argued that it had an obligation, from a public health point of view, to direct people towards the less dangerous forms of alcohol; put simply, towards beer rather than towards spirits.

I deplore the tendency of the younger generation to drink white wine on an empty stomach. A generation before people would have drunk a glass of beer. What is even worse is the tendency of the generation just starting to drink to drink bland spirits such as vodka or Bacardi with mixers-dry ginger ale, or coke. They do not taste the alcohol in the drink. They exceed a safe level of alcohol intake through ignorance and through not being able to taste these bland spirits.

I think the actions of the Bacardi company are quite criminal. Its slick television advertising of the White Light, the illusions between the White Light and the Star Wars theme-Luke Starwalker and all the rest of it-is an incitement to the young to drink Bacardi and Coke. I think that is criminally negligent. I would much rather see young people drinking beer, particularly the low alcohol beers, because beer is the drink of moderation. It is very hard to build up a high blood-alcohol level quickly with beer because of its volumetric capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they have to drink at all, that is.

—Quite right. I thank the honourable senator for that point. I do not want what I am saying to be interpreted to mean in any way at all that I am inciting people to drink. I think that is a very good point made by Senator McKiernan. I do feel very strongly that the Government has a responsibility and that it can manifest its responsibility by making a significant excise differential favouring beer as opposed to spirits. I think spirits are rather cheap in Australia when compared with world prices and at the same time Australian beer is among the dearest in the world. When other senators and I were a lot younger we could go and have quite a few beers for a pound. One can only have about one beer for a dollar today and the major part of that cost is the excise the Government takes. The Government has a responsibility to cut down on excise on beer.

SPEECH.PARA: I also think that the Government ought to be involved in public education programs, that if people are going to drink they ought to be taught to start in moderation-in fact, to finish in moderation. The Opposition will oppose Part VI of the Bill because we believe it will not operate for the benefit of Australia. I will confine my further remarks on this Bill to the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia support the legislation that is going through the Senate but oppose clauses 25, 26 and 27 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. The coalition disagrees with the inclusion of these clauses because they will remove the requirement of a maturation period of two years for brandy, whisky and rum. In Queensland we do not have any brandy producers or whisky producers. There used to be a Corio whisky manufactured in Victoria, around Corio Bay. I have not seen that whisky on the market for some time. We have two rum distillers in Queensland. One is Beenleigh Rum Pty Ltd, which I think now produces only small quantities of rum, and the other is Bundaberg Distilling Co. Pty Ltd, which is the largest producer of rum in Australia. It produces 60 per cent of all the rum consumed in Australia, including the imported products. It produces 30 per cent of all the Australian manufactured distillable spirits and produces and markets the largest selling individual spirit in Australia-as Senator MacGibbon said, its sales of spirit are greater than the sales of brandy, whisky or any other type of spirit.

SPEECH.PARA: If this legislation were to go through the Senate without amendment we would see an influx of cane spirit, which is really raw ethanol, with a bit of artificial colouring and a bit of flavouring being sold as rum. I believe we would see imports into Australia of `fire water' from every country which produces a sugar cane crop. Tahiti, the Philippines and Mauritius would all be able to distil rum from their sugar crop, or even from potatoes and grain. From other crops such as carrots and turnips they would be able to distil ethanol spirit. It would not be rum. It would just be a raw spirit with colouring and flavouring.

These cheap imports would be branded `rum'. They would be heavily promoted through television and radio-no doubt we would see young girls in bathing suits and young men in fun situations sitting around enjoying this raw spirit-and would be sold at the same price as rum or less. Its price would be able to include a heavy advertising component and still compete with our pure rum, brandy and whisky. These carefully orchestrated marketing and advertising campaigns would erode the sale of Queensland rum made out of Queensland sugar, at a time when the sugar industry is in a perilous state and is receiving little help from this Government. The sugar industry will receive a mere $63m or less over a period of three years, when it was promised $150m in the Kerin aid package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put a bit of thirst into your argument.

—Senator McKiernan should stick to comments about Western Australia because he does not understand the sugar industry. I do not accept his interjection. The Kerin package promised $150m but it was reduced to $20m a year. This Government has now brought in legislation which will further sell out the sugar industry by reducing the sale of sugar, particularly around the Bundaberg area where $6m worth at the factory level, and many more millions of dollars worth at the retail level of Bundaberg rum is produced. Of course, if this legislation comes to fruition, many tonnes of sugar cane sales will be lost in the Bundaberg area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting to note that the Bundaberg Distilling Co. pays this Government over $60m a year in excise and sales tax. That is more than the Government is prepared to offer to the ailing sugar cane industry. The Government collects from the Bundaberg Distilling Co. $60m in excise and taxes and in the Kerin package it is prepared to give only $20m a year-one-third of that $60m excise collected-over a period of three years. That is all that it is prepared to give to help the desperate sugar industry which, through no fault of its own, is being put through hell.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fault rests with the Queensland Government.
—The fault is not that of the Queensland Government.
—The Queensland Government's regimentation is the cause of it.

—Senator Walsh has been reprimanded today by the Chair. I hope that that will not happen again. The Kerin plan promised $150m to the sugar cane industry. That figure was reduced in actual terms to about $63m, which is $20m a year over three years, despite the fact that this Federal Government has obtained $60m-it is probably a little more than $60m now-from the Bundaberg Distilling Company.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Walsh is really interested in the sugar industry, I will tell him what the Queensland Government has put into it over the past two or three years. It has put in $20m in rural adjustment, $32m to the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, $14m in co-operative loans to sustain the co-operative sugar milling companies, $6m in interest subsidies, $20m from loans at an interest rate of 4 per cent, and $11m in direct grants and interest subsidies. That is a total of $103m. The Federal Government has put in $15m. It should be ashamed of itself. On 6 April the sugar millers and growers passed a unanimous resolution that the responsibility for a support price plan was clearly that of the Federal Government. Mr Kerin has since said that unless the Queensland Government acknowledges that some of the money that was intended to be given was price support, the sugar cane growers will not receive anything. I do not believe that the Queensland Government will acknowledge that. It has played its role by contributing $101m against the Federal Government's $15m.

To get back to the problem in hand, if this legislation is passed unamended we will see the sale in the market of inferior spirits labelled as rum, whisky or brandy. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in his second reading speech said that this matter would be taken up by State laws. I do not understand how people who import brandy, rum or whisky can be stopped if they attempt to pass spirits across the borders of any State, allowing them into the retail chain. I am very grateful that the Australian Democrats have seen fit to support our proposed amendment. Therefore, the legislation will be amended. Thank goodness for that. It would be almost impossible to stop the sale of the inferior products. Rum, brandy and whisky have carved out a very substantial place in the market because of the way that they have been produced.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have contributed to my medical practice over the years.

—That is very good. Rum has been made in the same way for 400 years. Eliminating the maturation period would take away the profile and inherent flavour of rum. Some honourable senators have pointed out the cost of maturing rum in wooden vats. I make out the cost to be about 12c a bottle. Senator MacGibbon says that it is 30c a bottle. We will certainly not argue about 18c. That works out at about 1c a nip for people to drink a product that has been made in a certain way over a number of years. It certainly would be safer. The esters are absorbed by the wooden vats over the two years. It is then a much safer product.
—Safer for what?
—It is safer to drink-a much healthier product.
—It is unadulterated.

—It is unadulterated, as my colleague Senator Dr Peter Baume said. I looked at the Minister's second reading speech to see whether I could find a reason why he would want to remove the two-year maturation process. I cannot understand it. I would be very interested to listen to Senator Walsh explain it in his closing remarks. Some comments were made about deregulation. I thought that it was a pretty poor excuse to disrupt the liquor industry by allowing inferior imitations of distilled alcoholic products to take over a substantial market that has been established by the genuine product. Allowing imitations into this country under false labelling would wreck our sales of genuine brandy, whisky and rum products.

SPEECH.PARA: I still cannot understand why a government would go to the trouble of bringing in legislation that will wreck established industries that have been operating for a long time-in the case of the Bundaberg Distilling Company for about 98 years. Beenleigh rum has been on the market, not for 98 years, I think, but certainly for 50, 60 or probably 70 years. The Government has not thought of the ramifications of this legislation. It has not come up with the bottom line. It should encourage the manufacturers and distillers to produce premium high-grade products. I can nominate some of them. Black Bottle brandy is world class, and the famous Bundaberg rum is so labelled: It is a famous product. It is sold throughout Australia. The Government should encourage the pursuit of excellence. That is exactly the opposite of what this legislation will do. The Australian distillers will have to make a cheap, nasty product to compete with the short-cut methods of some of the lower market manufacturers and to compete with the cheaper imports that will come in, which earlier I called firewater. The Democrats have assured us that the proposal amended by Senator Messner will be carried. The people of north Bundaberg will be very happy that the clause will be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have not been present for the whole debate but I have heard bits of the last two or three speeches. Senator Puplick spoke about inwards duty-free shopping. Frankly, I could not understand what he was getting at; but I did not understand the contributions by Senator MacGibbon and Senator Boswell. The facts regarding removal of the Commonwealth requirement that spirits be matured in wood for two years are as follows. The Department of Health has advised the Government-the matter has been under consideration for about two years-that there is absolutely no health reason for the requirement to remain. As far as I know, nobody in the Opposition has disputed that as a health measure. The Opposition has embarked yet again on its penchant for regimenting society. It is particularly appropriate that Senator Boswell, who is a trenchant defender of the Government of Queensland, which is more heavily into the regimentation of people than any other government in Australia, should want to retain this provision. The simple truth is that the Opposition does not trust people. The Opposition does not believe that people should have what they want; it believes that people should have what the Opposition believes is good for them.
—They can have what they want as long as they do not label it rum or brandy.

—What we seek to do is to give people a choice. If they want to buy something that has a label on it which says that it is matured in wood for three years, 10 years or 150 years, like some of the members of the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia, they can buy that product and pay a price premium if they wish to do so, but if on the other hand people do not care the attitude of this Government is that they should be free to buy what they want. The attitude of the Opposition is that big brother will dictate to them that they will not be able to buy spirits unless they have been matured in wood for two years. It is yet another example of the fundamental conflict between the rhetoric of the Opposition and its practice. There have been a number of references to an amendment to be moved by the Opposition. My inquiries suggest that there is no amendment, or at least no amendment has been circulated. The Opposition proposes to vote against clauses 25, 26 and 27.
—We are just opposing the clauses.

—Senator Boswell kept talking about an amendment. Senator Messner cannot blame me if I am confused because I have been misled by one of his colleagues. As I understand it-apparently Senator Messner agrees-the Opposition proposes to vote against clauses 25, 26 and 27. Consumer behaviour will continue to be regimented if those clauses are not carried. If they are carried the Government's belief that people should be entrusted to make their own choices on this matter will prevail. Finally, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a telex received by Senator Button on 24 April from the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers Association of Australia Inc. This telex states that the Wine and Brandy Producers Co-operative supports the legislation that this Government has put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

GORDO AA80398
24th April 1986
Senator the Hon. J. N. Button,
Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce

Clauses 25 to 27-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate, as Opposition senators did earlier during the second reading stage, that the Opposition will be opposing clauses 25, 26 and 27 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. I think the reasons why we will be opposing these clauses have been made very clear. I am sorry that I was not in the chamber to hear Senator Boswell's contribution, because no doubt he would have drawn our attention to the very important changes that may occur in the rum industry in Queensland as a result of the removal of the maturation requirements. It will certainly have a very large effect in South Australia. At the end of the second reading debate the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) incorporated in Hansard a copy of a telex from the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers Association of Australia Inc. giving support to the Government's action. The Minister might be interested to know that that body certainly is an important organisation in South Australia but it does not represent all the brandy makers and it does not represent that group of brandy makers which is most likely to be affected by the removal of the maturation requirements. The Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association, which represents those people and many other producers as well, voted very clearly in opposition to the removal of the brandy maturation requirements. That can be placed on the record as well. I do not have a copy of the telex but I have certainly had personal conversations with members of that group. Earlier, in the second reading debate, I read from an article which appeared in the Adelaide News of 2 May which made it quite clear, as it quoted the Executive Director of that Association as saying that this may well cost jobs in the Riverland and in those areas in South Australia devoted to the brandy industry.
—As many as the free lunch abolition is going to cost?

—It was not specified by Mr Mettlebeck but it sounds as though the Government has not done its homework again. If it is interested in that question it might well contact that very important organisation and determine its attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: As I explained earlier, the brandy industry should not be seen as an industry separate from the wine and grape industry. I pointed out earlier that it is a safety valve for excess grape production as those grapes are turned into spirit and later into brandy. In that way, the wine and grape industry tends to look after itself rather than being forced into accepting government handouts in years of surplus production which cause market prices to fluctuate and fall and which bring difficulties to the industry, particularly in the area of job opportunities.

Brandy is a vital part of the overall South Australian grape and wine industries. I notice that South Australian back benchers on the Labor side of this chamber have not taken part in this debate and have not sought to put forward the views of their State. This is fairly typical. Whenever an issue of importance to the State comes up we find them going to water as quickly as possible. What have we heard from Senator Maguire and Senator Elstob about the impact of the perks tax on the motor car industry in South Australia? Even the Premier of South Australia, Mr John Bannon, is imploring his counterparts-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not think we want to go on to the car tax. We are dealing with the excise legislation.

—Mr Chairman, I thought it was rather topical. I know that back benchers Senator Maguire and Senator Elstob would not have gone to bed tonight happy if that matter had not been raised. Let me come back to the brandy industry. I think it is important to recognise that impact of the removal of the maturation period will lead to the destruction of the quality end of the market. While it is clear that some people within the industry are supportive of these changes, it is important to recognise that there are no safeguards for labelling, say, imported material which cannot be certified, which cannot be checked or verified and which may well flood the market. In many ways it is already flooding the market, displacing Australian produced brandies. Why is the Government so quick to act to impose this so-called deregulatory measure when it does not take proper account of the difficulties of adjustment in the industry?

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that is significant is that brandy, as we all know, is subject to a favourable differential rate of excise. That has been fought for by South Australian senators on both sides of the chamber over a long period very largely for the reasons--

TALK.START.PARA: —All sides.

—I beg the honourable senator's pardon-honourable senators on all sides of the chamber. We are trilateral. We have maintained that rate of excise over a long period to the advantage of the industry. One of the points the Government is putting forward as a reason for the removal of the maturation requirements is that this will lead to the development of alternative products by grape growers in the wine industry and brandy makers. They will use the conditions available under the excise legislation to produce cheaper product to put on the market, although it may well not be called brandy if these maturation requirements are removed. It seems odd that this Government is seeking to institute a loophole in order to allow the development of an alternative product. That product may well undermine the future stability of the present industry.
—But they can do that now as long as they don't call it brandy; they can produce it.
—That is right, they can, and that is the whole point. The removal of this clause will lead to a change in that attitude. For those reasons the Opposition will oppose these clauses.

That the clauses stand as printed.
