DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1985-86[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1985-86APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1985-86]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I suggest that it may suit the convenience of the Senate to debate the second reading of Appropriation Bills (Nos 3 and 4) cognately with the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86.
—Is that the wish of the Senate? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating Appropriation Bills (Nos 3 and 4) 1985-86 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86. These Bills provide the additional estimates of expenditure for the current financial year. They cover essential and unavoidable expenditure and enable additions to the expenditures provided for in the Budget Bills. The main components of the increased outlays are higher wages and salaries stemming from the November 1985 national wage case decision. The Bills also provide for expenditures due to unavoidable costs and price rises, and such factors as changes in the rate of exchange of the Australian dollar. They provide for expenditures due to fluctuations in these types of variables since the Budget was framed last August.

SPEECH.PARA: Altogether the appropriations in the three Bills total some $940m, made up principally of $755m in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), $183m in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and $1m in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). As I have indicated, that $940m is for additional outlays over and above those provided for in the Bills passed through Parliament after the August Budget was brought down and they should be seen in the context of total Commonwealth Government outlays. We are talking about additional outlays of some $940m out of a total Budget involving expenditures of $69,000m, so those additional outlays probably add only a bit over one percentage point to total Budget outlays. The amount of funds appropriated by these three Bills to some extent is offset by savings in Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2), which were before the Parliament in the latter half of 1985. The savings in regard to those Bills total some $264m, so the net increase in Commonwealth Government outlays over and above those provided for at the beginning of the financial year is some $696.3m. As I have said, that comes close to adding one percentage point to our total Budget of $69,000m.

I wish to go into some of the principal details of that extra expenditure. Some $297m is for extra wages and salaries to meet increases in award wages and other wage and salary costs incurred since the Budget was brought down. In addition there is a further amount of $16.9m for the Department of Community Services to implement revised subsidy arrangements for child care services in Australia. Under the new arrangements the subsidy will be paid on the basis of the number of places child care centres have for children, thus replacing subsidies previously based on the ratio of qualified staff to children. A further $70m is provided for the Department of Trade to enable the Australian Trade Commission to eliminate the backlog of eligible claims under the export market development grants scheme.

In general, payments approved under Appropriation Bill (No. 4) tend to be of a more capital nature than those approved under Appropriation Bill (No. 3). For example, under Appropriation Bill (No. 4) some $16.7m is provided to the Parliament House Construction Authority, the reason for that being better than expected progress with construction in the latter half of 1985-with more work being done on that project than was expected, more expenditure has been incurred by the Commonwealth Government. That Bill also includes the sum of $21m in natural disaster relief assistance to the States, particularly due to drought in Western Australia and damage by cyclones in Queensland.

Tonight I would like to take the opportunity, in the context of these appropriation Bills, to reaffirm the achievements of the Hawke Government on the economic front. Over the last three years Australia has achieved higher economic growth rates than any other member country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to put that together with inflation and interest rates?

—I will be on to that shortly. National accounts data released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that Australia's gross domestic product grew by some 4.9 per cent in the 12 months to last December. That is the third year running that the Australian economy has recorded real growth rates of the order of 5 percentage points, so that over the three years that this Government has been in office the Australian economy has become 16 or 17 per cent larger in real terms than it was at the beginning of the Government's term.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pleasing to note in relation to that five per cent real economic growth some very new information which has been published, I think only this week, on the performance of some of our basic industries. I instance the very strong performance currently being turned in by the Australian iron and steel industry. I know it is of great interest to constituents of mine in Whyalla that in the 12 months just ended raw steel production in Australia increased by 9.5 per cent-a very welcome increase-and pig iron production, another major output of that very basic and fundamental Australian industry, grew by some 14.6 per cent. They are very welcome growth rates and reflect a marked reversal of fortune for the steel industry.

The strong economic performance of our economy in the last three years has allowed the Government very amply to fulfil its commitment to create a half a million jobs in its first three years of office. In fact the Government has exceeded greatly its original commitment. Since the National Economic Summit Conference was held in April 1983, just over three years ago, some 617,000 extra jobs have been created in Australia, which means that the Government's target of an extra 500,000 jobs has been exceeded by over 100,000 even though, in terms of the release of the data, the three-year period is not up yet. So that is a promise very amply fulfilled by the Government. The great majority-75 to 80 per cent-of those 617,000 new jobs have been created in the private sector. Further, the great majority of the jobs are full time. I am pleased to say that in my own State of South Australia, which experienced difficult economic fortunes in the early 1980s and the late 1970s, the situation has been reversed. In the three years to March this year employment in South Australia has grown by 43,000 positions-a very large number of extra jobs. It is a tremendous achievement, reversing the previous decline in the numbers in the State's work force. It is also particularly pleasing to note that of those 43,000 extra jobs in the State, some 28,000 are full time. It is particularly welcome news that in March this year South Australia recorded its highest ever level of employment-595,000 jobs. Not only was March a record month, but so were the months of February this year and December last year. It is notable that in South Australia we continue to break new records on the employment front on a month-to-month basis.

The prices and incomes accord between the Government and the trade unions has been the foundation of Australia's economic recovery. Within the context of that accord-the agreement between the Government and trade unions to operate an incomes policy-we have seen a welcome reduction in the unemployment rate. It peaked in 1983 at a rate of 10.4 per cent-double digit unemployment was the legacy of the Fraser-Howard Government-and by March this year we had reduced Australia's unemployment rate on a seasonally adjusted basis to 8 per cent. That is a welcome reduction in the context of the accord.

It is particularly important to note that great inroads have been made into youth unemployment as a result of the expansionary policies enabled by the accord. Last Friday a South Australian senator, Senator Vanstone, claimed that youth unemployment at present was at record levels. Clearly she has not been examining the figures and is not cognisant of the facts. The facts are that in early 1983 when the Liberal Government, which I am sure had Senator Vanstone's support, lost office, youth unemployment was measured at the rate of about 27 or 28 per cent. It is interesting to note that, on the last published figures, youth unemployment has been reduced to a rate of between 21 and 22 per cent. That is not an acceptable level and we must continue to try to reduce it. However, it is certainly true that in the three years that this Government has been in office, the youth unemployment rate has been reduced by six percentage points.

While we have been having such good economic news on the national front, I regret to say that Queensland is very much the weak link in the Australian economy. I regret to say that on the latest available figures provided by the Department of Social Security on the number of persons receiving unemployment benefits, Queensland is now in the invidious position of having more persons receiving unemployment benefits than the number of such recipients in the whole of the State of Victoria. That is a most disturbing indicator of economic health, or lack of it, in Queensland. Furthermore, the number of persons now receiving unemployment benefits in Queensland total 110,367. That figure is only 8,000 to 9,000 more than the entire population of the largest provincial city in Queensland, which is Townsville. On the latest official figures made available recently by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the population of Townsville was measured at 101,700. That points to the extent of the malaise in the Queensland economy. It is to be hoped that that poor performance can be improved to help to underpin the national economic recovery which is occurring in Australia.

As to the figures of unemployment benefits to the end of March, this is probably the first time that the number of people out of work and receiving benefits in Queensland has exceeded the number of such people in Victoria. It is a staggering proposition. The facts are that on the latest available data Victoria's labour force is 67 per cent-two-thirds-larger than that in Queensland, yet more people are receiving unemployment benefits in Queensland than is the case in Victoria. Obviously, the State Government in Queensland is failing miserably in managing the State's economy.

I looked at the policy speech delivered in September 1983 by Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, Premier of Queensland, in which he said that Queensland's direction was straight ahead towards growth and progress. They are not my words or the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They were spoken by the Premier of Queensland. I regret to say that the unemployment figures show that Queensland is stuck in reverse gear while the Labor States are moving straight ahead. Clearly that is the case.

Let us examine another indicator of the position in the Queensland labour market. In only three months out of the 30 months that have elapsed since the Premier gave his last policy speech in September 1983 has the Queensland unemployment rate been below the national average. There are 30 months of information available from official sources. In only three of those months-November and December of 1983 just after the Premier's policy speech, and in February 1984-has the Queensland unemployment rate been below that of Australia as a whole.

It is interesting to take that analysis further and look at the share of Australia's jobless living in the State of Queensland. One can do so readily with the aid of information from Commonwealth Government sources. It indicates that at the time Sir Joh announced his policies in September 1983, only 14.8 per cent of Australia's jobless lived in the State of Queensland. So at that time fewer than 15 per cent of all the unemployed people in Australia lived in the State of Queensland; but now an appalling 18.1 per cent reside in the State of Queensland. Therefore, there has been a dramatic increase in the share of Australia's jobless living in that State. It is no wonder that population movements show a net population outflow from Queensland in the economically active age groups. I instance the fact that members of the age group from 20 to 34 years clearly are leaving the State of Queensland, according to the latest interstate population figures. To sum up, those Queenslanders are voting with their feet and are migrating to other parts of Australia looking for work.

Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen has turned Queensland into the sick man of Australia and the electorate is becoming increasingly disenchanted with the substitution of rhetoric for positive economic action. I understand that tomorrow we shall be able to read the results of a new Morgan gallup poll, according to the Dateline News Digest which is available to all members of Parliament and which is being published this evening. That poll will appear in tomorrow's Bulletin and I believe that it shows a slump in the popularity of the Queensland Premier. If any reason needs to be put forward for that situation occurring-if it is correct, and I shall await tomorrow's Bulletin-then the state of the Queensland economy will be one of the causal factors. The present Queensland Government for many years has traded on its alleged competence to run the State's economy. If that Government wants to make the running of the economy its keystone for which it seeks credit when things are going well, it must take the blows, the disenchantment of the electorate, and the responsibility when things are going bad. I suspect that is what is happening in regard to that opinion poll.

One of the other side effects of the accord between the Hawke Government and the trade union movement has been to bring harmony into Australia's industrial relations climate. Industrial disputes in Australia, days lost per employee in industrial disputes, are at their lowest level for 17 years-not at their lowest level in seven years but at their lowest level in 17 years. It is very interesting to note that in my State of South Australia days lost through industrial disputes per employee are now at the Japanese level. Japan has been held up for many years as a model economy by people who would criticise Australia's economic policy. Certainly Japan is one of our major trading partners. Therefore, we have to pay some attention to what is happening in the Japanese economy.

It is now the case that in South Australia days lost in industrial disputes are at the Japanese level. I regret to say that unfortunately that does not apply in Queensland. The differences between the two States in industrial relations can be summarised by saying that in South Australia there is a policy of industrial conciliation, of solving disputes. In Queensland there is a very overt policy of industrial confrontation. The difference between industrial conciliation and industrial confrontation has contributed to a very high rate of days lost per employee as a result of industrial disputes in Queensland.

The accord between the Government and the trade union movement certainly has worked to help stabilise and lower Australia's inflation rate. In the last year of the Fraser Government when Mr Howard was Treasurer the inflation rate-that is, the increase in the rate of prices in Australia-was 11 1/2 per cent per annum. That was double digit inflation, despite the policies of the Government that said that we had to fight inflation first, that Australians had to make sacrifices, tighten their belts and lower their expectations. That Government which was very critical of high rates of inflation left office with double digit inflation. The inflation rate is now not 11 1/2 per cent as it was when Mr Howard was Treasurer, but 9.2 per cent. The discounting of the national wage rise in the current wage case to be handed down at the end of this month by 2 percentage points below the consumer price index level and the Government's decision to pass on lower petrol prices to the community following the collapse of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries will help to ensure that the 9.2 figure is a peak rate of inflation and that Australia's rate of increase in prices will fall hereafter.

Despite Opposition claims to the contrary, the prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions has helped to reduce unit labour costs. Unit labour costs, or employee costs per unit of production, are at their lowest level for many years. That is proving to be of great benefit to the country and is certainly helping to raise the level of competitiveness. In 1985, for example, nominal wages or money wages rose by some 4 per cent. By comparison, wage increases in the weighted averages of the economies with which we normally trade grew by 4.8 per cent. So our wage rises during 1985 were lower than the average wage rises in the countries with which we trade. In Mrs Thatcher's United Kingdom, for example, the bastion of deregulated free market policies, wages rose not by 4 per cent as they did in Australia, but by 8.6 per cent. So there is a very interesting comparison.

I notice that the Opposition is about to embark upon a policy of freeing up the labour market and moving away from centralised wage fixing. If it followed Mrs Thatcher's example, it would be looking at a situation with potentially high rates of growth of money wages at a time when this country is delivering relatively low rates of increase in that measure of income. The Government's agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to defer the 3 per cent September productivity claim and discount wages by 2 per cent, I believe, will help to preserve our new-found competitiveness and ensure that any rise in import prices will not be built into Australia's inflation rate. In other words, instead of there being a 4.2 per cent rise in wages as would be the case with the consumer price index, in the current wage case the rise will be discounted by approximately 2 percentage points so that employers will be facing a 2.2 per cent or 2.3 per cent increase in wages.

The 1984 Budget of this Government was the first to be brought down in conformity with the Government's trilogy of budgetary commitments. Broadly speaking, these commitments require the Government to contain the rate of growth in Commonwealth outlays and tax revenue to no more than the overall rate of growth in the economy and not to increase the deficit on the Budget as a proportion of gross domestic product. This is the first time in 17 years that any government of this country has been able to reduce these three ratios. The Hawke Government has cut the Budget deficit from $6,700m in 1984-85 to $4,900m in 1985-86. In accordance with this reduced Budget deficit, the Government has made substantial cuts to the total public sector borrowing requirement; that is, the extent to which the public sector has to go out on the market and borrow funds to finance the excess of its expenditures over its revenues. The public sector borrowing requirement has fallen from around 7 per cent of gross domestic product in 1983-84 to some 4.5 per cent in the current financial year.

In recent weeks there have been many claims by doomsayers on the Opposition benches that there will be a severe downturn in the Australian economy this year, and that there is the danger of an economic recession developing from that. But I place on the record the fact that in recent weeks there have been some very significant declines in some Australian commercial interest rates. The reductions in interest rates will be watched closely by the community, which will be keen to see them continue and spread generally throughout the economy. It is a matter of record now that since the middle of February rates of interest paid by banks on 90-day bills issued by them have fallen very significantly. Indeed, rates on bank bills issued for 90 days have fallen by well over three percentage points from around 18 per cent or 19 per cent in the middle of February this year to just over 15 per cent now. So the reductions which are occurring in these important market interest rates are very welcome.

Over the same period interest rates paid by the Commonwealth Government on its 10-year Treasury bonds which mature in 1996 have been cut by around 2 1/4 percentage points from some 14 1/2 per cent to 12 1/4 per cent. That is very encouraging news indeed in the financial market with the very welcome falls in interest rates. The gloom and doom emanating from the Opposition benches are clearly out of step with the assessment of the economy by independent commentators and the financial and industrial markets. The Government's commitment to budgetary restraint and the accord's stabilising influence over wages and prices will enable the economy to consolidate the three years of high growth which we have experienced into a more sustainable pattern of growth for the future.

A steady growth in employment opportunities is a major objective. It will develop more fairness and equity in the community. It will provide for a steady rise in living standards. On that basis I look forward to the next Federal election with a great degree of confidence.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Corporal Punishment-Ainslie Village, Canberra-Dalkon Shield-Northern New South Wales: Tertiary Education Facilities-Philippines

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware of my interest in the issue of corporal punishment in schools, especially its abolition. This evening I have some criticism to level against the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority about this particular matter. My first criticism relates to a question which I placed on notice on 20 March this year. This question asked for detailed information about the use of corporal punishment in Australian Capital Territory government schools in 1985. Following comments I have previously made at Estimates committees, the Schools Authority should have been well aware that I intended to ask questions this year about this matter. The material to answer the question to which I have referred should have been readily available. Indeed, if I had asked the question at a recent Estimates committee hearing, I expect that the information would have been made available, if not immediately, then within a couple of days. I place a question on notice because I knew I would not be in Australia at the time of the Estimates committee hearings. What I wish to stress is that an answer should by now have been provided to Senate question No. 1005. I see no reason why I cannot receive an answer this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter relates to a news item I heard on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning. The text of this item is as follows:

Corporal punishment will disappear from Canberra's Government schools within 12 months. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has made the decision following completion of a study into school discipline policies and practices. The Chairman of the Schools Authority Council, Dr Don Anderson, said the Council is opposed to corporal punishment. Dr Anderson says only 15% of Canberra's Government schools still use corporal punishment and its use has been halved over the past two years. The Schools Authority has considered an immediate ban on corporal punishment and phasing it out over 12 months would allow schools time to learn a less authoritarian approach to discipline.

I have some comments in relation to what was said. Firstly, the use of the adverb `only' is hardly appropriate in reporting that 15 per cent of government schools in the Australian Capital Territory use corporal punishment. Use of the word `only' is overdone in our society. We see steak at `only' $12 a kilo or motor vehicles at `only' $14,000. Just as people may regard $12 and $14,000 as excessive for a kilo of steak and a motor vehicle, so too would some people regard 15 per cent as an excessive number of government schools in the nation's capital which still resort to the barbaric practice of using the cane.

Secondly, if the Authority has decided to ban corporal punishment, why not do it now, instead of in 12 months time? Some school principals may suffer withdrawal symptoms, but students in government schools would get a better deal now, instead of having to live under the threat of corporal punishment for a further year. But I am not sure whether the ABC radio report is as good as it appears on the surface. I made some inquiries today and it seems that the Authority may not be banning the use of corporal punishment, but merely encouraging schools to abolish the practice. If that is all it intends to do, the Authority should stand condemned as an organisation which lacks the courage of its own convictions. If it can not take a strong stand on this matter, the public may well ask what authority this so-called Authority actually has.

I have been informed that the Authority briefed the media but apparently members of parliament will not receive any detailed information until a report is first issued to government schools and then released to the public in two weeks time. This seems to indicate a disdain towards those who pay the bills. Why could the Authority not advise the Parliament at the same time as it attempted to promote its media image? However, like other senators, I look forward to examining the report on its release and to debating its contents in this chamber. If copies of the report can be made available earlier than planned, the Authority may benefit from the comments of those members of parliament who have a deep and professional interest in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other aspect of the matter relates to a statement I have received from a constituent, attached to a statutory declaration, relating to the work she does on Saturday mornings in Civic as a volunteer for the Hunger Project. In these pages she recounts the morning of 8 March, when she met two men in Civic whom she describes as drunk and probably derelict. She goes on to recount the day. During the day these men were arrested and taken to the police station and released at about 5 o'clock that night, when she took them home and to a function that she attended. Subsequently, at the end of the night, as she was not able to offer them accommodation or find any accommodation for them, she took them back to what they call the Starlight hotel, which is the area behind the Australian War Memorial, where they had in fact slept the previous night and perhaps on many others.

SPEECH.PARA: This woman came to see me about the problem of derelict men in Canberra, of whom there are a number. She was surprised to find, on making inquiries, that there really is not much accommodation for people like this and she feels that it is something that needs to be addressed. It is on that basis that the two representations have similarities.

The Department is looking into the upgrading of Ainslie Village. If it is to continue, nobody would deny that it needs to be upgraded. But, at the same time, we do need to look at the needs of those who require this form of accommodation. We certainly need to look at the needs and the rights of those who live in Ainslie and who wish to live peacefully in their homes nearby; the needs of all people need to be considered.

I suggest that the questions that have been posed by my constituent-that is, what is the intention and what is to happen to people like this in the Australian Capital Territory-need to be answered. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the statement to which I have referred which sets out this story that occurred on 8 March because I think it is meaningful. I will not take the time of the Senate to read it out.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

On Saturday mornings, I work in Civic as a volunteer for The Hunger Project. My work is to ask passers-by if they will sign a card to support ending hunger on the planet, and to talk with interested people about the possibility of doing that by the end of the century.

On Saturday 8 March, I was in Petrie Plaza, working in this way, when I spoke with a pair of young men, whose names were John ( ) and Robert ( ). I realised that they were drunk and probably derelict, judging by their appearance and behaviour, but it is my experience that such people have a very real experience of hunger and understand the fundamental issues of the question. These two men had spent the previous night-a cold night-at a barbecue site behind the War Memorial. At the time I saw them-about 11 a.m.-they were still shivering with cold. Robert was dressed in a T-shirt, jeans and thongs; John slightly more adequately.

We talked about the work of The Hunger Project, and about their situation. They showed me the Good Behaviour Bonds they carried-$1,000 for Robert and $500 for John. A third person, their friend, was due to appear on some charge, and they could not leave Canberra until after that Court appearance. I suggested that we might be able to obtain some warm clothing for them from the Goodwin Market Stall. They were reluctant to come with me-`You wouldn't want to be seen with us'-but they obtained a nice new plastic bag from an expensive shoe store in which to hide their flagon of port so it would not disgrace me.

We were unable to obtain any help at the Stall. It was sheltered and sunny there, so I asked John to wait for me to get my car to drive them to the Woden Rehabilitation Centre. (John claimed to have already been there, but to have been turned away as physically beyond help. This did not seem likely to me). He was certain I would not return, but I assured him I would.

My car was some distance away; I had material to pack up; I had a friend to meet and explain the situation to-it was about 30 minutes before I drove up next to the Stall. When I arrived, the two were gone. Only the flagon of port remained on the pavement.

I searched rapidly around Garema Place and Petrie Plaza. No sign. Returning to the Stall, I asked a gentleman sitting on a bollard whether he had seen the missing pair. Yes-the police had taken them away. No-he hadn't thought they were doing any harm, either. I had arranged to meet them?-don't worry, dear, the system will take care of them!

At Turner, I explained to my friend, Leslie, the latest development, and rang the Police Station. Yes, the two men were in the Watch House. They would be released when the Sergeant considered them sober enough-about four hours, usually. After speaking with a contact in the Salvation Army, I arranged with Bruce, at Lasa, to deliver warm clothes to the jail and to try to find shelter for them Bruce explained that there was no shelter for adult men in Canberra-only one in Queanbeyan, which was often full, but he would do his best.

Other commitments filled my afternoon, and when Bruce rang to say he was not able to help it was already quite late. I rang a contact in St Vincent de Paul to ask her to help, then let the Police know that I would collect the two men myself. At approximately 5 p.m. I arrived at the Station. John, Robert and a third, older man, were brought out to the foyer. The Sergeant took me aside and said that he couldn't believe I would take such people into my home. He warned me that we would almost certainly be robbed. I assured him I would ring if trouble developed, but also asked why derelicts were not arrested in the evening and kept in overnight for their own protection. The Sergeant explained that it was not the policy, and told me that there were perhaps 50 such homeless men around Canberra, who would all take advantage of me if I were to help these two in any way. John and Robert had dinner with us. They were full of jokes and fun, and told us quite a lot about themselves. Each had a wife and child. Robert was from Tennant Creek and had left home at fifteen. With a professional boxing troupe-no doubt to get away from a father who disciplined his children with a stockwhip. And they told us that in the jail they had been given nothing to drink, not washed, and allowed no blanket.

When my friend rang back, she told us that the only possible accommodation would be a 2-berth cabin at the Caravan Park, for which we would need to pay $33 and claim reimbursement. We were not in a position to do this. As a family of four in a two-bedroom house, and with no experience of caring for alcoholics, we did not want to take on responsibility for them ourselves, either.
So, instead, we invited them to come with us to the Woolshed, where we were going with our children anyway. They enjoyed the dance immensely, and created no disturbance at all.

At about 10 p.m., we drove to Hale Crescent, Turner, to retrieve the flagon of port, and then returned them to the campsite behind the War Memorial-the place they call `The Starlight Hotel', and where they had been sleeping, 3 men under 1 blanket, in `the biggest king-size bed in Australia'.
We have not seen them since.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to the following comments in the Fairfax Good Weekend magazine of 22 March last:

SPEECH.PARA: If a Dalkon shield were presented to us now, it would probably still be accepted. Unless the producers give us the full information about the product, we wouldn't know there was a problem.

The person quoted was the medical services adviser in women's health and family planning for the Federal Department of Health. According to that article, the Australian Government has no testing procedures to check the claims that foreign manufacturers or importers make about their products. Their word is basically taken without further question. If manufacturers or importers can get a product on to the market in some overseas country, they can sell it there. Even though the Food and Drug Administration in the United States of America requires manufacturers to apply quite serious and rigorous testing procedures to their products, fraud cannot be ruled out.

A.H. Robins on several occasions withheld relevant information damaging to its further distribution of the Dalkon shield in the United States of America. It went to quite some trouble to prevent material coming out before the Food and Drug Administration. In Australia that company could probably just bluff it out. I ask the Australian authorities whether we have the powers and procedures to deal promptly with a product about which adverse reports have been made, or will the lack of information mean that the manufacturer's word will be taken in the case of serious dispute? I draw the Government's attention to my Hazardous Goods Bill, which goes some way towards solving this problem. However, I believe that we have to answer a few other questions.

It is against that background that I want to put on record some disturbing facts about the development and distribution of the Dalkon shield. I sincerely hope that we have learnt some lessons from that disaster because many women and their families have suffered needlessly. In the case of the Dalkon shield there has been unethical conduct, wishful thinking and outright fraud virtually from the outset. A patent for the original invention was obtained in 1967. The device resembled a policeman's badge in shape and hence came to be called the shield. The device was then modified by the addition of five fins on either side and a new patent was applied for in November 1968. Dalkon shield plaintiffs' lawyers have contended that the concealment of the role of Dr Hugh Davis in the invention of the Dalkon shield was an initial fraud on the Patents Office. Two Special Masters appointed in 1984 by a St Paul court to examine the files of A.H. Robins made this observation about the contentions:
We note that the deliberate omission of a joint inventor from the patent application invalidates the patent.

Next to be concealed was Davis's financial interest in the Dalkon Corporation, the initial marketers of the shield. Davis's share of $750,000 paid by A. H. Robins for the rights to the shield, and 10 per cent of the royalties accruing to the Dalkon Corporation from North American sales, and on top of that his modest annual retainer of $20,000 as a consultant to A. H. Robins, were all concealed from the public. None of this was revealed while Davis was attacking the safety of the contraceptive pill and promoting the safety of the Dalkon shield. He paraded as an independent witness in many forums. His original foray was a brief article in the American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology on 1 February 1970. The article was headed `The shield intrauterine device-a superior modern contraceptive device'. It described a study of 640 women for one year and cited five pregnancies, 10 expulsions, nine removals for medical reasons and three removals for personal reasons. The data covered 3,549 woman-months of experience and the claim was made that there was a pregnancy rate of 1.1 per cent. That was to be advertised throughout the sales of the shield. It was quite fraudulent, but that did not prevent the claim from being rehashed in the Australian and New Zealand Press and in reputable medical journals as late as 1974. By that time the shield had been withdrawn in the United States.

In the initial report by Dr Davis, the fraud was manifold. The average participant in the trials had worn the shield for less than six months. Probably only eight people had been in the trial for a full year. The data went to the statistician three days after the close of the trial. This meant that injuries and pregnancies were ignored. The people who had dropped out were never followed up, nor the reasons for that. Some of the women had been told to use a spermicidal foam as well as the shield. No wonder such glowing results were obtained in this case but were never obtained by independent researchers. A. H. Robins quoted the magic figure of 1.1 per cent pregnancy rate at every opportunity, despite later evidence. In fact, the medical director of A. H. Robins made these observations when the company was examining the purchase of the market rights in June 1970:

Davis' first paper on his first year experience mentions 640 insertions with five pregnancies. However, data given me for the first 14 months (Sept. 68- Nov. 69) covers 832 insertions with 26 pregnancies (none after the 11th month).

That was to be devastating to A. H. Robins' defence against Dalkon shield suits. Similarly, the presence of copper and copper sulphate in the plastic from which the shield was moulded was also devastating. The original patent application said:
An important aspect of the device is that it may be coated with a suitable film of material (to) enhance its effectiveness.

The material could be a heavy metal such as gold, platinum, silver or copper. The copper had been mixed into the plastic since 1969, but no mention of that appeared in Davis's original article. His results, such as they were, were based on a shield that contained no copper. Two days before A. H. Robins took over the Dalkon shield rights on 12 June 1970, a vice-president of the company wrote the following in a memo:

As I understand it, metallic copper was first added for the purpose of improving radio-opacity and to improve the physical properties of the plastic. Then, according to my understanding, they observed that the material with copper was apparently lowering the pregnancy rate, and at this point they reasoned that a more soluble form of copper would further improve effectiveness, so they added copper sulfate for the express purpose of improving effectiveness.

He was troubled by the irritant and astringent nature of the copper salts. He was alarmed that if the device was sold to doctors without any mention of copper sulphate, that would amount to a claim that the results were attributable to the device alone. This whole thing was covered up. A. H. Robins went to extraordinary lengths to maintain that the copper additive had nothing to do with the contraceptive effectiveness of the Dalkon shield. In this way it escaped the Food and Drug Administration requirement that the proper tests on 1,500 to 2,000 people should be carried out for two years before a drug could be marketed. Other manufacturers, such as Searle with the Copper-7, told the truth and were temporarily inconvenienced by the need to conduct tests.

What the Commonwealth Department of Health was told in Australia is not at all clear. In 1974 allegations that the Dalkon shield contained copper acetate which was bioactive were put to the Department. We do not know how far any investigations were carried. Dalkon shields were allowed in without quality-control checking or monitoring of distribution. That is one of the reasons why most figures relating to the shield in Australia are estimates. What we got, along with the rest of the world, was a smaller version of the shield for women who had not yet had babies. No other manufacturer had sought this particular market because of the high rate of menstrual cramps, bleeding, complications and expulsions that had followed test insertions of IUDs in childless women.

A. H. Robins did not carry out any specific tests with childless women before chasing the custom of that particular group. A. H. Robins was also determined to spend as little as possible on both research into the shield and work to improve its quality, especially in relation to manufacturing standards. Employees who suggested how things could be made more safe were routinely told that it was none of their concern. The company was certainly not prepared to depress its massive profit margin-the device cost about 25 cents to manufacture and sold for over $4-in the interests of the consumer. A quality control supervisor suggested that the open ends of the multi-strand supramid nylon string attached to the shield be heat-sealed. This introduced bacteria into the womb, and the whole story goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't let's hear it again.

—I will jump over that section of the story of the tail and how various women became sterile as a result of the bacteria which travelled along the string into their wombs and caused enormous numbers of septic abortions-some of which were fatal. This is what eventually led to the withdrawal of the Dalkon shield in the United States. A remarketing proposal with a monofilament string never eventuated because of various other problems. In September 1974 Robins' Australian salesmen were advised by the General Manager:

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say is persevere and hang in there as I think time will prove that our choice of maintaining the sales of the Dalkon shield in Australia rather than taking the easy way out and suspending its sales will be appreciated by the medical profession and accepted by the female population of Australia.

Senator Peter Baume called for the shield to be taken off the market in Australia in November 1974, and warned of another thalidomide disaster. Early the following month the Medical Council of the Australian Family Planning Association accepted the Dalkon shield for use in its clinics. The first septic abortion report in Australia occurred in the same month. The Family Planning Association decision gave A. H. Robins a ready major outlet for the distribution of the shield, which continued beyond 1977. Originally, it was going to wait for new supplies with mono-filament strings, but that did not happen.

The obvious question is: What have we learnt? I ask the Government that question. Do we have mechanisms that will more readily enable false claims to be tripped up? Do we have a patient reporting service that will provide the sort of statistics that A. H. Robins continued to withhold for years in the United States? One of its strategems used in this case was to order the medical and legal sections of its operation not to pass information to each other. What guarantees do we have that this is not happening now with other products? If the circumstances were repeated, would the Department of Health again take the word of a manufacturer when it was in such great conflict with the experiences reported by women?

Whatever the Department may say, the relatives of at least three women who died believe that the deaths can be attributed to wearing the Dalkon shield. Three thousand women from Australia are joined in the class action in the United States. The voluntary reporting system that we now have does not appear to have brought to light even a small fraction of the cases brought to the attention of the Leichhardt Women's Health Centre and the Public Interest Advocacy Centre since they joined forces in 1982 to warn women of the Dalkon shield risks and to offer legal aid assistance to victims. Surely that constitutes a major problem that the Department of Health must tackle now.

There is also the question of the dumping of the shields after they had been recalled in the United States of America. I believe that it is important that the Department of Health act now. Are Australian agencies and departments maintaining higher alert and vigilance procedures when there are such happenings in the United States and elsewhere on any product? I hope that we can get a considered response to the problems because people are being hurt.

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem faced by the college is one of capital funds for such programs as residential accommodation. Another problem of the college is that the students cannot commute to the college. They live either in cities around the State or in outlying country areas. TALK.START.PARA: —I have referred in the Senate previously to my participation in the international observer delegation to the Philippines election. I was the only Australian and was there as a representative of the Liberal Party of Australia-the Australian Government and the Australian Labor Party as a party had refused to participate. The ALP was not prepared to stand up and be counted as supporting the hundreds of thousands of Filippinos who, on this occasion, were working for free and fair elections and were prepared to risk their lives for such free and fair elections. In fact, some 90 did lose their lives in election related incidents.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that the delegation would issue a report, which it has now done under the title `A Path to Democratic Renewal'. It represents the finding of the mission, which I remind you, Mr President, comprised 44 delegates from 19 different nations. The report is comprehensive, covering an assessment of the electoral law, an assessment of the institutional actors-that is, COMELEC, the Philippine Commission on Elections; NAMFREL, the National Movement for Free Elections; the KBL, the New Society Movement; et cetera-and an evaluation of the electoral process, the political campaign, the role of the media and the administration of the election, looking at the pre-election phase, election day observation, the counting phase and developments during the week following the election.

The delegation concluded-I suppose not surprisingly but very regrettably-that the election of 7 February was not conducted in a free and fair manner. It further concluded that because the National Assembly ignored explicit provisions in the Philippines electoral code requiring that tampered or altered electoral returns be set aside during the final counting processes and for other reasons, the proclamation of the National Assembly naming Ferdinand Marcos and Arturo Tolentino the winners of the election was invalid. Mr President, I seek to incorporate in Hansard the short executive summary from the report to which I have referred.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The International Delegation which observed the February 7 presidential election in the Philippines was sponsored by the National Democratic and Republican Institutes for International Affairs and included forty-four individuals from nineteen countries. The co-leaders of the delegation were the former President of Colombia, the Honourable Misael Pastrana, and the Honourable John Hume, a member of the British and European parliaments from Northern Ireland.

1. The delegation concludes that the election of February 7 was not conducted in a free and fair manner. It is our belief that the Government of Ferdinand Marcos and the Commission on Elections (COMELEC) bear the responsibility for this failure.

2. The delegation finds that the National Assembly, the Batasang Pambansa, ignored explicit provisions of the Philippine Electoral Code requiring that tampered or altered Election Returns be set aside during the final counting process-despite protests by representatives of the opposition party. For this reason, and because of numerous other violations of the Code, the delegation concludes that the February 15 Batasang proclamation naming Ferdinand Marcos and Arturo Tolentino the winners of the February 7 election was invalid.

3. At the same time, we observed millions of Filipinos who were committed to making the electoral process work. Principally because of their commitment, the election succeeded in providing a vehicle through which the national will of the Philippines was ultimately expressed.

4. There is no single piece of ``smoking-gun'' evidence which leads to our determination that the election failed to meet a ``free-and-fair'' standard; there are instead many ``smoking-guns.'' They include the following:
The campaign period was marked by numerous violations of the provisions designed to curb improper campaign practices and to limit the Government's use of its power to influence the election;

The Commission on Elections (COMELEC) did not carry out its responsibility under the election code to provide equal access to the television media during the campaign period. As a result, Marcos benefited greatly from the partisan-owned and influenced television and radio media, though the opposition had reasonable access to alternatives (radio and print) media.

COMELEC officials were unable or unwilling to deal with the problem of fraudulent registration. Safeguards designed to guard against double voting, including indelible ink applied to voters' fingers, were in many areas either ignored or unenforced. The combination of these two factors contributed to an undetermined amount of double voting.

An estimated 3.5 million voters were disenfranchised on election day when they could not find their names on the voting register. This resulted in a voter turnout of only 76% in this important presidential election, as compared to 89% in the 1984 Batasang election. This is a major dropoff, especially considering the absence of a well-organized boycott for this election.

Disenfranchisement appears to have occurred in opposition-oriented provinces or cities. For example, in the ten cities and provinces which had the highest voter turnout, the winner was the ruling party, while in the ten cities and provinces which had the lowest turnout, the opposition won in eight out of ten. Even more striking is that in the cities or provinces where the ruling party won by a margin of 150,000 votes or more, the turnout ranged between 82% and 96% of the vote. On the other hand, in areas where the opposition's margin of victory was greater than 50,000, the turnout ranged between 71 and 81 percent.

Virtually all members of the delegation observed or were told by credible sources that voters were being paid on election day to vote for the Marcos-Tolentino ticket. In many areas, carbonized sample ballots were used as proof of an individual's vote and as a receipt for payments ranging between 25 to 500 pesos.
Numerous instances of intimidation of voters were recorded by the delegation; members of the military, the Civil Home Defense Forces, and Barangay officials were commonly implicated.
Pollwatchers from the designated opposition UNIDO party and the accredited citizen's arm, NAMFREL, were not permitted access to polling in many provinces.

Problems relating to the country of votes occurred during all phases of the process. Major discrepancies between the count kept by NAMFREL-based on hard copies of precinct tally forms signed by all members of the Board of Election Inspectors-and COMELEC recurred throughout the week following the election, evidencing attempts to manipulate the vote count.
Delegation members reported numerous instances wherein precincts recorded zero votes for Aquino despite the claim of the UNIDO pollwatchers present at the precinct that they voted for Aquino.

Hard evidence was uncovered of `ghost' precincts, or fictional polling places, wherein the vote was completely fabricated. In one municipality of Southern Leyte, three such precincts were discovered over and above the 55 authorized. In the 55 legitimate precincts, the vote was 6,371 for Marcos and 5,876 for Aquino. In the three ghost precincts, the vote was 900 for Marcos and 9 for Aquino.

While we have no direct evidence, we believe that the interference with the counting process which occurred after election day was not simply a dispute between COMELEC and NAMFREL over their `quick count' agreement; rather we believe this was part of an effort by the Government and its supporters to buy time so that the above mentioned fraud could be undertaken.

5. The above-listed violations were perpetrated by national and local officials who supported the Marcos-Tolentino ticket. While we cannot exclude the possibility, our delegation did not observe a single election code violation by supporters of the opposition party despite efforts undertaken to monitor their activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —That incorporation has saved me detailing the abuses which were observed by the mission. Let me simply say that examples of such abuses which were observed were, for instance, that an estimated 3.5 million voters were disenfranchised on election day when they could not find their names on the voting register. The mission observed widespread vote buying for the Marcos-Tolentino ticket and observed numerous instances of intimidation of voters by members of the military, the civil home defence force and Barangay officials. Similarly, there were many instances where precincts recorded zero votes for Aquino, despite claims of opposition UNIDO pollwatchers that they had in fact personally voted for Aquino. The mission also received hard evidence of ghost precincts; that is, precincts that simply did not exist. In one such municipality in Southern Leyte, three such precincts were discovered and in each precinct there was a vote of 900 votes against nine-in favour of Marcos.

SPEECH.PARA: The document to which I am referring is now obviously of largely historical value as a record of electoral abuse. It certainly records abuse which, as we know, the Filipino people ultimately refused to accept. I witnessed the motivation and determination of the young people who ultimately stood unarmed before tanks. They are an inspiration to all of us who treasure democratic freedoms but perhaps sometimes lack the courage to stand up and fight for our beliefs. Those young people, the church, the free trade unions, the independent bar, youth groups and, in fact, millions of Filipinos, now have their country back. But the challenges ahead for the Philippines are enormous. Their expectations are high but their new government faces entrenched abuse in the military, enormous economic problems and great social inequities.

Any belief that the New People's Army would lay down its arms has now been shown to be unreal. Its agenda is a different revolution and democracy is not its goal. Regrettably, since Mrs Aquino came to power there have already been some 600 military-related deaths in relation to the NPA and other dissident groups. That presents for Mrs Aquino just one more challenge. The important point I wish to make is that Australia can and must help, first for the sake of the Philippines and the Filipino people, but, secondly, it is in our own interests to help. Obviously a stable Association of South East Asian Nations is important to us. A stable region as a whole is important to us, and the Western alliance is equally important to us. The Philippines is an integral part of that alliance, and I would suggest it pays a much greater price than we do in Australia. The very large United States military bases on its soil is the price it pays-which is of benefit to us.

It would be foolish to overstate the role we can play, but through aid, trade and tourism, to mention just a few avenues, we can play a role in helping the Philippines in its economic recovery. It will be up to Mrs Aquino then to ensure a better distribution of that economic growth.

That in turn will help the fight against the NPA which has been greatly assisted by economic and social abuse within the country. An improved economic outlook and a few runs on the board will help her greatly in acquiring the confidence she will need to reform the military.

I wish to acknowledge the efforts of the international institutes of both the Republican and Democratic parties of the United States who put this mission together. That applies particularly to the Republicans as they invited my Party to participate. Regrettably the Americans are blamed for most that goes wrong in the world and are given little credit for that which goes right. These institutes believed that a role could be played to help the Philippines and democracy and so got out to do something, which, I suggest, is much more useful than staying at home and criticising. Finally, I wish to thank the Liberal Party for giving me the opportunity to participate in the mission. I seek leave to table the report to which I have referred.
Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board (AIRDIB); (b) Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC); (c) Automotive Industry Authority (AIA); (d) Industries Assistance Commission (IAC); (e) Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board (MICLB); and (f) Steel Industry Authority (SIA).

(c) The AIA was established by the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984-no appeal mechanisms;
(d) the IAC was established by the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973-no appeal mechanisms;
(e) the MICLB was established by the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983.

Appeal Mechanisms: Section 47 of this Act provides that application may be made to the AAT for review of any decision of the Board to revoke or to refuse to renew a management and investment company licence; and

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.
None of the authorities listed in answer to part (1) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February 1986 Senator Sheil asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:
